title: Lionel Richie says hes far retirement ahead 70th birthday celebration
story: Share this article          Richie was accompanied by much younger girlfriend Lisa Parigi at the gala as he was honored for his charitable contributions and then performed his biggest hitsHe performed three of his biggest hits All Night Long, Hello and Dancing On The Ceiling to a packed house at the MGM Grand Garden Arena.Before that stars like Snoop Dogg, NE-YO,, Miguel, Leona Lewis, Bernie Williams and Pedro CapÃ³ performed some of his iconic hits.Close friend Shania Twain got emotional as she presented Richie with the award, she said: 'He's my buddy, my pal, he's a lifesaver and a really wonderful friend. I'm happy to be here for him. I have a personal interest in the cause. My grandmother had Alzheimer's. It's a very devastating disease and we just need more awareness.'Humble Richie reacted: 'What you all are doing tonight is helping mankind and actually making a difference in the world. I'm so proud to be here tonight to share this award.'After a warm welcome from Keep Memory Alive co-founders Camille and Larry Ruvo, the evening began with Siegfried Fischbacher presenting Lonnie Ali, wife of late great Muhammad Ali, with the Keep Memory Alive Caregiver Hero award.This accolade is in honor of those who have gone above and beyond to care for those who are unable to care for themselves and Ali's grace and selflessness make her a true caregiving hero.The evening generated the majority of the annual revenue for Cleveland Clinic Nevada to provide service, care and resources for patients and their caregivers in the fight against cognitive diseases including Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Huntington's, multiple system atrophy, frontotemporal dementia and related disorders, multiple sclerosis and more.

title: Ten year old skateboarding champion heading Britains Olympic team
story: Share this article Does this little dynamo have a hope of winning a medal? Experts think so. Skateboard GB chair Lucy Adams describes her as â€˜absolutely phenomenalâ€™, pointing out that she can pull off moves such as a 720, which involves two full mid-air rotations. â€˜There are only a handful of girls in the world doing that.â€™When she was just eight, Sky was the youngest competitor in the Vans U.S. Open, and placed higher on the leaderboard than women 20 years her senior. This year, she won gold at Simple Session, a womenâ€™s contest in Estonia. The course had been designed for men twice her size.         Skateboard GB chair Lucy Adams describes her as â€˜absolutely phenomenalâ€™, pointing out that she can pull off moves such as a 720, which involves two full mid-air rotations. â€˜There are only a handful of girls in the world doing that'Todayâ€™s venue â€” a skate park in Salford, Greater Manchester â€” is pretty much Skyâ€™s UK â€˜homeâ€™. She certainly seems at ease here.One minute we are standing together at the edge of an 8ft drop, talking about her favourite pop stars, the next she has tipped her board off the side and disappeared. No helmet. No knee pads. Argh!â€˜This is the thing we have most arguments about,â€™ says her dad. â€˜She hates the pads, so we donâ€™t make her wear them for bowls this size â€” but we do for bigger ones, and when sheâ€™s on concrete. Weâ€™ve said that if she breaks a bone, we may reconsider.â€™Off she goes, arms out, body bending, sun-bleached hair billowing behind. She swooshes up the other side of the bowl, coming right over the edge, and flips her body upside down. Afterwards, sheâ€™s grinning ear to ear.What does it feel like? â€˜Like Iâ€™m flying,â€™ she says. â€˜The minute I stop, I want to do it again, but higher.â€™         Her father Stu claims to be a social media novice, and was astonished when the first YouTube video he posted of Sky in action got tens of thousands of hits. Another followed. And anotherDo skateboarding prodigies exist? Well, Sky did develop the skills early. Perhaps some of it was in the genes.Before she was born, her father was a passionate and committed surfer. He admits that when his Japanese wife Meiko gave birth to Sky, he thought those days were over.â€˜My attitude to risk changed when I became a dad,â€™ he says. â€˜It seems weird now, given how things have turned out, but when I knew I was having a girl, I thought sheâ€™d want to do things with her mum. I never imagined she would be into the same things as I was.â€˜Sheâ€™s taught me a lot about gender equality â€” about everything.â€™ He had a tiny tornado on his hands. When he tried to wrap her in cotton wool, she broke through.â€˜She was fearless. Sheâ€™d say: â€œHigher, Daddy, again.â€ Sky could surf pretty much before she could walk. She still surfs every morning.â€™The fact that their house is on the beach helps. â€˜School starts at 7.30am so I have to get up at 5,â€™ Sky says. â€˜Ocean and I run down the beach. When Dad tells us itâ€™s time to get ready for school, we say: â€œJust one more wave!â€ â€™They surf on their own? Stu nods. â€˜They know what theyâ€™re doing. Itâ€™s natural for them.â€™There are shared skills between surfing and skateboarding, and theyâ€™ll both be making their Olympic debuts at the Tokyo games. And guess what? Sky hopes to qualify for the GB surfing team, too. â€˜Two medals would be good,â€™ she admits. â€˜Iâ€™d like to win, yes, but even if I donâ€™t, it doesnâ€™t matter. I just do it because itâ€™s fun.â€™ Is she ever afraid? â€˜Yes, but I want to beat it,â€™ she says. â€˜And if you fall, you just get up again.â€™And itâ€™s not just sport. She will try anything, especially if there is a competition involved. â€˜She and her brother will see who can eat the spiciest chilli,â€™ says Stu.Whatâ€™s the most adventurous thing she has eaten? â€˜Tarantula,â€™ Sky says. â€˜We were in Cambodia and they have restaurants that serve crickets and all sorts of insects â€” and tarantula. Someone said: â€œWould you like to try it?â€ and I said: â€œWhy not?â€ â€™Stu claims to be a social media novice, and was astonished when the first YouTube video he posted of Sky in action got tens of thousands of hits. Another followed. And another.The family were asked to get involved with skateboarding charities. Sky developed a taste for mentoring, it seems, and was happy to try her hand at being a feminist icon, too.â€˜Why should the boys have all the fun? Iâ€™ve been to Cambodia to teach children who have never skateboarded before. It was amazing. I said to the girls: â€œJust try it. You can do it.â€ â€™ When she first pitched up at contests, she admits the men raised their eyebrows. â€˜Then they started crowding round to watch and I was like: â€œYeeeeesss!â€ I want to show them that girls can do anything boys can do.â€™In the space of just a few short years she has amassed an extraordinary fan base. She was seven when she got her first sponsorship deal, but the big sporting juggernauts have started to take note. She recently signed a deal with Nike, which meant her image was emblazoned on posters all over the U.S.All the attention has thrilled and alarmed her parents in equal measure.â€˜We are nervous about putting too much pressure on her, and it becoming more than just fun for her,â€™ admits Stu. He isnâ€™t specific about how much money she has made, but it sounds as if her parents are determined that she is sensible about it.â€˜She self-funds a lot of the charity projects, so she will put money into that, with flights for instance,â€™ Stu adds. â€˜And her merchandising goes 100 per cent to charity. After that, well, money has been put away so that it will help her in the future.â€™They certainly donâ€™t seem to be limelight seekers. Stu declines to be in our photographs, â€˜because this isnâ€™t about meâ€™.Nor is his wife mad keen on the attention. â€˜We live in a small village in Japan, and we want to keep it low-key.â€™That may prove tricky. Last year, Sky won the junior version of the U.S. programme Dancing With The Stars, despite the fact sheâ€™d never had a dance class in her life.Stu says that the family were reeling when Sky got the offer, yet Sky insisted she wanted to do it. Why? â€˜Because it sounded fun,â€™ she says.She couldnâ€™t dance but threw herself into training, adapting her somersaults to moves she could do in a sequinned ballgown.While her mum and dad had moved to California for the filming of the show, they hesitated over allowing her to be too much of a media darling. Offers to appear on big chat shows such as Ellen were politely declined.And Skyâ€™s parents were nervous when the idea of her aiming for the Olympics was mooted.â€˜I didnâ€™t think it was a good idea, because I didnâ€™t want to put too much pressure on her, but Sky said she wanted to do it,â€™ says Stu.The family set-up is quite unique, but, as a blueprint for creating a future Olympian, it has its merits.The Brown family have a Californian beach vibe going on, but also a rigid Japanese work ethic. â€˜Her school is quite strict. They donâ€™t mind her being off if we have to be travelling, but she has to do her homework. That idea of hard work is important.â€™Skyâ€™s first language is Japanese, but she is also fluent in English, helped by her time in the U.S. Sheâ€™s very much a global citizen, though. Sheâ€™s travelled all over the world on sporting and charitable adventures. She has released her own skateboard, with proceeds going to charity, and has so far raised Â£13,000.Some of her mentoring has happened closer to home. Little Ocean is his sisterâ€™s double. They are inseparable and share everything, even a bed.â€˜Heâ€™s my bestie,â€™ she says, as he joins her on his skateboard, trying to match her every leap.When he takes a tumble â€” doubtless acquiring another bruise â€” she pulls him up.â€˜Letâ€™s go again,â€™ she says, and they do.Â Sky Brown (@skybrown) â€¢ Instagram photos and videos

title: Longleat Safari Park koalas swapped stately home sleep 21 hours day
story: Share this article â€˜Droppings should just be the right shape, like little rugby balls, the right colour and the right consistency,â€™ explains James Dennis, Longleatâ€™s deputy koala keeper. â€˜Too short or too dry could indicate kidney issues or other health problems.â€™Itâ€™s hard to imagine anyone in Britain knowing koalas better than 26-year-old James, who has dedicated the past year of his life to koala care.He moved to Australia for six months to get to know his new charges before they made their 10,000-mile journey to Wiltshire last October as part of a pioneering conservation project with Cleland Wildlife Park in South Australia, aimed at ensuring the survival of the species. James spends pretty much every waking hour with the koalas, tending them and chatting to them. Even on a rare day off he pops by to photograph them and check everythingâ€™s OK.â€˜It goes beyond love! I would do anything for them,â€™ he says. Which is a good thing, because koalas need a lot of love.         In the wild in Australia, the koalas are threatened by urbanisation, dingoes, bush fires, drought and heatstrokeDespite never knowingly taxing themselves (in the wild a koala can live its entire life never moving from one eucalyptus tree), theyâ€™re prone to illnesses, including a kidney disorder and a virus that affects their immune system. A study has also revealed that 47 per cent suffer from koala chlamydia, which is often inherited.In the wild in their native Australia, theyâ€™re also threatened by urbanisation, dingoes, bush fires, drought and heatstroke.But despite all these problems, their appalling eyesight and teeny brains, koalas have been around for more than 25 million years.         Enclosure keeper James Dennis checks Violet's weightThere are two species â€” the Northern Koala, smaller with finer fur and endangered and the bigger Southern Koala whose numbers have recovered after being hunted almost to extinction in the Sixties.Both live up to about 15 years in captivity (compared with ten or so in the wild), nurse new-born â€˜joeysâ€™ in their pouches for the first six months and are such solitary animals that thereâ€™s no collective noun for them. Until this lot came to Longleat last year, there were just three Southern Koalas outside Australia â€” in Hong Kong and Japan.The journey was two years in the planning, in which government licences had to be obtained and meetings held with Viscount Weymouth (patron of the International Koala Centre of Excellence, which protects koalas in the wild).Longleatâ€™s facilities were inspected twice by officials from Cleland Wildlife Park to ensure they could cope with the koalasâ€™ demands. â€˜Very few places can take Southern Koalas,â€™ says Cleland director Professor Chris Daniels.â€˜You have to be at the top of your game in animal husbandry. Koalas are incredibly difficult to move because they get easily stressed. And if they become stressed, they stop eating and with that goes their water intake.â€™It took two full-time staff a year to prepare eight animals for the 47-hour journey. They trained the koalas to move in and out of travelling crates.They simulated the planeâ€™s movement by driving them around in crates in the back of pick-up trucks. Not knowing which type of aircraft theyâ€™d be travelling in, they even played recordings of all sorts of aircraft engines, so the koalas wouldnâ€™t panic.         It took two full-time staff a year to train eight koalas to move and out of travelling crates in preparation for the 47-hour journey from Australiaâ€˜Koalas have incredibly sensitive hearing, so they would know the difference between one plane and the next,â€™ says Chris.Eventually, five koalas travelled by cargo jet, accompanied by a veterinary team and three keepers who chatted all the way to keep the animals calm.Not that they needed to â€” the koalas ate and slept all the way here. On arrival on UK soil, a fleet of Land-Rovers drove them to Longleat to start their new life.Five months on, they look happy and ready to meet human visitors when Koala Creek opens next week.         When the bears arrived on UK soil, a fleet of Land-Rovers drove them to Longleat. Five months later, they look happy and ready to meet human visitors when Koala Creek opens next weekTo me, they all look pretty much the same, sitting in trees on thick, furry, padded bottoms adapted for a life of sloth. But to keeper James, they couldnâ€™t be more different.He identifies them by the unique pink and black patterns inside their enormous nostrils and by their different personalities and peccadilloes.Maizie, he says, is the cuddly one, Dennis is a bolshy teenager full of hormones, Violet is the â€˜free spiritâ€™ and Coorong is â€˜stubbornâ€™.         Keeper Alessandra Topazio weighs one of the koalas. Longleat staff have to monitor every aspect of the Koalas daily life. The south Australian Koalas are choosing the specific type and even the location of the eucalyptus trees used to provide their daily dietAnd then there was Wilpena.â€˜She was our best eater, our largest koala,â€™ says James, suddenly sad. But after six weeks at Longleat she had lost a kilogram (a sixth of her bodyweight) in just seven days. Despite 24-hour care, she suffered a kidney disorder.â€˜Everyone was here for her final moments,â€™ says James. â€˜We all cried.â€™It was just awful bad luck.Today, ahead of opening to the public, the keepers are planning koala birthday celebrations (involving eucalyptus treats, naturally) and, hopefully, the pitter-patter of a teeny joey.Because, aged two, Dennis is nearing breeding age and the females know it. Theyâ€™ve been bellowing at him and flipping their furry ears to get his attention. In return, heâ€™s been flaring his nostrils and looking moderately interested.If heâ€™s a bit reticent, itâ€™s understandable. As Professor Chris Daniels says: â€˜Koala love-making is a challenging business â€” a fairly aggressive activity, and the boy needs to be big and strong if heâ€™s going to get his way . . .â€™All of which, of course, involves far more effort than this very lazy animal is used to.

title: luxury cruise ship carrying 1 300 people is evacuated off norway
story: The cruise ship Viking Sky after it sent out a mayday signal, off the west coast of Norway. Photograph: Odd Roar LangeNTB scanpix via APRescue helicopters have evacuated dozens of people from a luxury cruise ship which suffered engine failure on Saturday in stormy weather off the west coast of Norway, police and rescue workers said.A maritime rescue service said the Viking Sky, with about 1,300 passengers and crew on board, had sent out a mayday signal as it had been drifting towards land.The crew were later able to restart one engine and the ship was at anchor about 2km from land, at Hustadvika. The passengers were considered safe, although the evacuation was set to continue, the rescue service said.Only 87 people had been evacuated by 5.50pm GMT, and the airlift was set to continue throughout the night, rescue service spokeswoman Borghild Eldoen said. Window panes were broken and water came in. It was just chaos. The trip on the helicopter, I would rather forget. title: cyclone idai climate change key questions
story: A satellite image from the ESA shows the extent of flooding, depicted in red, around the port town of Beira in Mozambique on March 19, 2019 as tropical cyclone Idai cut a swathe through Mozambique, Zimbabwe and MalawiTropical Cyclone Idai brought devastation to east Africa, with strong winds and severe flooding affecting Madagascar,Â Mozambique,Â Malawi, andÂ Zimbabwe. The storm has killed hundreds of people and affected more than 2.6Â million others with catastrophic damage occurringÂ in and around Beira in southern Mozambique.Â Was Cyclone Idai caused by climate change?Itâ€™s impossible to say if the storm itself was caused by climate change but experts believe its impact was made worse by the gradual rise in temperature.How did climate change make it worse?Experts point to three factors.First, warmer air temperatures mean more rain is held and then released. Idai produced nearly a yearâ€™s worth of rain in just a few days - more than two feet in parts of the region.Second, the region has been suffering from sustained drought in recent years, itself a problem associated with climate change. The hard, parched earth was unable to absorb water quickly, increasing the risk of flash flooding.Third, rising sea levels mean that storm surges are much more powerful, increasing the risk of the sort of inland flooding seen in the port city of Beira. Sea levels are about a foot higher than a century ago fed by melting ice at the poles.What do the experts say?â€œCyclone Idai is a clear demonstration of the exposure and vulnerability of many low-lying cities and towns to sea-level rise as the impact of climate change continues to influence and disrupt normal weather patterns,â€ said Mami Mizutori, the UNâ€™s Special Representative for Disaster Risk Reduction.What does the future look like for the region?Rebuilding with climate change in mind will be essential. This was not done after the last major cyclone 19 years ago. Roads, housing, utilities should all be built with future storms and flooding in mind.Sounds expensive, can this be done?Ironically, climate change makes future-proofing more difficult as the regionâ€™s economy, and therefore its capacity to rebuild, has already been depleted by rising temperatures, drought etc.At the Paris climate summit in 2015, then-prime minister of Mozambique, Carlos Agostinho do Rosario, said: â€œThese weather phenomena affect the governmentâ€™s efforts to meet national priorities, especially food security, that are critical to poverty reduction.â€Secretary General of International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC), Elhadj As Sy talks with a survivor of Cyclone Idai, at an evacuation centre in Beira, MozambiqueYes, developed nations, including the UK, are scrambling to send aid and disaster relief teams to the area.The rich nations also pledged in Paris 2015 to ramp up aid to $100 billion per year in restorative climate funding to poorer nations by 2020. This is because industrialisation in the west caused most of the current rise in global temperatures. But so far less than 10 per cent of this funding has been secured.Protect yourself and your family by learning more aboutÂ Global Health SecurityÂ Please review our commenting policyUniversities could title: cyclone idai happens next
story: AÂ major humanitarian crisis has unfolded in the wake of Cyclone Idai, with hundreds of thousands of people in urgent need of assistance across Mozambique and Zimbabwe. In the former nation, rescuers were forced to let people die in order to save others.Will the death toll rise?Â Almost certainly. Emergency responders are struggling to reach parts of the three countries after some roads, bridges and communications networks were washed away or destroyed.The city of Beira with its some 500,000 residents is said to be 90 percent destroyed, while some 152 square miles have been flooded.Â Mozambique's president, after flying over the region, has warned as many as 1,000 people could die. But further deaths could occurÂ if people clinging to hope are swept away by the rising waters or are not reached in time with critical water, food and other aid.And now authorities are warning of water-borne diseases after what infrastructure existed in the largely impoverished countries was stripped away.What is being done to help?Mozambique and Malawi are two of the poorest countries in Africa, and the economy of once-prosperous Zimbabwe has collapsed in recent years.Aid appeals for millions of dollars have begun as the United Nations and other humanitarian organizations rush to deliver food, water, fuel and medicines to the vast affected area.Â Tropical Cyclone Idai approaching the Sofala province of Mozambique on 14 March 2019, shortly after reaching its peak intensityThe European Union and Britain have been among the first to pledge aid. The EU says its initial package to Mozambique, Zimbabwe and Malawi is worth about $3.9 million, while Britain says it will provide up to $7.9 million (Â£6m).The USÂ Embassy in Zimbabwe says it is mobilizing support for partners in the three countries, with no further details.Tanzania's military airlifted some 238 tons of emergency food and medicine to the three countries. Zimbabwe's president has said a number of countries, including the United Arab Emirates, South Africa, Botswana, Namibia and Angola, also were offering aid.Cyclone Idai and climate change | The Key questionsAid organizations and authorities are rushing humanitarian aid to Beira and other areas by air and sea, while rescue efforts push on.The torrential rains are expected to continue in central Mozambique until Thursday. As the water begins to recede throughout the region, the extent of the devastation will become clearer.And thousands, perhaps scores of thousands, of families could be on the move, seeking new refuge after their homes were washed away. title: bbc accused cultural colonialism drama set wales dominated english
story: Larry Lamb and Hayley Mills star in Pitching InThe BBC has been accused of â€œcultural colonialismâ€ over a new drama which is set in Wales but has an English character at its core.Pitching In stars Larry Lamb as Frank Hardcastle, a widower who runs a caravan park on the North Wales coast. His daughter, played by Caroline Sheen, arrives from England to help out.Both the writers and the director are English, and the supporting cast of Welsh actors are not native to North Wales.The comedy drama begins on Monday as part of BBC Oneâ€™s new daytime schedule, but was shown in a primetime slot on BBC Wales last month.The verdict was damning, with many viewers complaining that the Welsh characters have accents from South Wales.The leader of Cardiff Council, Huw Thomas, called it â€œone of the most unfunny, least culturally nuanced TV programmes ever commissionedâ€.Plaid Cymruâ€™s shadow minister for international affairs and culture Delyth Jewell, said the series is â€œcatastrophicâ€ and set in a version of Anglesey â€œwhere the inhabitants for some unfathomable reason seem to have developed Valleys accentsâ€.In an article criticising the series, she claimed that Wales is treated as the poor relation by the BBC, while the corporation has just launched a dedicated channel for Scotland.Ms Jewell wrote: â€œAs licence fee payers in Scotland are treated to a new nine oâ€™clock news programme committed to â€˜showing the world through Scottish eyesâ€™ on their new channel, Wales is treated to a sub-standard â€˜comedyâ€™ showing Wales through English eyes, inaccurate preconceptions about accents included.â€œThis form of cultural colonialism does a great disservice to Wales. Not only do licence fee payers have to suffer appalling TV that bears no relation to their lived experience, but our incredibly rich pool of creative talent is being shunned.â€The drama reduces Wales to â€œnothing but a lovely background for someone elseâ€™s story. No self-respecting nation should be satisfied in playing a bit-part like this,â€ she added.â€œDonâ€™t get me wrong, there is nothing wrong with a good English drama, but in this case we were promised a much needed English-language drama that pertained to the lives of people living in Wales.â€The drama reunited Lamb with Melanie Walters, his co-star from the hit BBC comedy Gavin and Stacey, and also features Hayley Mills.Lamb, 71, said during filming for the production: It's a family comedy drama - but it's about as far removed from Gavin and Stacey as you can imagine.Gavin and Stacey was set in the far suburbs of London - it was just filmed in Wales in Barry - while Pitching In is all about life on a leisure park in Anglesey.Nick Andrews, head of commissioning for BBC Wales, said: â€œPitching In is a comedy drama about family, friendship and community, which will showcase the beauty of North Wales.â€This is not the first time a drama has been criticised for failing to accurately represent Welsh people.Netflix series Sex Education came under fire earlier this year for its Americanised characters, despite the show being filmed in South Wales.One bemused social media user commented: Iâ€™m very confused by this Sex Education show on Netflix. story: Dracula by Bram Stoker, the first ever published image of the Count Dracula.Ever since Bram Stoker penned his ever popular Gothic horror novel, Dracula has been one of the genreâ€™s most enduring villains - his exploits terrifying generations of readers and cinema goers alike.Traditionally, little is known about the vampire himself, an obscure figure who remains in the shadows, emerging only to suck the blood of his innocent victims and spread his curse of the undead.But the latest adaptation of the legend now promises to shed new light on Count Dracula, the Transylvanian nobleman whose arrival at the north east port of Whitby sets off a train of grisly events.Steven Moffat and Mark Gatiss, the writers behind BBC Oneâ€™s Sherlock, have promised to make Dracula â€œthe hero of his own storyâ€ in their forthcoming TV adaptation of the novel.In Stokerâ€™s original novel, published in 1897, Dracula is only ever seen through the eyes of his victims of those trying to vanquish him.Crucially, however, Moffat and Gariss intend to tell the story of the vampire from his own perspective.Old Castle, Banska Stiavnica, Slovakia, where the new Dracula is being filmedGatiss, who has also written several episodes of Doctor Who - including The Unquiet Dead - told The Radio Times: â€œWe sort of made a promise to ourselves and the people who are making it, paying for it, that weâ€™d make Dracula the hero of his own story, and less of a shadowy presence. And thatâ€™s a really clever idea, but we had to make good on it!â€Moffat, whose writing credits include doctor Who and Jeckyll, BBC Oneâ€™s adaptation of Â Â Robert Louis Stevensonâ€™s gothic novella The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde, added: â€œThereâ€™s lots of things that are challenging about Dracula. Having an evil lead character is actually really difficult.â€œThatâ€™s been the main challenge I think. But how weâ€™ve handled, that youâ€™ll have to wait and see. We quickly found out why heâ€™s often kept a shadowy presence. So itâ€™s hard work, but I think itâ€™s worked. Itâ€™s worked well I think, so far.â€In a joint statement the pair said: â€œThere have always been stories about great evil. Whatâ€™s special about Dracula, is that Bram Stoker gave evil its own hero.â€Filming on the three-part mini series, jointly produced by the BBC and Netflix, started earlier this month, with the Danish actor Claes Bang starring as Count Dracula.Steven Moffat (left) and Mark Gatiss on the set of DraculaThe writers described their star as â€œtall, dark and gruesome all at onceâ€, saying Bang is the perfect choice to Â â€œre-introduce the world to Dracula, the vampire who made evil sexyâ€.Bang, best known for his roles in The Girl in the Spiderâ€™s Web, The Affair and Borgen, said last November after being cast for the part: â€œIâ€™m so excited that I get to dig in to this iconic and super-interesting character. Yes heâ€™s evil, but thereâ€™s also so much more to him, heâ€™s charismatic, intelligent, witty and sexy.â€œI realise that thereâ€™s a lot to live up to with all the amazing people that have played him over the years, but I feel so privileged to be taking on this incredible character.â€Some of the scenes for the feature-length episodes have been reportedly filmed at the Slovakian city of BanskÃ¡ title: peoples vote campaigners march london demanding public given
story: Meaningful vote on BrexitThe People's Vote campaign has been accused of overestimating by Brexiteers after claiming one million people took part in a march through LondonÂ in support of a second referendum.Thousands of demonstrators walked from Park Lane to Parliament Square on the 'Put It To The People March' holding placards which read 'Brexit is Rubbish', 'Revoke Article 50' and 'We Love EU'.People's Vote, the campaign group which organised the rally, said more than one million people took part and it was one of the biggest protests in British history.The group has previously been accused of trying to mislead politicians and voters about its level of support.A debriefing document prepared by the Greater London Authority put the number of attendees at October's Peopleâ€™s Vote rally at 250,000 - significantly below the campaign group's claim that they were joined by more than 700,000 people. Â People hold up placards and European flags as they pass Trafalgar SquareMPs have now criticised the group's latest turnout claims and suggested the group are spreading dubious figures.Peter Bone, Conservative MP for Wellingborough and part of the Brexit select committee, told TheÂ : I'm not really sure it can be called a People's March - it's hardly a march and more of a social gathering.I very much doubt the turnoutÂ figure is correct given they got their numbers wrong before.There were 17.4 million people who voted to leave the EU, so the protesters don't represent the country as a whole.People&#39s Vote campaigners in LondonMarcus Fysh, Conservative MPÂ for Yeovil, told The : They've obviously developed this march as a propaganda exercise so I wouldn't be surprised if they had overestimated their turnout figure.Let's be honest - they are marching against democracy and the implementation of a democratic referendum result.They are trying to set up a second vote where Remain is on the ballot. A 'final say' is not what they want - they want to reverse the result.This is a putsch that is going on this week.An effigy of British Prime Minister Theresa May is wheeled through Trafalgar SquareThe protest comes after the European Union agreed to delay the UK's departure. Meanwhile more than four million people have signed a petition calling on the Government to cancel Brexit.People's Vote claimed there were so many people at the march that some protesters were at a standstill for 'at least an hour'.A spokesperson said:Â Our estimate is based on professional expert advice and whatever the exact number, there can be no doubt that this ranks as one of the greatest protests - possibly the biggest ever â€“ that this country has ever seen.We have no doubt that this march is bigger than the last with our early estimate putting the size of the crowd at around 1 million.The day's activities were kicked off by the unfurling of a large banner on Westminster Bridge that read Love socialism, hate Brexit.Brexit | The best comment and analysisMarch attendees included Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, Labour MP David Lammy and Sherlock Holmes star Eddie Marsan.Mayor of London Sadiq Khan called for Article 50 to be revoked, telling crowds: With days to go we're in danger of falling of the cliff, which will have catastrophic consequences.Ms Sturgeon told protesters that the Prime Minister had pitched parliament against the people.Labour's deputy leader Tom Watson told the crowd: At every turn we have been ignored. At every stage Theresa May has doubled down rather than reaching out.She has made it impossible for anyone who cares about jobs, about solidarity at home and abroad, about friendship across borders and between communities to support this Brexit.The London march coincided with pro-Brexit campaigners continuing their March To Leave hike fromÂ Sunderland to the capital.Â They hopeÂ to arrive on March 29 - the original Brexit day.Former Ukip leader Nigel Farage told around 200 Brexit supporters that Theresa May had reduced the nation to a state of humiliation. Although at first some found them strange-looking or were convinced they would fall out of their ears, they quickly became the in-ear wireless headphone to aspire to.Rarely in the two years and three months since launch has demand eased off. As a result, the look has gone from curious to acceptable to â€“ dare I say it&nbspâ€“ iconic. And certainly ubiquitous.Now, the second-generation AirPods have been announced, I talked to Greg Joswiak, Appleâ€™s Vice President of Product Marketing and Kate Bergeron, Vice President of Hardware Engineering about the new arrivals.The new AirPods look, at first glance, like the older model, even down to the price, which remains the same at Â£159. There is no difference in the look or shape of the buds themselves and there is only one visible change to the case: a Wireless Charging Case is now available&nbspfor an extra Â£40, allowing you to place the case on a compatible wireless charging pad instead of plugging it in with a Lightning cable.This means thereâ€™s a tiny LED on the outside of the case to show when itâ€™s charging.&nbspThe 12, 2017Tim Cook, CEO of Apple, speaks about the iPhone X during a launch event in Cupertino, California, U.S. September 12, 2017So far, so good.â€œThe bigger picture, though, is that AirPods simply deliver a magical wireless experience.â€Iâ€™m not sure I like using the word magical, but I see what heâ€™s saying. Pairing AirPods with an iPhone is exceptionally simple. As Joswiak explains, â€œAs soon as youâ€™ve pulled the AirPods out of the box and flipped open the lid on the case, thereâ€™s a simple one-tap set-up, theyâ€™re automatically paired and connected. Once youâ€™ve done that, theyâ€™re immediately set up to work with all your Apple devices, including an Apple Watch, iPad or Mac that uses the same Apple ID. Once youâ€™ve used AirPods, you never go back. Theyâ€™re the most popular wireless headphones in the world. Theyâ€™ve become a cultural phenomenon. For us, theyâ€™re the key ingredient to the wireless future. We designed them to be effortless to use.â€Open the case near an iPhone and a screen will pop up showing the exact battery life. And there are other cool features, like the way when youâ€™re talking to someone, and you naturally take one of the AirPods out your ear to do so, the music pauses, resuming when you put the bud back into your ear.All these features remain the same in the new version. By the way, you can use AirPods with Android phones, for instance, but the pairing is not as seamless.Kate Bergeron explains the new headphones in more detail:&nbspâ€œWhen we were thinking about generation two, we really wanted to focus on this new H1 chip that was designed specifically for headphones. Weâ€™re combining wireless technology which is a hallmark of Appleâ€™s and very highly customised audio. Together, these things create an amazing audio experience. Because the H1 chip is more powerful, it delivers some profound efficiencies, which means you can have Siri available all the time.â€Ah, yes, I forgot to say, another AirPods feature is the way you can tap on either of the buds while they are in your ear and then ask Siri, Appleâ€™s virtual personal assistant, to change the track, lift the volume or even give you spoken directions to wherever youâ€™re going.AirPods 2 on Wednesday, 20 March (Apple)Now, with the new AirPods, you donâ€™t need to tap. Just say, â€œHey, Siriâ€ and it will respond. This is made possible thanks to the H1 chip saving so much battery life that it can be listening for the magic wake words at all times.â€œSo, weâ€™re able to have 'Hey, Siri' listening enabled at all times and still keep the same battery life as before: five hoursâ€™ listening time is still achieved thanks to this new chip,â€ Bergeron says.â€œIn addition, weâ€™ve been able to deliver 50 per cent more talk time so when youâ€™re on a call, youâ€™ll have three hours of battery life, not two.â€Leaving aside whether jabbering on for three hours is really desirable, this is quite a feat. So, how come more talk time but no extra battery life? Thatâ€™s because when youâ€™re talking, listening out for â€œHey, Siriâ€ is turned off.Switching between devices is up to twice as fast, now, too. â€œIf youâ€™re using your AirPods between your Mac, your iPhone and your iPad, switching is even more seamless and the connection to phone calls, when youâ€™re pulling your AirPods out of your pocket to connect to a phone call, is up to 50 per cent faster than before,â€ Bergeron says. â€œIn addition, for some casual gaming on your iPhone, for instance, weâ€™re able to provide up to 30 per cent lower latency.â€My experience of Appleâ€™s stats in situations like this is that the figures donâ€™t mean that much but the experience when you use them is noticeably different.Apple leak reveals bizarre new feature for 2019 iPhoneApple unveils brand new iPads in surprise announcementThe improved chip means improved audio in different ways, too. â€œThe combination of the wireless changes weâ€™ve made in the chip as well as the audio gives a more robust wireless connection, which turns into better audio quality in different conditions. When going outside, some people have found that in that environment there can be problems maintaining RF (radio frequency) links. Now, in all sorts of different conditions we find weâ€™re able to have better audio quality all the time.â€The LED on the new wireless charging case is the main visible difference compared to the previous case. â€œThe cases are exactly the same size, thereâ€™s a slight increase in weight thanks to adding the wireless charging coil but itâ€™s negligible.â€Wireless charging is traditionally slower than through a Lightning cable. â€œItâ€™s just over two hours to charge the case from zero to 100 per cent via Lightning,â€ Joswiak chips in, â€œand around three-and-a-half hours wirelessly. But realistically, customers rarely charge from zero, and the fast charge is the same as before â€“ just put the AirPods themselves into the charging case for 15 minutes and you get three hours of listening time.â€Apple is expected to release a new version of iOS, the operating software for iPhones and iPads, soon. I wonder if the new hands-free Siri feature will have to wait for that, but Joswiakâ€™s reply is elegant rather than factually revealing: â€œWe always recommend that for every new product that customers install the latest version of software thatâ€™s available at that time.â€Reading the runes, I would imagine it means that by the time the new AirPods reach customers next week, that enhanced software will be available to make hands-free Siri work.The new AirPods are a big event because almost no product attracts the level of interest of these little in-ear wireless headphones.&nbsp Next week, if they live up to Appleâ€™s promises, theyâ€™ll be even more desirable.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsBe inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. The family Chung family is locked in a battle with Elliott over HyundaiHyundai Motor was celebrating victory this morning. Its investors rejected a demand for the appointment of several new directors and a huge special idend, tabled by the activist investor, Elliott Advisers, which has become a major thorn in the side of the South Korean conglomerate.&nbspPaul Singerâ€™s outfit may have pushed too hard when it came to the size of the Won7tn (Â£4.7bn) idend it wanted. Hyundai has vast reserves of cash, but its profits have been in decline and the global outlook is cloudy for the motor industry. Given the latter, itâ€™s perhaps understandable that investors baulked and opted for the companyâ€™s offer, even though it is worth less than a sixth of what Elliott was proposing.It was on far firmer ground with its demand for a shake up in the boardroom to foster improved governance and greater accountability at the firm, one of the countryâ€™s famed family controlled Chaebol that have long dominated the South Asian nationâ€™s vibrant economy. They have been facing criticism on a number of fronts, including the charge of taking minority investors for granted.&nbspHyundai creates app to unlock and control vehicles with mobile phoneHyundai unveils walking car to help save livesHyundai to introduce new electric cars for 2022While this battle may have been lost Elliottâ€™s war is far from over.&nbspIt won a dust up&nbspover a proposed&nbspownership restructuring last year, which critics held was designed solely to benefit the Chung family, and cement its control.The next one will come when a revised plan is submitted later this year. Hyundai only needed the support of 50 per cent of its investors to knock Elliott back over the idend and board seats, and it was assisted by investors such as South Koreaâ€™s National Pension Service, the second biggest shareholder, falling in behind the Chung family.&nbspA revised restructuring plan could require up to two thirds support to pass. Elliott should find that easier to win if it objects by aligning with other overseas investors. Their deaths on Pakistanâ€™s â€˜Killer Mountainâ€™&nbspleave a sport reckoning with its own burgeoning popularity, writes Adam WithnallClick to followThe IndependentThe bodies of British climber Tom Ballard and Italian Daniele Nardi were found after a two-week searchTom Ballard will never climb Everest. Before his death on Pakistanâ€™s Nanga Parbat was confirmed earlier this month, the prodigious British mountaineer would joke that he had been scaling peaks since before he was born â€“&nbspin a way, it was what he was born to do.&nbspAged just 30, Ballard already had some extraordinary feats on his climbing resume, foremost among them his record for scaling all six of Europeâ€™s most challenging north faces in a single winter.Ballardâ€™s mother was Anna Hargreaves, the first woman ever to climb Everest solo in 1995 and who, equally famously in the eyes of the press at the time, then died descending K2 the same year, leaving behind a husband, Jim, and two children, Tom and his sister Kate.&nbspShe carried Tom up the north face of the Eiger in the Swiss Alps when she was six months pregnant, and after he was born the family moved to Scotland so Hargreaves could practice on the local crags.The story of how Ballard came to attempt this particular mountain â€“&nbspthe mountain where his body will remain unless and until a recovery attempt is made â€“&nbspis as much about his co-climber Daniele Nardi as it is about the way this extraordinary, exhilarating yet occasionally deadly sport has evolved since Ballardâ€™s motherâ€™s own demise.Ballard, 30, and Nardi, 42, were attempting to reach Nanga Parbatâ€™s 8,126m peak via the most direct route, the Mummery Spur. Published by LannooThe dangers and challenges are such that no one has ever successfully taken the Mummery Spur route in winter before. And for Nardi, who had already turned back from four previous attempts at the same expedition, that was the point.&nbspThe Italian was obsessed with the route, says Pakistani climber and tour operator Ali Muhammad, who accompanied Nardi on his 2014-15 attempt but chose to turn back when conditions became too hazardous.In winter this mountain is so dangerous very windy, many avalanches and cloudy, with zero visibility. Sometimes you have to stop on the wall because you cannot see where to go â€“ down or upNanga Parbat is known as the â€œKiller Mountainâ€ for a reason, he tells The Independent. â€œIn winter this mountain is so very dangerous very windy, many avalanches and cloudy, with zero visibility. Sometimes you have to stop on the wall because you cannot see where to go â€“&nbspdown or up. Then we have no choice:&nbspjust hold on until we get better weather.â€It was only three years ago, in early 2016, when an international team of climbers made the coveted first winter ascent of Nanga Parbat by any route, leaving K2 as the only mountain above 8,000m anywhere in the world that has yet to be conquered in winter.Muhammad says he understands the urge to conquer a mountain in a way that has never been done before. â€œDaniele and Tom were trying to make a new history in winter climbing,â€&nbsphe says.But the Mummery Spur, he says, is not just one of the hardest ways to summit Nanga Parbat&nbspâ€“&nbspit is, in Muhammadâ€™s view, the most difficult unconquered route anywhere in Pakistan, perhaps even the world.Nanga Parbat is seen as a far greater challenge for serious climbers than Everest&nbsp(AP)Simone Mori, the star Italian climber among the group that completed the winter ascent in 2016, has described the Mummery Spur as â€œsuicidalâ€. â€œIt is ice, rocks, snow, and deep crevasses, and thatâ€™s just to reach Camp 2. After Camp 2 there are no crevasses. It is all vertical,â€ Muhammad says.Nardi and Ballard last made contact with base camp when they were at an altitude of about 6,300m. After a search of almost two weeks, their bodies were found using a high-power telescopic lens by Spanish climber Alex Txikon, another of the successful 2016 ascent team. The families consented to the release of the images, showing two figures and a tent lying close together on a small patch of snow at the bottom of a gully, surrounded by jagged rocks.What changed in the sport of mountaineering between Hargreavesâ€™ generation and that of her son, Ballard, and Nardi? Everest is still Everest, the highest peak on the planet, its height unchanged,&nbspmore or less,&nbspfrom 1995 to 2019.Rather what has changed is our perception of what is humanly possible, argues Jake Meyer, a mountaineer who at the age of 21 years and four months became the youngest Briton to scale Everest in 2005.&nbspHe says that the cultural allure of Everest comes from the fact that it wasnâ€™t climbed at all, that we know of, until Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay as late as 1953.The number of climbers worldwideAfter that, the landmarks tumbled:&nbspin 1975, the first woman to reach the summit. In 1978, the first successful climb without supplemental oxygen. In 1980, the first winter summit. All the way to Hargreavesâ€™ own achievement in 1995. To elite climbers, Everest now has little left to offer.Like Ballard, Meyer started climbing when he was young, gaining a degree of competency quickly so that his youth alone was basis enough to set new benchmarks and, almost just as importantly, attract the interest of sponsors to make the expeditions possible.&nbspHe describes a never-ending â€œarms raceâ€ among professional mountaineers to keep pushing the boundaries and achieve things that have never been done before, or at least do them in a way that is new â€“&nbspplaying with the â€œsemanticsâ€, he calls it.Nanga Parbat is the ninth tallest mountain in the world (AFPGetty)Nardi was keenly aware of this competition, and indeed saw it as integral to the sport. Pakistani mountaineer Karim Shah Nizari quoted him in a tribute after his death by saying: â€œHe always said, â€˜A climber is someone who climbs new routesâ€™.â€In a modern world of social media and round-the-clock connectivity, that urge to open up new frontiers and explore the worldâ€™s last wildernesses may be appealing â€“&nbspbut it is also one â€œthat has always been thereâ€ as a driving force for the great historic mountaineers, Meyer says.The difference now is that with Facebook, Instagram and Twitter, hundreds of thousands of fans around the world can follow their favourite climbersâ€™ expeditions in real time.Nardiâ€™s official Facebook page had more than 100,000 followers at the time of his death. The latest updates in the search and rescue operation for the pair were distributed direct to supporters by Stefano Pontecorvo, the Italian ambassador to Pakistan. And Alex Txikon, who has more than 58,000 Facebook followers, shared dramatic photographs and video from the frontline of the search.Alex Honnold, the first solo climber to scale Yosemiteâ€™s El Capitan Could this new exposure, and the fact that sponsors pay a lot of attention to mountaineersâ€™ status as modern influencers, be another factor leading them to take greater risks? Itâ€™s a question Meyer poses. â€œEveryone is so aware of what everyone else is doing,â€ he says. â€œYou have&nbspto be doing bigger, badder, more awesome and, as a result, slightly dangerous things to keep up? I think that if people are treating it like that, then it is a race to the bottom.â€If mountaineering and climbing have taken an edgier and more extreme turn in the past 20 years, it isnâ€™t just on new media formats that people are taking notice.&nbspUp until the turn of the century, the sport was considered fodder for low-rent thrillers like Vertical Limit (2000, starring Chris Oâ€™Donnell), Cliff Hanger (1993, Sylvester Stallone) and The Eiger Sanction (1975).Something changed around the time of North Face (2008), a critically acclaimed German film about the competition to scale the most dangerous ascent of the Alps. In 2010, 127 Hours about mountaineer Aron Ralstonâ€™s fall down a canyon in Utah was runner-up for six Academy Awards.&nbspFinally, this year the suspenseful Free Solo, about Alex Honnoldâ€™s successful climb up Yosemiteâ€™s El Capitan rock wall without a rope, won the Oscar for best documentary.I donâ€™t go to the mountains because I have a death wish. On the contrary, I go there because thatâ€™s where I feel aliveClimbing is now officially cool â€“&nbspand there are figures to back up the assumption that young people who might once have been inspired to take up skate- or snowboarding are now turning to their local bouldering gym instead.&nbspIn North America, indoor climbing is set to be a billion-dollar industry by the year 2021, according to the Climbing Wall Association, with a record 43 new climbing gyms opening up across the US in 2017.The International Federation of Sport Climbing estimates 25 million people are climbing regularly worldwide, with the number of young competitors in the UK up 50 per cent in the past five years.&nbspAnd in another landmark for the sport unthinkable a generation ago, sport climbing will feature at the summer Olympic Games for the first time in history next year at Tokyo 2020.Created with Sketch.Jake Meyer: youngest Briton to climb Mount Everest Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.110 Jake Meyer and K2210 Team climbing at 7400m on K2310 Ottalie and Poppy (with Daddy on the front page)410 Camp 4 on K2 - 7650m510 Jake on way to summit610 Climbing though the glacier710 Jake at summit of K2810 Ottalie, Jake and Saskia at Heathrow as Jake arrives home1010 Basecamp panorama K2 on left, Broad Peak on rightâ€œItâ€™s amazing to see how much itâ€™s changed over my career, and weâ€™re talking 20 years since I watched the new millennium dawn over Kilimanjaro,â€ Meyer says.&nbspâ€œItâ€™s incredible, fantastic, and itâ€™s an inspiration.â€As the sportâ€™s popularity continues to grow and its elite members keep pushing the limits of whatâ€™s possible, a point will be reached where mountaineering must pause and take stock of the element that makes it stand apart from other pursuits â€“ the extraordinary risk to life involved.The Italian climber Mori has been the most outspoken in the community since Ballard and Nardiâ€™s deaths, telling The Times newspaper that â€œif we continue to say they were just unlucky, the risk is someone will die there next yearâ€.And if the trend continues for increasingly young climbers to seek out the road less travelled, in search of new and more impressive feats, the dangers posed are not just from the mountains themselves.&nbspSearchight)Nowhere is this more evident than with Nanga Parbat. In 2013, a major terrorist attack was launched at the mountainâ€™s base camp, itself a remote outcrop 4,200m above sea level that can only be reached on foot.&nbspThe attack, claimed by the Pakistani Taliban, killed one local guide and 10 international climbers, among them an American-Chinese citizen who was believed to have been the prime target for the gunmen in a kidnapping gone wrong.In 2013 at Nanga&nbspParbat&nbspbasecamp a&nbspterrorist attack by Pakistani Taliban claimed the lives of one guide and 1o international climbersAfter the massacre, the gunmen walked for five hours before eating breakfast at a village and dissipating in the small hours of the morning. An AFP report a year on from the attack suggested most, if not all of the perpetrators remained at large.&nbspThe 2013 attack aside, the Gilgit Pakistan region where most of the countryâ€™s biggest mountains lie is generally very safe, far from the restive western border with Afghanistan.Trekkers and climbing enthusiasts are starting to return to the region in larger numbers and can expect encouragement from visa officials and a warm welcome from locals, says Karra Hadri, spokesman for the Alpine Club of Pakistan, the sportâ€™s governing body in the country.&nbspHadri, who remembers Ballard from the time when he visited Pakistan as a toddler with his mother and was carried up to K2 base camp on a porterâ€™s back, says last year there were more than 40 major expeditions in Pakistan â€“&nbspup from just one or two in the years after the 911 attack.The Bigger Red Nose Climb: Charity trek could do with less BallsStray dog follows climbers to become first to reach Himalayan summitWoman becomes first in India to climb â€˜men onlyâ€™ sacred mountainBut he is concerned that growing numbers of young people will come to the country seeking adventure and put their lives in danger. He is calling for a change to the regulations for permits, so that climbers must prove themselves on smaller peaks before attempting any of Pakistanâ€™s five 8,000m-plus summits.â€œMountaineering in Pakistan, especially above 8,000m, can be very difficult compared to the rest of the world,â€ he says. â€œWe still have many mountains that have not been climbed, but youngsters need to know the risks. They should have a lot of skill, a lot of experience, and much budget. And they should go in a group,&nbspnot just one or two alone.â€Hadri was closely tracking the progress of the search operation over the past two weeks and was â€œvery sorry to hearâ€ about Nardi and Ballardâ€™s fates. â€œTomâ€™s mother was a brave lady,â€&nbsphe adds.Ballard is survived by his sister, Kate, who posted a message on Facebook after he went missing thanking people across the world for their â€œlove and thoughtsâ€, and by his girlfriend Stefania Pederiva, who wrote: â€œI will find you in nature, in the rivers, in the trees, in the mountains, you will always be my most beautiful rock.â€Nardi is survived by his wife Daniela and a son Mattia, who is just six months old.&nbspAnd while the sport mourns two of its most promising sons, climbers as a whole are stoic about the risks they take in pursuit of their passion.&nbspMeyer, who last year joined an elite group of only 10 Britons to have scaled K2, says he cannot imagine removing the element of danger from mountaineering,&nbspdespite having, like Nardi, young children at home.â€œI donâ€™t go to the mountains because I have a death wish. On the contrary, I go there because thatâ€™s where I feel alive,â€ he says.&nbspâ€œIf you remove the element of risk completely, then what you are left with is almost every other sport. Having children didnâ€™t change my desire to want to go, but what it did was it gave me three times the reasons to come home safe.â€Weâ€™ll tell you whatâ€™s true. Then on 25 October a cow fell ill on a farm near the market town of Oswestry in Shropshire.That was the beginning of an epidemic that only ended five months later, with the farming business on its knees and huge areas of the country covered by overlapping five-mile exclusion zones.A total of 442,000 animals had been slaughtered in 2,364 separate outbreaks. In nine days, Scottish farmers and dealers reach the more important deadline when they can apply for a resumption of overseas exports, because then they will have been free of the disease for 90 days.The auction at Kirkwall, capital of the Orkneys six miles off the mainland, was seen as a trial run for the resumption of trade in other unaffected areas of the United Kingdom.Though no more than two dozen buyers, many of them mainland farmers from Aberdeenshire, made the ferry trip for yesterdayâ€™s sale, only auction and government veterinary officials, and representatives from the Scottish Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, were allowed close contact with the livestock. The buyers, dressed from head-to-toe in hats, clean boiler suits, rubber boots and white plastic raincoats, had to forgo the usual close inspections of the cattle before the sale began.For the Orcadians, the resumption of the weekly cattle mart was more than just a lifeline for business. The social effect of the closure has been devastating. Cost of epidemic put at Â£2.6bn8 March: more than 100 cases. Chief veterinary officer&nbspJim Scudamore&nbspsays outbreak will last â€˜for a long timeâ€™13 March: first case in France. US and Canada ban European exports22 March: first case in Ireland. About 50 new cases reported daily28 March: Blair asks public to visit rural areas to limit cost to tourism2 April: Blair announces general election will be held on 7 June23 April: suspected case of human catching virus25 April: Phoenix the calf saved from cull3 May: Blair says UK is in â€˜home straightâ€™&nbspafter 1,536 cases and 2.5 million slaughtered4 May: hundreds of footpaths reopened7 May: government announces Â£24m package to help businesses Â£625m expected for farmers3 July: cost to tourism put at up to Â£4bn18 July: Blair rules out public inquiry9 August: start of three independent inquiries20 August: first sale of live cattle since start of crisis, in Orkney islandsAt the Kirkwall sale, Jim Walker, president of the National Farmersâ€™ Union Scotland (NFUS), warned that complacency could reignite the epidemic. â€œWe have to remember that foot-and-mouth is still raging across the border in England,â€ he said. â€œThe last thing we want is for it to start up again in Scotland, because then all the games are off, and weâ€™ve got 3.5 million animals to shift between now and the end of the year.â€œWe have been through hell and back and this is a small but important step forward. Thereâ€™s much still to do to get out of the mess that foot-and-mouth has caused and get the farmers back to a kind of normality.â€Steven Metcalf, chairman of Orkney Auction Mart, said: â€œThe social effect of the mart reopening is good news. Early in the outbreak people were frightened to move around and werenâ€™t visiting neighbours or friends. It is a good boost for the morale of agriculture and it is a step nearer to normal trading and normal life.â€Although the slaughter of more than 800,000 animals north of the border has so far limited the number of confirmed cases to 187, Maria Limonci, spokeswoman for the NFUS, said Scottish farmers needed to see export bans lifted. â€œAround 40 per cent of the sheep produced in Scotland usually go out of the country and at present they have nowhere to go,â€ she said. â€œMore farmers deal in sheep than cattle, and this was only one sale. Itâ€™s a huge step in the right direction but it doesnâ€™t mean things are now OK.â€œWe have to hope nothing goes wrong in next few days. Having 90 clear days would give Scotland grounds to put forward the proposal to Europe to allow exports to restart.â€In England, continuing restrictions prompted 600 farmers yesterday to demand a public inquiry into the handling of the crisis.David Handley, head of the pressure group Farmers For Action who spearheaded last yearâ€™s fuel blockade, led a protest march from Hyde Park to Downing Street to hand in a petition condemning the governmentâ€™s policy on dealing with the crisis and the failure to implement a vaccination strategy to prevent the spread of the disease.Although the turnout was lower than expected, protesters included farmers from foot-and-mouth hotspots in North Yorkshire, Cumbria and Devon and Cornwall.Up to 3,000 civil servants at the Department of the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs held a one-day strike on 20 August 2001 over pay inequalities that followed formation of the new departmentThis article first appeared in The Independent on 21 August 2001Weâ€™ll tell you whatâ€™s true. They came bearing balloons and banners, face paints and flags â€“ and, above all else, smiles and good humour.â€œHave you ever seen a more polite crowd?â€ asked Silvia Angelotti, an Italian business analyst who has lived in London for 22 years. â€œBelieve me, a march of a million people in Italy â€“ it is not so calm, not so orderly, I think.â€Heseltine says PMâ€™s No10 speech â€˜affront to parliamentary democracyâ€™The best signs from the Put It To The People march in Londonâ€˜Millionâ€™ protesters gather in London for march against Brexit Celebrities fund transport to Brexit protest for new EU referendumSurrounding Ms Angelotti as she walked down Whitehall â€“ to where speakers included London mayor Sadiq Khan, SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon and The Independentâ€™s editor Christian Broughton â€“ was a sea of noise and a mile of colour. Or, rather, a mile of blue and yellow.The shades of the EU were everywhere, from teenagers resplendent in streaks of yellow eyeliner to mums (and dads) donning long blue wigs. Think cup final day on Wembley Way, and you have the right sort of vibe. Only here, supporters were asking â€“ given the closeness of the first result, given the misinformation they say was spread, and given the ever-unfolding sense of calamity â€“ for a chance to rethink and replay.â€œThatâ€™s not an unreasonable request,â€ said Sorcha Kirker, an archaeology student at University of the Highlands and Islands (UHI) in Scotland. â€œTheresa May has given parliament two votes on this â€“ and she wants another â€“ so why are the people being denied a second say? That isnâ€™t democracy.â€Ms Kirker herself&nbspwas speaking after a 28-hour journey to be in London. The 27-year-old lives on Orkney. To get to the capital, she had to leave home at 4.30am on Friday, take a boat to the mainland town of Thurso, travel by train to Inverness, and then, at 9pm, catch the 12-hour overnight bus to London.If youâ€™re reading this anytime between 8.30pm on Saturday and 10pm&nbspon Sunday, sheâ€™s still on her way back home again.â€œAm I tired?â€ she asked. â€œWell, I got about two hours sleep on the bus so thatâ€™s something. You come to something like this and adrenalin takes over anyway. There are 24 of us here from the UHI, and weâ€™ve all come because this is too important to miss because of something like geography. Itâ€™s our future. Brexit is a disaster. It takes away so many opportunities from young people that our parents had â€“ that canâ€™t be fair.â€She and her group were carrying massive EU flags â€“ but placards were largely the order of the day.Indeed, if national referendums could be initiated by the sheer originality of signs being waved alone, itâ€™s probably fair to say, the Electoral Commission would, right now, already be organising a Final Say vote.They varied from pop cultural references (â€œFrankie Says Remainâ€) to the poetic (â€œLetâ€™s stay among the starsâ€), to the somewhat crude: â€œIf only Nigelâ€™s dad had been so keen to pull out,â€ read one.Bright yellow stickers featuring the slogan â€œBollocks to Brexitâ€, meanwhile, were everywhere. Including, by the end of the day, entirely covering the Cabinet Office front door in Whitehall. After one person&nbspstuck their sticker there, hundreds more protestors followed suit â€“ turning this historic door yellow.â€œIf Theresa May really thinks she knows how we feel, she might want to look at her own Cabinet Office entrance next time she passes,â€ said Rob Hollinger, as he added another circular sticker to the mass. â€œShe says she speaks for the British public. She doesnâ€™t speak for anyone here.â€It was a sentiment shared by 14-year-old Jacob Henry. â€œI got off my Xbox to be here,â€ his placard told the world.The youngster, from Milton Keynes,&nbspwas there with his parents and 16-year-old sister Alice.â€œI donâ€™t know if any of this will make a difference,â€ his dad Leroi, a 49-year-old academic, said. â€œBut maybe the momentum is starting to move in favour of a second vote. I feel the country is starting to shift but I donâ€™t know if it will be too late. But I just think, as a family, we felt we had to try to do something. We had to be able to say in future we gave this a shot.â€Pursued by a toilet, Farageâ€™s foot soldiers slog 270 miles for BrexitIt was a hopefulness and positivity that infused the spirit of the whole procession.With a petition asking for Article 50 to be revoked topping 4&nbspmillion signatures even as the march started, many people felt, now more than ever, the tide of opportunity was turning towards them.Certainly Alice Joinel hoped so. She was the mother of possibly the youngest march participant of all. Carried in a papoose&nbspwas nine-week-old Anouk.â€œHowâ€™s she found it?â€ said Alice, who works in publishing in London. â€œSheâ€™s actually slept through most of it. Woke up for the odd feed, then gone back to sleep again. She seems pretty unfazed.â€The 32-year-old came because she felt it was important for the little oneâ€™s future.&nbspâ€œLeaving the European Union is going to make her future so much harder and with so fewer opportunities,â€ she said. â€œAnd as a parent, thatâ€™s unbearable. So we had to come. Her dad â€“ my partner â€“&nbspis actually French, so you might say she wouldnâ€™t even be here without the EU â€“ thatâ€™s how important it is to us.â€As the day came to a close â€“ anti-Brexit chants still filling the twilight â€“ a band could be heard finishing off in Trafalgar Square: Brass Against Brexit.How did march go for the group?â€œBrilliant,â€ said James again. â€œA few of us in this band play&nbspGlastonbury every year and weâ€™ve played the Rio carnival and, of course, itâ€™s impossible to compare. But this was special: just people getting into it, waving their flags, giving us thumbs up. It felt like we were a part of&nbsphistory.â€Weâ€™ll tell you whatâ€™s true. You can form your own view.At The Independent, no one tells us what to write. Thatâ€™s why, in an era of political lies and Brexit bias, more readers are turning to an independent source. PoliticsCan the House of Commons possibly agree on anything when it comes to Brexit?Theresa May is rapidly running out of time and options on Brexit.&nbspThe EUâ€™s latest demands, announced on Thursday, are clear: either she secures&nbspMPsâ€™ approval for her exit deal next week, or the UK must come up with an alternative&nbspway forward&nbspif it is to avoid crashing out of the bloc on 12 April.The prime minister is likely to try to hold a third vote on her proposed agreement early next week&nbspbut government sources are privately pessimistic&nbspabout the prospect&nbspof&nbspMPs&nbspsuddenly approving a deal&nbspthey have already comprehensively rejected twice.&nbspThere is also the matter&nbspof whether John&nbspBercow, the Commons speaker, will allow another â€œmeaningful voteâ€ to go ahead, given he has previously said the&nbspagreement must have changed â€œsubstantiallyâ€ before another vote can be held on it.With Ms Mayâ€™s deal looking unlikely to pass,&nbspattention has quickly turned to what kind&nbspof alternative plan the Commons could&nbspsupport.&nbspTory MPs to be offered free votes on Brexit â€˜plan Bâ€™, minister hintsDowning Street is now said to be considering holding a series of â€œindicative votesâ€ to let MPs&nbspgive their views on how to proceed if Ms Mayâ€™s deal is indeed rejected again.This would involve MPs&nbspvoting on a series of possible Brexit outcomes to determine which was the most popular.&nbspThe votes would not be legally binding&nbspbut would give ministers a strong sense of what kind of outcome, if any, could&nbspcommand a Commons majority.Pro-EU&nbspcabinet ministers including Greg Clark, Damian Hinds and Amber Rudd have been proposing&nbspthis approach for several months, urging the prime minister to try to find a&nbspbasis for a cross-party compromise.And last week, Ms Mayâ€™s deputy, David Lidington, told MPs&nbspthat if the prime ministerâ€™s&nbspdeal was voted down for a third time, the government â€œwould facilitate a process ... To allow the house to seek a majority on the way forwardâ€. This was confirmed by Mr Clark, the business secretary, on Friday,There are several ways that this could happen.Created with Sketch.Tariffs in the event of a no-deal Brexit  Show all 15Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.There will be tariffs on pork in order to protect British farmersThere will be tariffs in place on some cheeses including â‚¬22.10100kg of cheddar, â‚¬19.10100kg of processed cheese and â‚¬18.60100kg on some blue cheesesThere will be no tariffs in place on milkThere will be no tariffs on car parts imported from EuropeThere will be no tariffs on alcoholic drinks - Otherwise they will be setting us up to fail.â€œWe have all been working very hard to craft alternative compromises and the government, frankly, hasnâ€™t a clue where the potential for consensus lies because it hasnâ€™t engaged properly.â€Then there is the question of the process by which&nbspMPs&nbspwould actually vote.One system would see the Commons ide on a series of yesno votes on specific proposals in the usual way.&nbspNorway-style Brexit may not be right for UK, says Icelandic PMWho is left to stop Theresa May from leading us to a no-deal Brexit?Seven Labour frontbenchers set to join Put it to the People march This is likely to appeal to Downing Street because, if all the alternatives were voted down, Ms May could insist her deal was the only viable outcome. The danger, though, is that no option receives a majority.&nbspIn a bid to avoid this â€œlast man standingâ€ scenario, an alternative devised by Sir Oliver would involve indicative votes&nbspusing a paper ballot, adapting the â€œdeferred isionsâ€ method&nbspused to hold some Commons votes.&nbspThis would allow MPs to rank Brexit outcomes in order of preferences, rather than simply voting yes or no to each one.&nbspAnother proposal&nbspwould see various rounds of voting held, with the least popular option being discarded at each stage.If&nbspindicative votes are to uncover the basis for a possible consensus in parliament, MPs would need to be free to vote with their conscience&nbsprather than whipped by their parties.Brexit minister Kwasi Kwarteng appeared to confirm this on Friday, telling the Commons: â€œIf the house is being asked to decide a way forward, it would be surprising if those votes were not free votes.â€If Ms Mayâ€™s deal is rejected once again, it is likely&nbspthat parliament will&nbspbe given its first formal opportunity to vote on what type of Brexit it wants â€“&nbspjust days before Britain was supposed to be leaving the EU.With ongoing doubts over whether any option would command a Commons majority, though, it is far from clear whether indicative votes&nbspwill provide the route out of the crisis that supporters hope they will.&nbspGot an unanswered question about Brexit?
