title: national living wage uk 2019 budget 2018 increase minimum wage 16 18 25 year olds
story: But Chancellor Philip Hammond has announced a further increase for some workers from .The National Living Wage is the amount of money all employees aged over  are legally entitled to.It used to be known as the National Minimum Wage, but it was re-branded in .The National Living Wage increased fromÂ Â£. to Â£.Â for those aged  and over.The  pence-an-hour rise was introduced on Sunday April , .From April , the National Living Wage will increase by  pence-an-hour to Â£..The compulsory National Living Wage was introduced in .The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.In Budget , Chancellor Hammond announced that lowest-paid workers will get another pay rise from next year to a minimum of Â£. per hour.Its a five per cent hike, which will come into force from April, and will benefit around .million workers.Mr Hammond said: From April [the National Living Wage] will rise again, handing a full-time worker a Â£ annual pay increase.Hammond is aiming to get the wage to Â£ by .It is dferent to the real living wage which is voluntary and not fixed by the government.The National Minimum Wage is the amount workers aged under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.However, the amount dfers depending on age and whether the worker is on an apprenticeship scheme.From April  the rate for National Living Wage and National Minimum Wage is:From April  the rate for National Living Wage and National Minimum Wage will be:The national limits are legally binding.Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

title: worlds craziest houses
story: But some homeowners have gone all out with their property - here we have pulled together ten of the most outrageous houses from all over the world.Dubbed the Heliodome, this house in France has been described as the â€œultimate solar architectureâ€.Its eye-catching design - constructed by a cabinet maker - is not just for a unique look but to capture the maximum amount of solar rays as possible.It provides free heating in the winter and cools down the house in the summer.But although it is an eco-friendly way of producing heat, many locals have complained about itâ€™s look saying it doesnâ€™t fit in with the French countryside.The giant seashell house is a joy to look at - with dozens of coloured mosaics that light up the indoors living space.The multicoloured house is in Mexico City and was built in .It is full of plants and natural light after being carefully designed but has all the features to make it a modern home.Despite its unusual shape it was designed to fit in with the natural surrounding and make the occupants feel like they were immersed in the wilderness.This WC-shaped house is made from steel, white concrete and glass, with a suggestive opening in the roof.It is in Seoul, South Korea, and continues the bathroom theme as it is full of toilets.The toilet house was built by Sim Jae-duck, chairman of the organising committee of the Inaugural General Assembly of the World Toilet Association.It is called â€œHaewoojaeâ€ which means â€œa place of sanctuary where one can solve oneâ€™s worriesâ€ in Korean.The upside down house is in Affoldern, Germany, and took only six weeks to build.It cost about â‚¬, and has an interior which is very disorientating to visitors.It was build in the village near the Edersee Lake in , and comes complete with bedrooms, a kitchen and bathroom.Every item, including crockery, a bath, knives and a toilet, is glued to the ceiling.Star Trek fans can live in a replica of the Voyager, complete with out of this world lighting and decor.The studio flat in Hinckley, Leicestershire, has been lovingly decked out with the main commands control.No detail has been overlooked in the m flat in the Midlands.It went on sale in  for Â£,.The Keret House in Warsaw, Poland, was the worldâ€™s narrowest house when it was built in .The tiny structure is squeezed in between two other buildings and has been described as more of an art installation.Apparently not as claustrophobic as it looks at cms at its widest point, a long ladder takes the occupant up through ious rooms, which look more like shelves.It was planned to be a temporary home for travelling writers.This snappy home is the work of an artist who died two months before it was completed.The crocodile house in the middle of Abidjan, Ivory Coast, is completely hollow.It was completed in  and is now lived in by Thierry Atta, who helped to build it.With windows and a bedroom the unique home is completely liveable and is a popular meeting place for many people in the neighbourhood.This lonely house was built in the middle of a river in .It is perched on a small rock near the Serbian town of Bajina Basta.It was built by a group of young men who thought the rock would be the best place for a tiny shelter, after they needed to rest while out swimming.The man who lives there today was part of the group and has seen off floods and high winds in his little home.One of the strangest homes in the world is one shaped like a giant glittering grand piano and a violin.It is in Huainan, China, and was built in .It features a glass violin propped up against the huge piano, which is the entrance to the house.The piano has a roof terrace beneath a canopy shaped like itâ€™s open top.

title: mps vote theresa mays deal brexit slipping hardliners chasing fantasy
story: Brexit is slipping away.It risks being killed off entirely by the very MPs who claim to love it the most â€” Conservative backbench Eurosceptics still chasing Â­fantasy Brexits.Since last week, the options have changed.First, Parliament voted to rule out No Deal. Then MPs backed a Brexit delay.Itâ€™s asthe House of Commons is Â­following Tony Blairâ€™s step-by-step guide to overturning the  referendum.A No Deal Brexit will only happen in nine daysâ€™ timethe EU refuses an Â­extension. That is unlikely.Theresa May will beg for a delay, whatever the conditions.EU members will not want to be blamed for a messy No Deal outcome.From next week, MPs could start voting on their preferred Brexit options through so-called indicative votes. Spoiler alert â€” they will not end up backing a harder exit.I know there are Leave voters who do not like Theresa Mayâ€™s Brexit deal.Butyou do not like her deal, look at the alternative options for softer Brexits, which would be far worse for the country.If you think this deal risks the UK Â­getting stuck in a customs union, just wait till you see what the deal would look like with Labourâ€™s â€œpermanentâ€ customs union glued on top.Better to have an imperfect route to controlling our own trade policy than no route at all.If you do not like the fact that, under the PMâ€™s deal, we would have to keep existing EU goods and agricultural rules, imagine staying in the Single Market or, as it is rebranded, Common Market .. We would lose the veto over goods rules which we have in the backstop, and be forced to follow rules on services too.Even in a worst-case scenario, Theresa Mayâ€™s deal lets us escape the EUâ€™s â€œever closer unionâ€ political project and seize control of our own immigration policy.We would be in control of almost all our economy and not have to pay a penny for it on an ongoing basis.It is far better than most critics will admit. Thanks to changes secured at Strasbourg last week, we have new protections.The EU can no longer do what French President Macron arrogantly threatened. It will not be able to use the backstop as a â€œtrapâ€ to demand access to UK fishing waters.The EU cannot just say â€œnonâ€ to every sensible idea for resolving the Irish border issues. The so-called Star Chamber of MPs were quick to reject the Strasbourg changes.But they should listen to the Irish opposition party.Their Brexit spokesperson said: â€œWe have come a long wayâ€ from a â€œbullet-proof, rock-solid, cast-iron backstopâ€.Or how about top barrister Lord Â­Pannick  He is the QC who won the case for Gina Miller against the Government.He argues that in some circumstances the UK could terminate the deal through the so-called Vienna Convention.Conservative Eurosceptic big beasts, from ex-leader Michael Howard to former Chancellor Norman Lamont, have all weighed in behind the deal.David Davis, who resigned over Â­Chequers, is now onside.Lord Trimble, who won the Nobel Peace Prize for the Good Friday Agreement, has backed it. If he can live with the backstop, that should count for something.But some Eurosceptic back- benchers still refuse to support the PMâ€™s deal.Led by Jacob Rees-Mogg, they would prefer a harder deal. But face facts. There is no harder Brexit on offer.With No Deal out of reach, there is no incentive for the EU to provide any more concessions.That means the choices are this deal or a softer Brexit. Or no Brexit at all.And be sure that the Speaker, John Bercow, will bend every possible rule to frustrate Brexit.So, do not expect a long delay to offer a better answer.Anyway, the choice on our future could be made soon.There is no time to lose to save Brexit. Even a snap General Election offers no easy salvation. It would mean Theresa May leading the Tories into another campaign on a manesto of her deal â€” precisely what her critics want to avoid. And of course, the Conservatives could lose any path to power at all, kissing goodbye to any Brexit.Brexit would never have happenedit had not been for Boris Johnson.Now he has a crucial opportunity to save the whole project.He can show how he can be a Â­statesman, by compromising in the national interest.And he can demonstrate the sort of leadership that won him so much praise as Mayor of London.If the Government can persuade the DUP to vote for the deal, backbenchers including Dominic Raab, Iain Duncan Smith, Theresa Villiers and Mark Harper should follow suit.Otherwise, they risk being remembered as the MPs who wrecked Brexit, along with Labour MPs who helped trigger Â­Article  and then opposed both No Deal and the current deal.Theresa May also needs to recognise that backbenchers want someone  to take forward the next stage of the negotiations.If she tries to cling to power, critics on both sides of the Brexit ide may never back her deal.Whereasshe pledges to step down on getting her deal through, she can step down as a hero who delivered Brexit against the odds.MPs should know that politics is about taking the world as you find it, not as you would like it to be.And leadership is about taking decisions, even when all the choices are unpalatable.It is fine to stick to principle, but notthat means emulating King Canuteâ€™s stand against the waves.If Brexit does not happen it will be a Â­national democratic calamity.As the party in power, the Conservatives will be punished.That means risking Â­letting Jeremy Corbyn â€” a leader who can not even deal with anti-Semitism in his own party â€” seize control of the country.The stakes simply could not be higher. If this chance is squandered we will likely never get another moment.Right across Europe, critics of Brussels will think â€œeven Britain couldnâ€™t break freeâ€.Henry Newman is director of the Open Europe think tank.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: take what we can on brexit and scarper
story: This is according to the World Happiness Report.While the rest of the world is sinking into psychological depression, weâ€™re much more upbeat.Some of the British Press reporting this have used those dread words: â€œDespite Brexitâ€‰.â€‰.â€‰.â€‰â€It wouldnâ€™t occur to them that it might be BECAUSE of Brexit.I suspect for  per cent of us thatâ€™s pretty much the case. Maybe to keep up levels of national happiness we should leave horrible, authoritarian bureaucracies every year. Just to put a grin on our faces. I mean, the French donâ€™t seem very happy, do they But hereâ€™s the bad news. Theresa May is still Prime Minister and weâ€™re currently heading for a Brexit which would be a travesty of the one we voted for in . If we get Brexit at all.Some of the Brexiteers in Parliament think we might still be able to escape the EU with a No Deal, on World Trade Organisation terms. I think they are deluding themselves.Parliament, which is two to one in favour of NOT leaving the EU, simply will not let it happen.And the EU, desperate to retain its market for goods in the UK, will make sure it doesnâ€™t happen, too.Our Brexiteers are right that Theresa Mayâ€™s deal is awful. Butthey get a chance to vote on it again, they should hold their noses and vote in favour.Because I reckon itâ€™s that or nothing. We will have a delay, the EU may insist we hold a second referendum as a condition of that delay.And trust me, the second referendum will be rigged in favour of remaining in the EU. It will not be a straightforward in or out option. There will be three options, to split the Leave vote down the middle.In this fight to leave the EU, the British people have had everything against them. The EU, obvs. But also the House of Commons and the puffed-up, ludicrous, pro-Remain speaker John Bercow. And the House of Lords, the civil service and the BBC.The lesson for us low-born, powerless Leavers is to take what we can and scarper before the whole idea is killed stone dead. Which I fear it may be.And now Mrs May is heading back to Brussels to plead for a delay in triggering Article .All along she has been too obsessed with the process of leaving the EU, rather than the clear imperative as demanded by the British people â€” to simply LEAVE the EU, all of it.She has followed Brusselsâ€™ agenda at every twist and turn. And sheâ€™ll be following it now. Sheâ€™ll do what the EU wants.So hereâ€™s the deal, as I see it. Give her hopeless proposal one more chance and this time vote for it.We will have been cheated, but not as badly aswe do not leave at all.Because the longer this goes on, the more likely that outcome will be.THIS country becomes more deranged by the very hour.A Roman Catholic journalist claims she may face JAIL because she referred to a transgendered person by the sex assigned at birth, rather than the one she now identies as.Caroline Farrow has been told she must attend a police station for a taped interview.She said: â€œI have pointed out to police that I am a Catholic journalist commentator and it is my religious belief that a person cannot change sex.â€Quite. Biologists would argue exactly the same.When is this madness going to stop And donâ€™t the Old Bill have better things to do with their time Why should this be  Are they simply delighted theyâ€™re not Swedish Other stats might give us a clue.Finland also has one of the highest rates of alcoholism in the world. And also one of the higher suicide rates.So they rate highly for happiness because a theyâ€™re all perpetually p***ed b the sad ones have all topped themselves.GORGEOUS, pouting Olivia Attwood has been complaining that reality TV stars are prone to mental illness because of the horrible abuse they get online.Perhaps sheâ€™s right. There are some nasty t***ers out there, for sure.But might it not also be the case that reality TV stars are prone to mental illness anyway, without the trolls Being famous just for the sake of being famous appeals to a certain kind of rather fragile, insecure personality, I would reckon.THE Oxford English Dictionary has been updated to include the usual raft of gender words. Such as â€œzirâ€ and â€œhirâ€ and the horrible â€œpeoplekindâ€.I hope they have room next year for these following words Iâ€™ve just made up: Togerov â€“ a Bulgarian man who has transitioned to female.Abbottophobia â€“ the irrational fear that Diane is about to appear on the TV talking complete b******s.Droll â€“ an internet troll who is nonetheless quite funny.WYLFWTSâ€“ someone on a gender studies or media studies course. From the acronym Would You Like Fries With That, Sir IT is time to sort out the gamekeepers â€“ once and for all.A new study has suggested that they are responsible for the illegal killing of one of Britainâ€™s rarest birds, the hen harrier.These scumbags are believed to have killed almost THREE QUARTERS of tagged hen harriers. The killings take place on grouse moors.These moors occupy a vast area of the country.But they are managed for the benefit of a tiny number of iniduals. title: secret civil servant remain bureaucrats undermine brexit
story: Before joining the service I had believed, naively, that these values would be upheld unconditionally. I quickly came to learn that, in relation to Brexit, nothing could be further from the truth.Unfortunately, I must remain anonymous for fear of the backlash I would receive at my place of work.However, I can reveal I am a senior policy professional within the service and work closely with a number of government departments.There are a number of extremely dangerous myths regarding civil servants that I must dispel because of the impact they are having on the Brexit process.MYTH : The civil service is independent. The civil service was founded on the pillars of political neutrality.Civil servants are meant to ensure that their own political persuasions do not affect their work. Crucially, they should accept those from all political leanings and points of view.It has become clear to me that the vast majority of civil servants support Remain.From my observations I would estimate this number to be well over  per cent.This is worrying in itself and far from representative of the  per cent of the people who voted for Brexit.Most horrying, however, is the sheer disdain and utter contempt that my colleagues display towards people who voted to Leave.I have lost count of the number of insulting and derogatory terms that are used in my own department and where to refer to the .million people who voted for Brexit: â€œRacistâ€, â€œstupidâ€, â€œuneducatedâ€.Anti-Brexit jokes and snide remarks are dropped casually into everyday office con-versations. I live in fear that my colleagues will discover through a slip of my tongue that I am a Brexiteer.Were this to happen, I believe that most would refuse to talk to me again and I might even lose my job.This entire culture creates a thickening cloud of negativity towards Brexit that shades all areas of the civil service. I have witnessed first-hand civil servants doing everything within their power, subtly and under the surface, to frustrate Brexit and talk it down at every opportunity.This can only seriously undermine our efforts to be in the strongest position possible on leaving the EU.MYTH : Civil servants are experts in their field.One would like to think the iniduals making decisions that affect our entire nation would have some level of skill or experience.If only that were true.For example, I know of one stand-alone â€œexpertâ€ policy team leading our preparations for Brexit.You can imagine my disbelief when I discovered none of its members had worked on anything remotely related to the EU before. In fact, I have discovered over time that the vast majority of â€œexpertsâ€ within the service have no expertise whatsoever.In many cases the â€œportfolioâ€ you take on when you join the service is dictated by the one held by your predecessor.As a result, you have new civil servants inheriting politically sensitive and highly important work without the faintest clue about what they are dealing with.Civil servants who are seriously underperforming will usually have a new job title and position created for them somewhere  in the organisation instead of being sacked or performance-managed â€” they become someone â€™s problem then.Given the influence that civil servants are exerting over the Brexit process, this is truly concerning.MYTH : The civil service does not engage in scaremongering.I had hoped that civil servants, even in times of crisis, would be able to remain calm and level-headed in pursuit of ensuring the best outcomes for our country.And yet it is not uncommon for me to receive emails from colleagues promoting Brexit scare stories that are nothing more than lies and speculation. Recently, things have become so panicked that ious â€œBrexit contingencyâ€ plans have been set up throughout the organisation. This is to prepare for the â€œnational public transport breakdownâ€, â€œsurge in criminalityâ€ and â€œwidespread public unrestâ€ that is going to follow after we leave.These plans also involve collecting the personal details of certain civil servants to put in place a -hour, on-call rota for the â€œemergencyâ€ that is looming. This scare-mongering, created and whipped up by civil servants, is having a marked impact on the confidence and well-being of ordinary citizens.For example, one acquain-tance of mine is so terried by the speculative threats put out by the service they have started to stockpile large quantities of their medication. This needs to stop.MYTH : Ministers are in charge.When I was outside the civil service looking in, I always believed civil servants were there simply to advise their ministers, who, as elected representatives of the people, would make the ultimate decision. However, I have come to realise that ministers are often mere puppets, with civil servants pulling ferociously at their strings.The level of bureaucracy is unimaginable.In my experience parlia-mentary briefings go through â€” at a minimum â€” five stages of internal clearance, with crucial information being amended or deleted at every stage on the whim of that inidual civil servant.The power and competence of our ministers is, Iâ€™m afraid, a facade.They are nothing more than a megaphone for the views of biased civil servants who lurk behind them in the shadows.I am a supporter of the Leave campaign.To go against the will of the people expressed in the  referendum would be the ultimate act of betrayal.The Government MUST allow us to take back control by leaving the EU on World Trade Organisation terms. If the people are betrayed, I may have no choice but to resign.Honesty, impartiality, integrity and objectivity. title: brexit march london 2019 peoples vote article 50
story: Marchers set off in central London with banners proclaiming the best deal is no Brexit and we demand a Peoples Vote as they marched through the city.The days activities were kicked off by the unfurling of a large banner on Westminster Bridge that read Love socialism, hate Brexit.Demonstrators wore blue and yellow berets and flew large EU flags above the crowd as the march slowly made its way to Parliament Square.Placards bore messages urging the Government to revoke article  and for Brexit to be put to the people.The size of the crowd saw people spill over into the capitals side streets and some underground trains were not stopping at Green Park station.The stunt was organised by a group calling itself the Left Bloc which is supported by Labour MPs, including Clive Lewis and Kate Osamor, Green Party MP Caroline Lucas, trade unions and grassroots campaigners.And organisers today claimed one million people took part, whichcorrect would make it one of the largest protests in British history.In Parliament Square, Labours deputy leader Tom Watson told marchers that the only way to resolve the Brexit impasse is for people themselves to sign it off.Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, former deputy prime minister Lord Heseltine and London mayor Sadiq Khan also took the stage.Other speakers include former Conservative cabinet minister Justine Greening and former attorney general Dominic Grieve, former Tory turned independent MP Anna Soubry, Lib Dem deputy leader Jo Swinson, Green Party MP Caroline Lucas and SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford.Campaigners are arriving to the capital from across the country, with one taking on a -mile journey on ferries, trains and buses from Orkney in Scotland.The London march coincides with pro-Brexit campaigners continuing their long hike from the North East to the capital.Former Ukip leader Nigel Farage re-joined the March to Leave when it set off from Linby, near Nottingham, this morning.Saturdays demonstrations follow EU leaders agreeing to delay Brexit to give Prime Minister Theresa May a final chance to get her deal through Parliament.Leaders agreed to extend Brexit to May Mrs May can get MPs to back her deal in the Commons at the third time of asking.If the vote is not passed, the UK will have to set out an alternative way forward by April , which could mean a much longer delay - with the UK required to hold elections to the European Parliament - or leaving without a deal at all.An online petition demanding the Government stops the Brexit process had topped four million signatures by Saturday morning.

title: nets trees hedges stop birds nesting uk
story: Residents have branded the practice - used in preparation for felling - abhorrent and sickening.In Guildford, netting was seen covering  trees on a derelict site earmarked for  homes.While in Stratford-upon-Avon, whole stretches of hedgerows were covered in green fabric in an area set aside for a -home development.Its an offence to destroy an active nest, but there are no laws to prevent nets being installed to stop birds nesting in the first place.Naturalist and broadcaster Chris Packham has described the practice as ghastly and the antithesis of everything conservation stands for.The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds says the UK has lost more than  million birds in the past  years - has now asked the government to address this issue.In Birmingham, where trees at Solihull retail park were covered, residents were left furious.One wrote on Twitter: Humans pretending they own this planet. Whereas, in fact, they are destroying it for themselves, for their offspring and for all other species. Sickening.Another tweeted: This is a world gone mad.Abhorrent - an appalling image beyond science fiction. The oppression of nature - for what ends  another added.SolihullÂ councillor Tim Hodgson tweeted that it was very worrying to see this all over the country.The nets are to prevent nesting but this is cruel and shouldnt be happening, he said.The retail park said they wanted to chop them down to carry out a refurbishment but are now reviewing things after the backlash from the community.On its website, the RSPB warns against tree felling in the spring summer period.The guidelines read: We recommend not cutting hedges and trees between March and August as this is the main breeding season for nesting birds, although some birds may nest outside this period.It is an offence under Section  of the Wildle and Countryside Act of  to destroy the nest of any wild bird while it is in use or being built.

title: peru woman found dismembered cave satanic ritual boyfriend
story: Sharoom Leon Jara, , was discovered in a cave in the district of El Agustino in the western Peruvian province of Lima after she mysteriously went missing last week.She had reportedly been cut into pieces and burned and her boyfriend has confessed to the crime, according to Peru.Leon Jara went missing on March  when she went to meet her cousin and boyfriend, -year-old Nick Brayan Leon Chumpitaz.The victim, who has a young son from a previous relationship, had not been to collect her child in two days and the father grew concerned.He told the victimâ€™s sister Mayra and she went to confront Leon Chumpitaz.Mayra had Leon Jaraâ€™s phone and knew that her boyfriend was the last person to call her before she went missing.According to local media, she found him with scratches over his face but he claimed that he had not seen the victim since they had a row at around pm on March .The victimâ€™s body has now been found in a cave and grieving family members have accused Leon Chumpitaz of being involved, it is reported.They claim that they found dark and threatening messages on Leon Jaraâ€™s phone that were sent by the suspect.Leon Chumpitaz has since been arrested for the murder and a former girlfriend claimed that he once threatened her near the cave where Leon Jara was found a few years ago.The investigation is ongoing.

title: thailand booze ban red light districts close elections bangkok
story: Thailands red light districts, including the citys gogo bars and clubs, looked like ghost towns as a result of the ban.The country is holding its first elections in almost a decade on Sunday and the military rulers banned all sales of alcohol from pm on March  until pm on March , after polls close.Ladyboy strip clubs and lap dancing bars in the Soi Cowboy strip were deserted on Saturday night while bars in the neighbouring Patpong district also did not open for the evening.In the Soi  Nana area, some bars stayed open with signs outside warning tourists that alcohol was unavailable.Brits said the ban had ruined their weekends, with many spending the night in front of the TV instead of bar-hopping.Police patrolled the streets making sure that no holidaymakers were drinking and that supermarkets had stopped selling booze until the elections conclude tomorrow evening at pm.Anyone caught breaking the law can face up to six months in prison and a fine of up to , baht .David Maguire, , from Nottingham, said: Im on a cruise and were only staying in Bangkok for one night.But now theres nothing to do in the evening. I cant even buy a beer to take back to the hotel.So it looks like well be drinking water and watching the telly.Chris Tenreiro, from Leytonstone, east London, said: I was expecting everything to be buzzing on a Saturday night but its like a ghost town.Hopefully itll get back to normal tomorrow and there wont be any problems.The elections - widely regarded by critics as being rigged by the military - are the first time the country has gone to the polls in since the army seized power in  instilling General Prayut Chan-o-cha as leader.The ban that takes place around election times was introduced in September , revising the previous Election Act.Authorities choose to ban alcohol to prevent voting manipulation and bribery, with canvassers previously throwing parties to attract votes at the last minute.It is the first national election in Thailand since , following the military coup in .Andrew MacGregor Marshal, a lecturer at Edinburgh Napier University and author on Thai politics, said: The election will neither be free nor fair. Thai dictator Prayut Chan-ocha and his junta have shamelessly and systematically cheated throughout the election campaign.The Election Commission, which is entrusted with safeguarding the integrity of the polls and ensuring voting goes smoothly, has shown itself to be biased and incompetent.Pro-democracy parties have faced censure for the smallest alleged infractions, while the most blatant cheating by the junta has gone unpunished.For Thais who want true democracy, the situation seems hopeless. Many are questioning whether it is even worth voting.Phuket Provincial Police Deputy Commander Col Sermpan Sirikong toldÂ The Phuket News: The ban on the sale of alcohol is mandatory by law.Police will enforce it that same as we do for the five Buddhist religious days throughout the year.I believe that foreign tourists will understand that this is law must be followed.

title: disneyland paris france evacuated
story: Visitors to the theme park heard loud noises and then screaming as they were caught up in the drama shortly after pm on Saturday.The panic sparked unfounded rumours of explosions and gunshots as tourists fled in fear and armed police and the army secured the area.However a spokesman for the RER station at Marne la Vallee said: It seems that a maling escalator has caused the problems.It began working erratically, and causing loud noises. It may be that some people have been hurt in this accident.Following the panic, visitors to Disneyland were briefly confined in buildings, including the police station.One visitor said: I was at a coffee terrace when I saw people running and screaming.We all started running in panic and I took refuge at the police station with dozens of other people.A spokesman for Disneyland Paris said: There has been no explosions, no shootings, no injuries. It a  alarm.Please donâ€™t read any rumours or stories that over exaggerate â€“ the lockdown and police attendance were standard procedure following any sort of incident.Disneyland Paris is among Europes most-visited tourist destinations, with up to  million visitors a year.This is not the first time there have been unfounded rumours of gunfire that sparked panic.In November  pop singer Olly Murs was criticised for posting a series of dramatic tweets from inside Selfridges on Oxford Street, claiming hed heard gunshots.The incident saw people fleeing in fear as rumours spread of a terror attack.

title: theresa may gone 10 days brexit cabinet
story: The PM has one last throw of the dice to get her Brexit deal through Parliament this week â€“ but that looks doomed to failure.She looks increasingly isolated as even her most loyal allies concluded she has reached the end of the road.A senior Cabinet source said: â€œDespite all the ideological splits over Brexit, we are now united on one front â€“ we all think Theresa needs to go.â€But Mrs May has a last-gasp plan to rally rebel Tories behind her hated deal and stay at Number .Sources say she will await the outcome of this weekâ€™s â€œpick â€˜nâ€™ mixâ€ vote in which MPs choose a solution to the Brexit deadlock from a menu of seven.They are certain to choose a â€œsofterâ€ Brexit, probably staying in the customs union and requiring a two-year extension of Article .Mr May would then spring a snap Commons vote, forcing MPs to decide between that and her deal.She hopes it will force hardline Brexiteers back in line â€“ making her the hero of the hour.But she is pinning her hopes on Speaker John Bercow â€“ a self-confessed Remainer â€“ allowing her one last vote.Last night a senior Cabinet minister told The Sun on Sunday: â€œYou have to admire her resilience.â€œTheresa has surprised everyone with her tenacity but now itâ€™s Brexit or bust. I can sense weâ€™re in the end game. I think sheâ€™s got  days left.â€Yesterday senior Tory MPs openly texted each other saying Mrs May should go this week.Some want Deputy PM David Lidington to act as a caretaker to sort out the mess while a new leader is elected.Others favour a â€œtriumvirateâ€ run by Mr Lidington, Environment Secretary Michael Gove and Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt.Government chief whip Julian Smith and his team are also on the brink of resigning over the PMâ€™s refusal to listen.MPs tempers are fraying after she blamed THEM for the chaos in a TV outburst from Number  last Wednesday.In a meeting soon afterwards, her whips warned she now risks destroying not only Brexit but the Tory party, too.One member, Paul Maynard, was close to tears as he told her: â€œI think things are slipping away from us.â€An insider revealed: â€œIt was like murder on the Orient Express.â€Each whip told her that they would not be able to find the numbers to get her deal through Parliament unless she made a public promise to stand down.But Mrs Mayâ€™s response was to sit motionless for a few seconds then reply: â€œThank you for your honesty.â€ She then quickly changed the subject.Mrs May has been left hopelessly cornered after her stubborn-ness and stalling tactics ran out of time and space.If she went for a â€œno dealâ€ Brexit, half her Cabinet would resign. If she backed a two-year delay, the other half would walk out.The multi-choice vote on the best way forward is expected on Wednesday will almost certainly demand an extension beyond June  â€“ which the PM has already insisted was unacceptable.A senior MP said: â€œShe has less than three weeks to tell the EU what her next step is. If itâ€™s an extension she is finished. Nobody is going to let her stay on the get us out of this mess.â€The only formal process to remove her is a no-confidence vote of the  committee of MPs. But their failed bid to topple her in December means they cannot try again for a year.That means she has to be persuaded to resign â€“ or brought down by a general election.Some angry MPs are suggesting the â€œnuclear optionâ€ a â€œVote strikeâ€ until she gets the message.Mrs Mayâ€™s allies yesterday warned that politics will be in meltdown unless they come to their senses and back the deal.THERESA May has been accused of being the Sven-Goran Eriksson of politics - having no Plan B.The PM has failed to set out another route out of the Brexit chaos remaining tight-lipped when quizzed this week by EU leaders.The Swede, who managed England between  and , was accused for not having a rescue strategy by pundits.Mrs May has written to all MPs to indicate she may not bring back her dealit canâ€™t command enough support to secure victory.One Minister said: â€œLike Sven, she has no plan B when things go wrong. She just keeps moving the goal posts. She has now lost control of her dressing room.â€œShe has been running down the clock but now the EU have blown the whistle.â€Mrs May refused to sack Remain-backing Cabinet Ministers including Amber Rudd when she defied the party to keep no deal off the table infuriating colleagues.Another Minister added: â€œEveryday you hope the PM and Number  canâ€™t make it any worse and then they do.â€Hardline Brexiteers insist the PM should enact the law as it stands and leave without a deal when the deadline is reached at pm on Friday.But by agreeing to extend Article  last week EU chiefs have trumped UK law so it is now impossible to crash out.A Brexit-backing minister said: â€œLots of Eurosceptics are thinking â€˜one more push and weâ€™ll get it over the line by Fridayâ€™ but the truth is they wonâ€™t.â€œA communique released by the European Commission last week has changed the rules.â€œSo evenwe have carried out all the legislation required to leave the EU, that will be trumped by international law which dictates that the extension to Article  takes precedence.â€Another pro-Brexit minister added: â€œCanâ€™t they see that their Brexit dream is sinking before their eyes â€œThey are behaving like passengers on the Titanic, who can see the ship going down but refuse to join a leboat and stand there pointing at the guarantee on the main deck.â€Cabinet discipline has broken down with Business Secretary Greg Clark being accused â€œfreelancingâ€ when he announced the PM would back a series of indicative votes.One minister said: â€œNumber  are furious as his attempt to bounce her into it. If she ends up having to go through with it, there will be some pretty angry people on the back benches, too.â€If MPs seize control of the process this week, Mrs May could give Tories a free vote.Former minister Mark Francois, vice chairman of the European Research Group, said is proved she had given up the ghost on leading the country.He declared: â€œIf the government of this country does not have a view on how to proceed and the most important question facing Britain since the end of the second world war then, in effect, we no longer have a government, just a collection of iniduals who call themselves ministers of the crown.Despite her best intentions and a dogged determination to see Brexit through, the chances of her deal ever getting Commons support are pitiably low.Some senior ministers put the likelihood of it passing next week at  per cent.The PM has seen her own authority seep away and is now unable to uny her own Cabinet, let alone the party in general.That means she is powerless even to call an election.As the  Committee chairman Sir Graham Brady points out here, her deal may be threadbare but it still offers the only realistic chance of Brexit actually taking place.Backing it would give Britain a chance of a new start. If the deal fails again it seems Philip Hammond and David Lidington will be knocking on the PMâ€™s door to tell her the time has come to make an exit.But in the midst of this paralysing crisis even that is not an easy option.There is no clear route to appointing a successor in the short term. And with the party at loggerheads even a swt transition to a caretaker PM is perilous.After this weekâ€™s turmoil we face being stuck for some time with a lame-duck Prime Minister, whoever it may be.Britain needs a miracle to avoid it.â€œItâ€™s a total and utter shambles and itâ€™s all the Prime Ministerâ€™s fault.â€A Number  insider said: â€œEveryone at Number  is losing their rag at the slightest issue. It really does feel like the last days of Rome. Bunker mentality has set in.â€â€œEven in the early part of this week, the PM felt she could deliver her domestic agenda after getting Brexit through.â€Â Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chloe ayling testify kidnap trial
story: Mum-of-one Chloe, , says she was snatched and bundled into the boot of a car by two brothers when she turned up for a bogus photoshoot.Last year Lukasz Herba was given  years for his part in the kidnap and his brother Michal is now on trial after being extradited from Britain where they both lived.At the first trial in Milan the court relied on a police statement and Chloe was not cross examined but lawyers for Michal have successfully argued she should be cross examined.They claim there are anomalies in her story and want to question her as to why she â€œwent shopping with Lukasz, held hands with him and slept in the same bed as himâ€ while being held hostage in an isolated farmhouse near Turin.Eyebrows have been raised ever since Chloe claimed to have been kidnapped in Milan two years ago before being released five days later.Some sceptics have claimed it was a publicity stunt and at Lukasz trial it emerged a Hollywood director had contacted his lawyer pointing out similarities in Chloeâ€™s case and a film he had made.Last night Michalâ€™s lawyer Simone Zancani said:â€I can confirm Chloe will testy via video link from London in May.â€œThis is a signicant step forward in our defence and we are delighted. It gives us the opportunity for the first time to cross examine Chloe about her story.â€She had argued that she felt â€œvulnerableâ€ going to Milan but Mr Zancani pointed out she regularly posted pictures of herself on Instagram at locations across the world and earlier this year uploaded a picture of herself in Milan saying it was â€œone of her favourite citiesâ€.Chloe, from Coulsdon, south London was not available for comment.Since the kidnap she has appeared on Celebrity Big Brother, published a book and had a fling with Ceglie CBB star and footballer Jermaine Pennant.Â Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: settle brexit mess leave eu with deal
story: Something as simple as taking back control of our own country has been made to look impossibly complicated.Nation states around the globe make their own laws and trade successfully with or without free trade agreements. The UK itself has been more successful in recent years in growing its trade with markets outside the EU than with those that are inside the single market and customs union.It baffles me that so many British politicians have so little faith in Britain that they think we would be sunkwe had to stand on our own two feet.The mistakes that have brought us to this point are well known: agreeing to decide the terms of the Withdrawal Agreement before settling the future trading relationship with the EU agreeing to a â€œbackstopâ€ to prevent a â€œhard borderâ€ in Ireland allowing the militant Remainers in Parliament to damage Britainâ€™s negotiating position by taking â€œNo Dealâ€ off the table and allowing our exit date to be deferred.If only we had accepted the EUâ€™s offer two years ago to have a big Canada-Plus free trade agreement, we could have locked in certainty for business and spent the last two years trying to improve upon it!The question now is whatâ€™s the best way to achieve the proper Brexit that the British people voted for nearly three years ago I understand why so many of my Tory and DUP friends have voted against the PMâ€™s deal. I told her in November the â€œbackstopâ€ made it impossible for anyone who wanted to leave the EU to vote for it: it could lock the UK into the EU customs union for ever.That is why I voted against it the first time. Itâ€™s also why I tabled the â€œBrady amendmentâ€ â€” which was voted through at the end of January, telling the PM to go back and ensure the â€œbackstopâ€ couldnâ€™t become a permanent trap.When the Governmentâ€™s lawyer Geoffrey Cox said the changes agreed would allow a way out in most circumstanceswe were faced with a tough choice.To take a risk and support the deal or keep voting against, hoping something better would emerge. It was defeated a second time, with a big majority against.Those of us who really want Brexit to happen and British politics to be able to get on with other things are now faced with taking a massive political judgment.By voting for the pretty threadbare deal Theresa May brought back from Brussels, we can ensure some sort of Brexit and then a new negotiating team that believes in what itâ€™s doing can work to get something worthwhile out of the future relationship after we have left.If we donâ€™t vote the deal through this week, it no longer looks like Theresaâ€™s promise that â€œno deal is better than a bad dealâ€ will be honoured. Two years ago,  per cent of you voted for a political party â€” whether Tory or Labour â€” that promised to implement the referendum decision.Two years on Labour is angling for a second referendumand lots of other MPs are pushing for a Brexit that amounts to staying in. Some want endless delay, a few are at least honest enough to admit they really want to ignore the decision of . million voters altogether.Meanwhile, the EU is creaking. Just as the EU is set for crisis, this country is poised for success.British businesses are sitting on big cash balances but are crying out for the certainty that will allow them to invest.If we deliver on our promise to leave in the coming weeks, Britain will prosper. If we get stuck in the departure lounge, our country will suffer.For heavenâ€™s sake, letâ€™s settle this now.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit london march hundreds thousands
story: NewsBrexit London march: One MILLION people join Peoples Vote protestThe Put It To The People march took place in central London with speeches from politicians across the political spectrumShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews ReporterDave Burke:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video politicians-famous-faces-address-crowd-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAround a million people marched on Westminster today demanding a Peopleâ€™s Vote on Brexit. Marching bands, music, whistles, chants and cheers provided a noisy backdrop to the aposput it to the peopleapos march. James McGrory, the director of the Peopleâ€™s Vote campaign and one of the organisers of the march, said the campaign for a second Brexit referendum is now the biggest mass movement in Britain, dwarfing the membership of the main political parties. â€œPeople from all walks of le see can what they were once offered bears no relation to what is being delivered and they are angry about it because it feels like a bad deal is being rammed down their throats,â€ he told Reuters.  Â  The Mayor of London kicked off the speeches criticising â€˜party politicsâ€™ as delaying a Brexit deal. He said: â€œI have lived in London all my le. I have never seen London look so magnicent as you do today. â€œJust days ago we were in danger of falling off the clf which would have catastrophic consequences. â€œWe have seen party politics repeatedly put ahead of national interest. â€œWe have seen the government ignore our warnings time and time again. â€œItâ€™s time to say loud and clear enough is enough.â€  Addressing the crowd in Parliament Square, Labourâ€™s deputy leader Tom Watson said: â€œWe are one million strong.â€ He said he was there on behalf of his -year-old daughter. â€œShe has told me to thank you for campaigning for her future,â€ he said. Mr Watson said the Prime Ministerâ€™s deal â€œpleases no-oneâ€. â€œIf you voted remain itâ€™s a rubbish deal,you voted leave itâ€™s a lousy deal. There are no winners, only losers,â€ he said. He added: â€œBrexit is stuck in the parliamentary pipeworks and itâ€™s not going to find a way out.â€ Addressing his comments to Theresa May, he said: â€œI can only vote for a dealyou let the people vote on it too. â€œPrime Minister, youâ€™ve lost control of this process, youâ€™re plunging the country into chaos, let the people take control.â€Â   First Minister Nicola Sturgeon also took to the stage. She said: â€œI bring with me today solidarity from Scotland. â€œA land where  per cent voted to remain in the European Union. â€œOur voice has been ignored. â€œBut it is not merely our voice that has been ignored - but the voice of the  percent who voted remain across the UK has been ignored. â€œAnd the voice of those wanting to leave but who could never have contemplated the maze that Brexit has become. Their voice is being ignored as well. â€œMy message is for every European national living in the UK, in Scotland and Wales and Northern Ireland. â€œWe think you are welcome here and we want you to stay. â€œWhat has been done to you by these Brexiteers politicians has been nothing short of desperation.â€ Concluding her speech to raucous applause and cheering she said: â€œPut this back to the people and let us sort Brexit.â€  David Lammy MP for Tottenham also spoke to the protesters. story: NewsMum who became incontinent after childbirth hid it from husband for YEARSEXCLUSIVE: Kelly-Anne Combes, from Norfolk, became completely incontinent following the birth of her daughterShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsKelly-Anne Combes suffered incontinence after Amelia was born "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who became incontinent after giving birth to her daughter lived in a constant state of embarrassment and even hid her condition from her husband. She took spare clothes out with her and frequently had to change into them. Yet she suffered in silence. Speaking exclusively to , Kelly-Anne said: I didnapost tell my husband. I didnapost feel I needed to. I couldnapost face telling my friends either. I just made constant excuses as to why I couldnapost go out or see them. I was just so mortied.  Â  Initially, I only confided in my mum, she was the one person that I felt comfortable with telling as I knew she wouldnapost judge me.Â  But to begin with, it happened a lot but I thought this was just a normal experience after childbirth. The muscles around the mumaposs bladder had become weakened during pregnancy and after childbirth, which led to the urinary incontience. It was suggested Kelly-Anne used a pair of shorts with electro muscle stimulation technology to help her recovery. The blogger continued: I am doing all those things that bladder weakness stopped me from doing for so long. I am out and about, mingling with other mums and feel like me again. The shorts have strengthen Kelly-Anneaposs pelvic floor. These muscles, which keep the bladder shut, come under great strain in pregnancy and childbirth. Professionals suggest mums and expectant mums do simple exercises to strengthen thew muscles. But Kelly-Anne stressed it is also important not to feel alone. My advice to others would be to not feel alone because there are so many women out there who have been through the same thing. Nobody should feel that they need to suffer in silence and be too embarrassed to seek help like I was. Everybody should value their quality of le and not give up years of their le, like I did.

Â  One person wrote: â€œDeepest sympathy for all Melaposs family and friends at this sad time. â€œA lovely lady who will be missed.â€ Another said: â€œAmazing lady. A lovely friend and colleague. Thinking of all the family.â€ Even in death, the Humberstone gran has still helped people in need. Her family have revealed that her heart, lungs, liver and kidneys were given to people desperate for organ transplants, Â â€œWe never really talked about it before but we thought she would want to donate her organs.. we think she saved lives, Sarah said. Melanie leaves her children Sarah, Rachel and Carl â€“ who all went to Humberstone Junior School â€“ and four grandchildren. title: woman ended up marrying convicted
story: NewsWoman ended up marrying convicted killer after answering a newspaper advertEXCLUSIVE: Val Thatcher was  when she first started writing to George, a convicted killer. And now she wants to prove his innocenceShareCommentsByOlivia Buxton:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsVal with a painting of George he had painted "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who answered an ad from a convicted murderer ended up marrying him â€“ and spent years trying to clear his name. Val Thatcher was a -year-old orced teacher way back in  when she first started writing to the man who would become her second husband. George Thatcher was serving le for shooting a worker dead in an armed robbery on a Co-op dairy, a crime for which he was originally condemned to be hanged. And as the unlikely pair corresponded, and then met over the next six years in jails around the country, their relationship gradually blossomed into romance. Astonishingly, it eventually led to a -year marriage that lasted until George died from a stroke in .  Â  Today retired Val tells how she always believed George, a petty thief and safeblower, was framed for the killing for which he served  years. And a TV show re-examining the case could shed new light on it as modern-day legal experts give it their consideration. A team of barristers will st through evidence from the time and look at question marks over a verbal confession â€“ potentially flagging up a miscarriage of justice. Val, now , said: â€œI have read George was a man addicted to unreasonable violence, which is so untrue. He was such a gentle person. He wouldnâ€™t have hurt a fly. â€œIt was all an image that was painted of him that just wasnâ€™t true. â€œEven now, I still canâ€™t help but be upset because of the injustice of what happened to him and the years wasted because of it.â€  Â  Val first made contact with George when he was doing time in HMP Albany on the Isle of Wight. Frustrated by what he claimed was his wrongful imprisonment, he had placed an advert in the upmarket magazine New Statesman and it caught Valâ€™s eye. She recalled: â€œThe best thing I ever did was to reply to his advert, which read. â€˜Ler, aspiring dramatist and painter seeks new outlets through communication and visitsâ€™. â€œMy reaction was â€˜Gosh, there is somebody worse off than meâ€™. I felt sorry for him so I wrote him a letter. â€œWomen might write to prisoners to get a kick, but there was none of that prurient fascination â€“ because I had no idea when I replied to the ad what George was supposed to have done. â€œWe exchanged a few letters before I went to visit him a couple of months later. I was very nervous because I had never been inside a prison before but George was so kind and gentle, very dferent from what I was expecting. â€œHe was a wonderful artist and I sent him photos of London because he loved to paint street scenes. He loved creative writing too and had written a play The Only Way Out.  Â  â€œThe manuscript was smuggled out of prison in a painting and was performed at the Royal Court Theatre in London in , which I encouraged people to watch. â€œIt was only when I began toabout the case that I understood it. He always protested his innocence in prison and when I really got to know him, I started to believe him. â€œHe really didnâ€™t seem like an armed robber or a killer.â€ George was born in  into a childhood of abject poverty and by his s was a career criminal with a string of convictions. On November , , a gang of robbers struck at the Royal Arsenal Co-op in Mitcham, Surrey, and stole Â£. Detectives called to the scene found the managerâ€™s office ransacked and the safe plundered. Outside, a depot vehicle sat abandoned with its window shot out. And a Co-op employee, father-of-two Dennis Hurden, lay leless at the entrance.  Within hours a getaway car had been found and soon three men, Philip Kelly, John Hilton and Charles Connelly, had been arrested. Kelly gave cops the name of George Thatcher, who denied not only that he shot Mr Hurden but that he had even been on the raid. There was no scientic evidence linking him with the crime and no ID parade was held. The key evidence used against George were statements from police, who testied that he had implicated himself.George was found guilty at the Old Bailey on March ,  of an offence known at the time as capital murder, which carried a mandatory death penalty. His co-accused Kelly, Hilton and Connelly were all convicted of murder and jailedfor le.Less than a month after the trial Georgeâ€™s sentence of execution was commuted to le imprisonment. And though he avoided the hangmanâ€™s rope he still spent nearly two decades locked up for a crime Val is still convinced he did not commit.  Â  Val, who was living near Bristol at the time, said: â€œI never believed that writing to George would end up in us getting married but I wanted to offer him my support. â€œWhen we first met he was in Albany and then Parkhurst, where Ronnie Biggs and Mad Frankie Fraser were. Then he was transferred to Coldingley in Surrey, Gartree near Northampton and finally to Leyhill in Gloucestershire. â€œAfter a couple of years I realised I was falling in love and George told me he felt the same. â€œWhen he got to Leyhill he was allowed occasional phone calls and it was quite easy for him to sneak out. We could meet at night and be romantic.â€Val even took her daughter Marion along on visits and George would give her bars of chocolate and toys he had made himself. She added: â€œBy then I couldnâ€™t reallyÂ  imagine my le without George.â€œHe was recommended twice for parole and turned down by the Home Office but I grew determined to win his release and I wrote to more and more people. â€œI became Georgeâ€™s leline and his window to the outside world.â€œFast-forward to  and his release from prison and our wedding were the two happiest days of my le.â€œWe got married at Bath register office and everyone I taught with at the school turned up.â€ To start a new le, the couple bought a derelict house in Co Kerry in Ireland, spent years renovating it and eventually moved out there full-time. Val added: â€œWe rarely spoke about what happened and we burned all of our letters along with the manuscript from the trial. It felt cathartic.â€  Sadly when George was  he was diagnosed with pulmonary fibrosis. Val left their home because it held too many memories but went back to scatter Georgeâ€™s ashes and film for the BBCâ€™s Murder, Mystery and My Family.The show tells Georgeâ€™s story, with QCs Sasha Wass and Jeremy Dein examining all the facts relating to the case. Val added: â€œLosing George left a big hole in my le. I spent  years fightinghis corner and it has been very, very hard to readjust.â€ Murder, Mystery and My Family is on BBC One, weekdays at .am.

story: Artwork created by children could raise thousands of pounds for a charity.Aberdeen wealth management firm Mattioli Woods is taking part in Venture , which challenges teams to raise as much money as possible from a starting sum of Â£.All the cash from Venture will go towards supporting Charlie Houseâ€™s plans to build a state-of-the-art specialist support centre in Aberdeen.The team from Mattioli Woods came up with the idea of a canvas they could auction off and turned to children, siblings and parents who are supported by Charlie House to help create the artwork.They were asked to draw something inspired by the theme â€˜homeâ€™, then all the artworks were combined to make a landscape design of the Granite City.Mattioli Woods worked with FortyTwo Studio to produced the final image, which is now being auctioned.The Evening Express currently has the leading bid of Â£, on the online auction.George Gray is leading a team of six at Mattioli Woods.He said they were delighted with the response since opening the bids for the canvas on Tuesday.George said: â€œOur plan is to get the canvas displayed at ious locations throughout the city in the coming weeks before the end of the auction.â€œWe thought it would be a great idea to get the children of Charlie House involved, and the idea just snowballed.â€œWe came up with the children doing a picture with the theme of home and what is special to them about Charlie House.â€œWeâ€™ve pulled all those images into one giant image for the north-east.â€George added: â€œThe canvas is .m long and is a metre tall. title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site isÂ  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of Â£m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at Â£.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of Â£m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and Â£m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK governmentâ€™s proposed use of the armyâ€™s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea itâ€™s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site isÂ  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs a very enthusiastic, though amateur, photographer, I had treated myself to a new and rather expensive camera lens.Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this â€“ why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: people say future high rise
story: NewsPeople to have their say on the future of high-rise flats in AyrTenants asked for their preferred optionShareByGary Fanning:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTenants in the Riverside Place multi-storey flats in Ayr are getting the chance to have their say on the future of the high-rise properties as South Ayrshire Councilâ€™s consultation on â€˜Your place, your futureâ€™ gets underway. The consultation and engagement exercise â€“ approved by Councillors last year â€“ gives tenants the chance to choose their preferred option for the long-term future of the flats: Refurbish Â â€“ this means the Council would keep the flats, decant tenants, carry out identied refurbishment works, and thentenants to their refurbished flats. Rehouse Â â€“ this means tenants would be rehoused permanently in suitable alternative accommodation and the flats would be demolished. Rebuild Â â€“ this means tenants would be decanted to temporary accommodation and the flats would be demolished before some tenantsto a new-build housing development on the Riverside Place site. The detailed consultation, which is based around inidual one-to-one meetings with more than  tenants, has been planned in conjunction with the River Ayr Tenants Association, which represents tenants in the three blocks. The Council has communicated regularly with tenants in the lead-up to the consultation to ensure they have all the information they need to take part. A further letter has now been distributed to homes in Riverside Place following queries and concerns raised by tenants regarding a letter sent to them byÂ Fort, Seafield  Wallacetown Community Council. The community councilâ€™s letter appears to query the three consultation options being discussed with tenants and questions South Ayrshire Councilâ€™s interpretation of the expert report approved last year regarding the â€œessential and advisableâ€ works required to the flats. Councillor Philip Saxton, South Ayrshire Councilâ€™s Portfolio Holder for Housing and Community Wellbeing, said: â€œWe are committed to ensuring that our tenants are fully involved in the discussions about the future of their flats, which is why weâ€™re taking such a detailed approach to this consultation. â€œItâ€™s vital that tenants understand all the facts so they can form their own views about the option that is best for them. That is why we have gone back out to them to respond to the queries and confusion that have been generated by the community councilâ€™s letter. â€œWe fully appreciate that the community council may have a view on the consultation, which is why colleagues are meeting with them next week and weâ€™re happy to keep them informed about the consultation and engagement process. â€œHowever, our focus â€“ which was clearly expressed by tenants at the recent River Ayr Tenants Association meeting â€“ has to be on hearing the views of those who will be directly affected by Councillorsâ€™ decisions later this year: the tenants of Riverside Place. â€œWe thank them for their participation in the consultation and I can reassure them that their views will be taken into account before any decisions are taken about the future of Riverside Place.â€ Joe Lafferty, Chair of the River Ayr Tenants Association, said: â€œWe have worked closely with the Council over the last couple of years as discussions around the future of the flats have moved forward â€“ and we very much appreciate the approach the Council has taken. â€œIt is for every tenant to consider what is the best option for them and to ensure their voice is heard by those who will be making the decisions about what happens next. Clear facts, easy to understand information and answers to the questions tenants have is whatâ€™s needed and thatâ€™s exactly what we have got from the Council.â€Â Â  Feedback from the consultation will be considered by Councillors in June this year.Full details of the Riverside Place consultation are available atÂ  www.south-ayrshire.gov.uk riverside-place . story: NewsPlans for luxury flats at Prestwicks Malcolm Sargent House are scrappedDevelopers have dropped their proposal to build on the famous site at the seafront.ShareByPaul Behan:,  MAR NewsArchitects plans for the retirement flats "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPlans to build luxury flats at the former Malcolm Sargent holiday retreat for sick kids in Prestwick have been binned. Major question marks hang over the buildingâ€™s future following the bombshell announcement. The news prompted an angry backlash from Derek Hart, chair of Prestwick North Community Council. In an extraordinary outburst he claimed the building has been â€œplundered and left to rot.â€ The building provided a retreat for children battling cancer for more than  years. It was opened by Princess Diana in . In  it was sold by owners Clic Sargent after claims of a â€œchallenging fundraising environmentâ€. They sold it to McCarthy  Stone and trousered Â£.m from the deal. However, since McCarthy  Stone took ownership and unveiled their luxury flat plans they have been embroiled in a bitter fight with neighbours Prestwick Golf Club. A spokesperson said: â€œFollowing a strategic review last year we are no longer pursuing any new developments within Scotland and have withdrawn our plans for Prestwick.â€ Derek Hart reckons the decision is a kick in the teeth for all the campaigners who fought to retain the presence of a sick childrenâ€™s home in Prestwick. He told the Post: â€œI find this action taken by McCarthy  Stone not only deplorable but a slap in the face to the Save Malcolm Sargent House team who fought bravely to try to purchase it. â€œIs it not time for South Ayrshire Council to stop and listen to the community  â€œThe community stated that the development would only feather the nests of McCarthy  Stone â€“ and perhaps chemists â€“as the age group targeted by them were over  years. â€œThereâ€™s been very little input to Prestwick and we are now left with a building that has been plundered and left to rot. â€œWill we find the same response to the other end of the beach, at the old Gym, I wonder â€He added: â€œTime after time SAC have allowed developers to build as they wish with barely a challenge to the character ofthe town and how it should look.â€The news will be viewed as a major victory for Prestwick Golf Club, who fought long and hard against the development. A statement by the club said: â€œWhile we welcome this news we hope that, should a new development proposal for the site be put forward in the future, the design and scale will be more sympathetic to the surrounding area.â€ The statement said the club was not against the principle of redeveloping the site but was â€œdisappointedâ€ at the scale and design of the proposed development.
