title: astonishing-level-of-dog-dirt-on-sports-pitches-in-tranent
story: Sports clubs are working alongside East Lothian Council in a bid to reduce the number of people failing to clear up after their pets.Three blackspots in the area have been identied ndash Polson Park, Meadowmill and Ross High playing fields ndash and Councillor Colin McGinn described the amount of dog fouling as ldquoastonishing.He said: ldquoWhat is currently happening is the rugby club and Tranent Colts, who use Ross High playing fields, they have to send out a group of coaches or officials to walk the pitches and clear up the mess before they start playing. Runners at Meadowmill, or even the cricket club, are having to go out and make sure the training areas are clean before they start.ldquoFolk want to just turn up and get fit or improve their wellbeing without having to resort to clearing up dog mess before any activity.ldquoIt is irresponsible and pretty uncaring from people.Mr McGinn, who lives in Tranent, visited Meadowmill alongside representatives from ious East Lothian Council departments, including environmental health.The councillor described the situation as ldquoa disgrace, with a campaign to be launched in the coming weeks.Adam Hook, head coach at Ross High RFC, agreed it was a major problem.He said: ldquoIt is really frustrating. You can imagine we are trying to get warmed up and someone stops playing after spotting dog mess on the pitch. Someone then has got to take time out to clear it up and it impacts the warm up or during the game.Mr Hook was keen to see more regular patrols carried out by dog wardens in an attempt to catch irresponsible pet owners.He added: ldquoThey should hit them in the pocket and seethey do it again.ldquoIt is just total laziness. I know lots of people with dogs that would never dream of doing it.Phil Purves, chairman of Tranent Colts, agreed that it was a problem which was getting worse.He told the Courier: ldquoIt is very frustrating.ldquo[Clearing dog fouling] is something we have done pretty much all the time we have coached but it is out of control now.ldquoWe had a game two weeks ago and had to clean up  piles off one pitch.The club has recently bought a dog fouling bin to be put near the playing fields in a bid to encourage owners to clean up after their pets.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe council has noted an increase in complaints about dog fouling in recent weeks, particularly within grass sports areas and school grounds.ldquoOptions are currently being considered as to how best to tackle this situation and will be communicated in due course. In the meantime, all dog owners are reminded of their legal and moral responsibility to clean up after their dog and dispose of the waste properly.

title: new-affordable-homes-in-ormiston-approved
story: The  new homes off the villagersquos Tynemount Road will be part of a larger development by Walker Homes. In total,  properties are being built at the site.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department gave the scheme the go-ahead last week, with  affordable houses and  flats to be built on the site.The housing will be a mix of council homes and mid-market rentals.Each of the new homes will be classed as affordable housing, with the  flats comprising of six semi-detached two-storey flatted buildings with two bedrooms, and four semi-detached two-storey flats with one bedroom in each.Ten of the houses will be semi-detached, with three terraced properties and two detached homes.Sixteen of the properties will have three bedrooms, with the remaining house containing two bedrooms.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe are delighted to be creating more affordable housing units in Ormiston.ldquoAt least  of these will be new council houses.ldquoWe are currently in discussion with another affordable housing provider to potentially deliver  of the units for mid-market rent, creating a mixed tenure development to meet the ied needs of our communities.Meanwhile, more than pound, will be split between the villagersquos primary school and Ross High School in Tranent to ensure that there is sufficient educational capacity to serve the housing.A sum of pound, will go towards Ormiston Primary School, with a further pound, going to the secondary school.Haddington and Lammermuir ward member Councillor Shamin Akhtar was delighted with the additional housing. She said: ldquoIt is good news that permission has been granted for  council houses and  affordable homes for rent in Ormiston.ldquoThese are much-needed homes and will be welcomed by the local community.

title: longniddry-schoolgirl-meets-nicola-sturgeon-over-bubbles-campaign
story: Ellie McIntyre champions Longniddry Primary Schoolrsquos Bubbles Beat Balloons campaign, which encourages people to blow eco-friendly bubbles as an alternative to releasing balloons at public celebrations or tribute events.The youngster wrote to First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, who invited the eight-year-old to the Scottish Parliament to discuss the scheme further.The P pupil received a letter from Ms Sturgeonrsquos office highlighting the importance of young people being involved in developing initiatives and taking them forward.Ellie, who lives in Tranent, said: ldquoIt was exciting to meet Nicola Sturgeon and she let me have a selfie with her.ldquoI was happy she was able to sign our pledge.The youngster was joined at Holyrood by her mum Pauline, as well as her class teacher Yvonne Hart.The group were given a tour of the building, before meeting Ms Sturgeon and sitting in at First Ministerrsquos Questions. Ellie took a framed campaign certicate and Ms Sturgeon signed the lsquoBubbles Beat Balloonsrsquo pledge.Miss Hart added: ldquoThe First Minister was clearly impressed by Ellie and was keen to sign our campaign.ldquoFor her to make time in her busy schedule like this was amazing!The environmental campaign was launched by the school, which is home to  pupils, last summer.After participating in a One Planet One Future project and watching the BBCrsquos Blue Planet  programme ndash which highlighted the devastating impact of plastic on wildle and nature ndash the pupils decided to take action.The children learnt that mass balloon releases were often used when celebrating events or for remembering loved ones. So they decided the much-loved childrenrsquos pastime of blowing bubbles was a much more environmentally friendly way of marking special events instead of polluting the planet with latex balloons.The initiative has already been backed by the Marine Conservation Society, as well as East Lothian Councilrsquos Countryside Ranger Service.Pupils at the school have delivered presentations to local community councillors while a number of local businesses and organisations have signed up to the Bubbles Beat Balloons pledge.The campaign was part of the schoolrsquos work towards achieving gold status as a Rights Respecting School. Longniddry is the only primary school in East Lothian to hold Gold Right Respecting Schools status.The UNICEF UK award recognises the schoolrsquos work embedding childrenrsquos rights in its policy, practices and culture.Sheona Skinner, headteacher, said: ldquoIrsquom incredibly proud of Ellie using her pupil voice to continue our schoolrsquos campaign. Having the First Ministerrsquos support has widened awareness of the initiative and will hopefully encourage more people to become involved. It was a special occasion for Ellie and for everyone involved in Longniddry Primary School.

title: services-to-be-held-in-musselburgh-to-remember-well-known-nun
story: Sister Bernadette died peacefully in her nineties on March  at the Sisters of St Paulrsquos Convent and Care Home in Birmingham.She served St Annersquos Convent and Care Home in Windsor Gardens, Musselburgh, for  years, during which time she endeared herself to residents, relatives and staff.She was a familiar sight walking along the streets of Musselburgh and Portobello, as many of the nuns have done over the last  years since they arrived at St Annersquos to establish a rest home.Born in Burton-on-Trent, she joined the Sisters of Charity of St Paul the Apostle and taught in its schools in South Africa for more than  years.On herto England, she worked in parishes in Shropshire, Lancashire and London before moving to St Annersquos.She spent every spare minute knitting teddy bears, hats, scarves and gloves for children in Romanian schools and for St Annersquos summer fayre to raise funds for the residentsrsquo outings.Two years ago, due to failing health, Sister Bernadette retired to the convent and care home in Birmingham.A spokesperson for St Annersquos said: ldquoThe sisters wish to thank all the wonderful people in Musselburgh and Portobello who helped Sister Bernadette in her works of charity. She endeared herself to all she met by her gentle smile and kind greetings.ldquoAlso a huge thanks to all the bus drivers who made sure she ed home safely, especially in the wet and windy weather, and for whom she had a great respect and appreciation.The first Mass of Remembrance will be held at the chapel at St Annersquos this Sunday at .am. Entrance by Ashgrove. The second takes place at Our Lady of Loretto Church on Newbigging, Musselburgh, at .am on Wednesday. Everyone is invited to attend.

title: pavements-to-be-dug-up-over-next-nine-months-as-ultrafast-broadband-comes-to-musselburgh
story: The company says that this will help bring ldquoultrafast broadband speeds of up to Mbps ndash the fastest widely available speeds in the UK ndash to the area.Speaking at a meeting of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council last week, Eddie McGuigan, the companyrsquos community liaison officer, said that the project to lay fibre cable underground would get under way in mid-April.He said: ldquoWe will be in Musselburgh itself for the next eight or nine months, certainly until Christmas time.He added: ldquoThe idea is to give everyone the opportunity to get the cable.ldquoItrsquos a great thing for businesses and homes that use a lot of internet and wi-fi.ldquoThe downside to that is we are going to have to do some work on your pavements. We do about  metres a day, so wherever we are, we come and go quite quickly.He added that trenches would be created and high-pressure air used to blow a high fibre cable through.Mr McGuigan said that small cabinets, which are connection points for the network to residentsrsquo homes, would also be ldquodotted around areas.He stressed: ldquoWe donrsquot put them in corners or outside peoplersquos front windows. They canrsquot be in the line of sight of someone and we keep them away from driveways.ldquoAll the work we do is on adopted council land, so we speak to the council beforehand and get the notices in.ldquoIf we need to go into any private estates, shared drives and private roads, we seek way leave which is permission to go in there. If we donrsquot get that, we donrsquot go in.Small diggers will be used to carry out the work and soft areas will be dug up by hand.Mr McGuigan added: ldquoThe barriers will go upthere is a driveway and we will make sure itrsquos covered. We have ramps to go over, so everyone can get in and out.ldquoWe will dig up the pavement ndash unfortunately there will be a scar. We do it the same colour as the pavement. If itrsquos slabs, we will lt them up and put them back down. If itrsquos mono block, we have special mono blocking teams. If itrsquos just concrete, we use the same colour concrete. We will have multiple crews in multiple areas.He said that letters with his details would be sent out to local residents, adding: ldquoIf there is anyone on night sht, we will work round about that.Mr McGuigan said the work would start at the Fisherrow Harbour end of Musselburgh, with Wallyford the next phase, then Tranent and Port Seton.Information events will be held and a pop-up gazebo with information will also be located in the town centre.A company spokesman added: ldquoWith a Mbps connection, files, films and games become unbelievably quick to stream, download and upload.

title: first-dunbar-parkrun-to-be-held-this-weekend
story: The Lochend Woods Parkrun starts on Saturday morning, with runners covering a five-kilometre course in Hallhill.A trial took place on Saturday morning and Lynne Lewis, event director, was pleased to say things had gone smoothly ahead of the real thing starting at .am on Saturday.She said: ldquoThe parkrun trial happened in the most horrendous conditions.ldquoWe had  runners who braved the conditions and a lot were families, with mums and dads running with their children.ldquoWe tested all the kit on Saturday, tested the timer, uploading the times and that was all done on a test system.ldquoWe are expecting, hopefully, not too big a crowd ndash we could get  people running.Parkrun was formed in England more than  years ago by a group of friends who met each weekend for a jog.Until earlier this year, there were no parkrun events in East Lothian but Dunbar is set to join Meadowmill, near Tranent, in flying the flag for the county.Participants can either walk or jog the route, with a team of volunteers working hard for more than six months to see the event created.Mrs Lewis, who has taken part in more than  parkruns, said: ldquoIt is really about getting the message out there that parkrun is for everyone.The course starts at the running track outside Hallhill Sports Centre and is a figure-of-eight shape, comprising two laps of . kilometres.The course heads west away from the centre on tarmac paths around the sports pitches, then s towards the centre and heads into Lochend Woods, before ing towards the centre and repeating itself.Funding for the initiative has come from a number of local organisations, including the townrsquos running club, community council and Rotary club, as well as Viridor, EDF ndash Torness, Team East Lothian and Improve My Running.For more information, go to parkrun.org.uk lochendwoods

title: haddingtons-swimming-pool-to-close-for-nine-weeks-for-refurbishment
story: The pool and health suite at the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre is due to shut in April to allow operators enjoyleisure to update the pool hall, which dates back to the s.Essential maintenance and interior deacutecor works will be carried out at the sports centre, off Mill Wynd.Bill Axon, enjoyleisure general manager, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be working with our partners, East Lothian Council, to bring to fruition the upgrade of the pool hall at Aubigny Sports Centre for the benefit of our customers.ldquoIn a coastal county such as ours, being able to swim is a key le skill, as well as delivering numerous health and wellbeing benefits.ldquoAs East Lothianrsquos charitable sports provider, enjoyleisure is delighted to offer swimming opportunities across the county.ldquoIn order to deliver on our aim to inspire active communities, we realise our facilities have to be as inviting as possible. This refurbishment will truly revitalise the swimming pool within Haddington for the benefit of all.One of East Lothianrsquos original sports facilities, lsquoHaddington Swimming Poolrsquo, as it was first known, opened in September .The much-loved site consists of a four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool.Currently, the facility welcomes about , bathers to the pool each week for swimming lessons, AquaFit classes, swimming club training, school and public use.enjoyleisure, which operates leisure centres in the county on behalf of the council, is working on plans to give the pool hall a facelt from its existing s facade.Currently, the work is scheduled to take place over a nine-week period from April .The refurbishment plans include the complete replacement of custom-fit ceiling window  and a new roof covering.Inside the pool hall, following a complete drain of both pools, a light and bright ceiling covering will replace the outdated wood cladding.A new energy-efficient lighting scheme will be fitted which it is hoped will transform the look and feel of the facility.Existing wall tiles will be replaced with wall liner  to complete the new look.While the pool and health suite will close for the work to take place, the rest of the centre, including the gym, dance studio, sports hall and cafe, will remain open.For more information on the refurbishment plans, go to enjoyleisure

title: britons-tell-of-frightening-evacuation-from-cruise-ship-off-norways-coast
story: Two hundred Britons were on board theViking Sky ship which sent a mayday call after losing engine power, prompting the start of an evacuation of , passengers and crew in high winds.Local police inMoere og Romsdal said the shiprsquos crew hadmanaged to anchor in Hustadvika Bay, amid fears the vessel wouldrun aground.The shiprsquos operator Viking Cruises said a small number of non le-threatening injuries had been reported.Wersquore waiting for evacuation by helicopter #VikingSky #Mayday pic rqSYaWGikmdash Alexus Sheppard ##zwj#March , Footage online appeared to show the ship rocking dramatically, with debris falling from the ceiling and furniture including chairs sliding across the floor as passengers sat waiting to be rescued.Derek and Esther Browne,from Hampshire, said the ldquowhole boat was swaying, it was very rough before they were airlted to safety.Mr Browne toldBBC Radio  Liversquos Stephen Nolan: ldquoWe had a few people on stretchers, several with cuts, two with broken limbs, but fortunately we were alright. We were airlted onto the helicopter which was quite a frightening experience.He added:ldquoIrsquod never been in a helicopter before, there were a lot of high winds, hovering overhead and the winchman came down and we were then collected up and so I shut my eyes as we arrived into the helicopter and there were  of us for about a -minute ride.Norwegian media said the majority of the cruise ship passengers were British and American tourists.By pm local time in Norway around  people had been rescued from the ship.The ship was due to arrive in Tilbury in Essex on Tuesday.A spokeswoman for Viking Cruises said: ldquoThe ship is proceeding on its own power and a tugboat is on site. The evacuation is proceeding with all necessary caution.ldquoA small number of non-le threatening injuries have been reported. Guests are being accommodated in local hotels when they arrive back on shore, and Viking will arrange forflights for all guests.The operator advised anyone with concerns about guests who were onboard to visitwww.vikingcruises oceans my-trip current-sailings index.html.Theft Viking Sky was built in  and is described on the official website as a ldquocomfortable, award-winning ship, intimate and thoughtfully created by experienced nautical architects and designers to enrich your interaction with your destination in every way.A spokeswoman for the Foreign Office said: ldquoWe are in touch with Norwegian authorities and stand ready to help any British people who require our assistance.

title: pm-coup-plot-speculation-reaches-fever-pitch-amid-all-over-tweet
story: The Prime Minister could be forced to resign within days, one paper claimed, amid a furious backlash over her handling of Brexit.Mrs Mayrsquos former policy adviser MP George Freeman said it was ldquoall over for the PM, tweeting: ldquoShersquos done her best. But across the country you can see the anger.ldquoEveryone feels betrayed. Governmentrsquos gridlocked. Trust in democracy collapsing. This canrsquot go on. We need a new PM who can reach outbuild some sort of coalition for a PlanB.Irsquom afraid itrsquos all over for the PM. Shersquos done her best. But across the country you can see the anger. Everyone feels betrayed. Governmentrsquos gridlocked. Trust in democracy collapsing. This cant go on. We need a new PM who can reach out  build some sort of coalition for a PlanB.mdash George Freeman MPMarch , Pro-EU former education secretary Nicky Morgan told the Sundaythat Cabinet ministers should tell Mrs May ldquoitrsquos time to go while Brexiteer Steve Baker said potential leadership contenders in the Government should ldquoact now.Tory backbencher Anne-Marie Trevelyan wrote in the same paper: ldquoWe now need a leader who believes in our country and wants to take her on the next stage of her journey.Conservative peer Lord Gadhia, a former member of David Cameronrsquos inner circle, said the upcoming days in Parliament may be ldquovery dramatic and could see the end of Mrs Mayrsquos time as premier.The Sunday Times reported  Cabinet ministers had told the paper they wanted Mrs May to make way for someone  and that the PMrsquos de facto deputy David Lidington was in line to take over the helm.But the Mail on Sunday reported ministers were plotting to install Environment Secretary Michael Gove as a caretaker leader.On Saturday, around one million people were said by organisers to have joined a march on Parliament demanding a final say for the public over Brexit.Marchers waving EU flags and carrying their placards emblazoned with political messages weaved their way from Hyde Park Corner to Parliament Square.Elsewhere, pro-Brexit campaigners will continue their long hike from the North East to the capital, leaving Loughborough on Sunday morning.After another turbulent week for the Prime Minister which saw her come under fire for delaying Brexit and seeking to blame MPs for the impasse, the Commons was expected to be given the third chance to vote on her Withdrawal Agreement this week.But on Friday night Mrs May wrote to parliamentarians warningthere is insufficient support for her Withdrawal Agreement in the coming days that she could seek an extension to Britainrsquos EU membership beyond the European Parliament elections.Mrs May said she was holding Brexit meetings over the weekend as she tweeted pictures of herself on the local election campaign trail in Milton Keynes.Tory former Brexit secretary David Davis argued leaving without a deal on World Trade Organisation terms ldquolooks much better than the other options in front of us in a piece for the Sunday .On a busy weekend of Brexit meetings, good to join @iainastewart and @MKConservatives and talk to local residents ahead of the council elections on  May. pic fImEReGMZmdash Theresa MayMarch , He wrote: ldquoIf Parliament rejects the deal on offer, the Prime Minister has it in her power to deliver a WTO outcome. That is what she should do.ldquoAndsome Ministers resign as a result  That would be a pity, but there are always volunteers to replace every departure.

title: call-to-crack-down-on-unqualified-scots-identifying-as-electricians
story: Tory Jamie Halcro Johnston described the lack of regulation in the profession as an ldquoanomaly and has urged the Scottish Government to take action to ensure the title of electrician is protected in law.Over  professions are currently protected in law, including registered gas engineers, but not electricians.Mr Halcro Johnston said that he will introduce a membersrsquo bill to the Scottish Parliament aiming to address the issue.In a debate on the subject in October, MSPs from across the parties at Holyrood gave their support for providing protection of title.Mr Halcro Johnston said: ldquoFor too long, the Scottish Government has dithered around the regulation of electricians.ldquoIt has been discussed and discussed again, without any real commitments ever seeing the light of day.ldquoWhen I speak to people about this campaign, the first reaction is usually surprise that anyone can call themselves an electrician without any qualication.ldquoWhen so many other trades and professions are regulated, it seems the position of electricians is more of an anomaly than anything .ldquoMost people donrsquot consult electricians on a regular basis and arenrsquot always confident about the qualications of people they employ. This should provide some additional protection to consumers.ldquoElectrical safety is vitally important. Every year, there are fatalities caused by electric shocks and fires caused by electrical mals. It is important that people carrying out electrical work are qualied and able to do so.ldquoI was pleased to get so much support from across the political parties when this was debated back in October and I would hope that support would carry across to introducing a Bill on the subject.Skills Minister Jamie Hepburn said: ldquoThe serious concerns raised about electricians are being considered fully and we are committed to continuing to work in partnership with all stakeholders.ldquoDuring a debate in Parliament in October last year, I offered to meet with any MSPs to discuss these issues further. Whilst others have made contact, Mr Halcro Johnston has not taken up this offer.ldquoFollowing calls for further regulation, we formed the Electricians Working Group to bring the industry together and attempt to build consensus for a way forward.ldquoAn independent analysis of research, leading to a risk assessment and business case on the way forward, is due to be presented to the Scottish Government later in March.

title: we-are-f-says-official-report-on-impact-of-brexit-on-rural-scotland
story: A document published by Scottish Rural Actionfeatured a side banner on page four with the statement.It was one of a number of banners attributed to participants in a workshop which asked them to imagine what newspaper headlines they might expect to see after Brexit.Amanda Burgauer, SRA chairwoman, said that the exercise had been used as an ldquoicebreaker and that several of the participants had used ldquoearthy language in describing their feelings towards Brexit.The comments are only explained on the following page, saying they had been put forward by those taking part in the workshop event.Ms Burgauer said that she would flag up the ldquodesign and layout issue with the SRA design team.The Scottish Government has said that although the SRA report was funded through its Brexit Stakeholder Fund, it had no editorial role.The report will be launched at an SRA event with cabinet secretaries Mike Russell and Richard Lochhead in Elgin on Monday.Its findings also detailed the potential impact of Brexit on rural Scotland, suggesting that it could lead to ldquost century clearances, with a loss of freedom of movement resulting in signicant depopulation.Further concerns raised in the report, taken from conversations with rural communities, also included the risk of EU funding being lost post-Brexit and potential damage to social cohesion.Speaking about the report overall, Ms Burgauer said: ldquoThis report is about giving voice to a rural point of view that is rooted in Scotlandrsquos people and places, rather than its rural industries.She added: ldquoThere is widespread anger and frustration across rural Scotland, but that anger isnrsquot solely about Brexit.ldquoIt was clear from workshop discussions that Brexit is compounding long standing concerns about rural equity and fragility.ldquoBrexit was described as the lsquostraw that breaks rural Scotlandrsquos backrsquo, with people pointing to structural fragilities across rural communities.ldquoParticipants generally believed that an historic over-reliance on EU funding to lsquoprop uprsquo rural areas makes rural Scotland particularly exposed to future loss of EU support.Speaking ahead of the reportrsquos launch, Constitutional Relations Secretary Mike Russell said: ldquoThe Scottish Government is committed to ensuring the voices of rural communities are heard and I commend Scottish Rural Action for the work it has done to achieve this.ldquoThe findings in this report are stark. Taking Scotland out of the EU against our will removes us from a market which is eight times bigger than the UK alone.ldquoRural communities are deeply worried about the impact of Brexit on their lives. From funding and trade to community le and the workforce, many believe the effects will be nothing short of catastrophic.ldquoThis is sadly yet another example of just how damaging Brexit will be for Scotland.A UK Government spokesman said: ldquoThriving rural areas with strong, sustainable economies and vibrant communities will continue to be a priority for the UK Government when we leave the EU.ldquoWe have committed to establishing a UK Shared Prosperity Fund, which will cover Scotland, to increase productivity in areas where the local economies are furthest behind.ldquoWe have also confirmed that we will maintain the same cash total in funds for farm support until the end of the Parliament.

title: glasgows-vegan-soul-food-kitchen-reviewed-by-ron-mackenna
story: GlasgowLETrsquoS go out for Sunday dinner, I suggest, and to high fives all round we pile in thecar, cruise the motorway, park easily and almost skip down to a basement in Finnieston. Home of the good restaurants. There are sunny colours on the wall, a free table in a corner, cheery waitresses and music playing from speakers in the ceiling.As the family scans the menus I shuffle back in my seat and wait and watch as little dark clouds of puzzlement slowly puff above their heads.Hang on, says my sonhellipthis isnrsquot a vegan restaurant, is it  Umm, ooh, arr could be, I reply, provoking sighs all round. Vegan is good, vegan is healthy, vegan is cool. Oh, alright, I would have needed dynamite to get them out the houseI had mentioned the V word at home.Over a Karma Cola ndash naturally sugar-free ndash I cheerily mention that while meat is notmurder the unspeakable horror of what we do to animals infor bland, usually tasteless, throwaway crap is just not right.Come on, humans ndash whisper it, we are monsters.Course, as we canrsquot even sort out what we do to each other, what chance have the poor animals got  Anyway, high five to the vegan nation I say, one day all food will be like this. Well, not exactly like this I hope as, like a needle being scratched from a turntable, the opening notes of tonights meal are not the best. Somehow the sweet potato chips come out the kitchen looking tired, very dark and unappetisingly floppy. And they should be able to do chips. The plain-vanilla potato versions are not much better.That great mound of vibrantly yellow turmeric and pineapple sauerkraut is hugely acidic, pungently vinegary, and very tough. Isnrsquot real sauerkraut vegan anyway At this point Irsquove also got to confess to a squeamishness when it comes to all these fake-meat things that populate some vegan restaurant menus, yes probably too many sci-fi movies when I was young.But what is seitan  And was that really a wise choice for a name  Itrsquos wheat and gluten, it transpires. Raw cheese sauce  Itrsquos actually just nuts and juices ndash which to me sounds a damn sight less sinister than the official description which will easily stampede the non-vegan horses.Joanna Blythman reviews: Condita in EdinburghWalnut taco meat  Now, I actually have this in my raw Mexican bowl and after some peering and a cross table consultation with the chirpy waitress we come to the conclusion itrsquos just minced walnuts.Vegan mayo  This one genuinely gives me the shudders but, calm down dear, itrsquos apparently simply soya milk, lemon, salt and vinegar.Back to that raw Mexican bowl then  Great, actually. Fresh, crunchy, textured with what is essentially a mountain of crumbly walnut mash, flavoured with that mayo stuff, light, refreshing and I would definitely have it again.In fact, I positively skip out the place, though thatrsquos partly because theyrsquove turned the tinny ceiling music system over to a whole album of someone called Best Coast and it sounds like an Asbo Family are having a very annoying party in a flat right upstairs.OK, thatrsquos an age thing. The rest of the food  The beetroot burger ndash nobody fancied taking on the great seitan version ndash is a decent idea of a warmed minced beetroot patty, lots of hummus, some salad but is let down by the bun.We also have an African peanut stew which is nothingnot blandly, excessively sweetly, studenty and served in a huge quantity.I could have tried the ldquoin-house Asian beef but as I believe, and I think this meal shows, vegan meat substitutes usually taste just plain strange while vegan food thatrsquos not pretending to be anything is usually pretty good.So, Irsquoll say this about the Soul Food Kitchen: itrsquos not much dferent than a middle of the road non-vegan restaurant. Flaws and all. So itrsquos no breakthrough.Soul Food Kitchen Sauchiehall StreetGlasgow  Menu: Itrsquos vegan, Jim, and just as we know it, seitan burgers, raw cheese and meat-free-mayos. The usual mix of fake meat and fresh vegan dishes.  Service: Bright, breezy and cheery staff are helpful though maybe not knowing much more than the rest of us about those strangeingredients.  Atmosphere: Itrsquos a clean, crisp and relentlessly cheery basement made up reasonable successfully of a number of rooms with the added plus of slogans on the walls.  Price: Nothing here to stampede the horses, most mains came in at under a tenner.  Food: To this non-vegan itrsquos pretty good when not doing meat substitutes but the kitchen needs to be much sharper with simple things like side dishes and fresh bread.

title: annie-lennox-joins-host-of-celebrities-urging-support-for-campaign-to-reverse-brexit
story: Actor Hugh Grant, scientist Brian Cox and comedian David Mitchell were also among those who put their names to the petition with the official D-Day over Brexit just eight days away.Annie Lennox tweeted her support saying: "I have just signed this petition to #RevokeArticle. Itrsquos currently gaining k signatures an hour!"Please join me, sign  share."Some attacked her decision.George Ross responded: "So, to hell with the people who voted out  Some democracy."Sarah Hewlett added: "OMG itrsquos so sad when celebrities feel they have to stick their nose into current affairs, stick with the music, we voted, wersquore leaving, get over it #ticktock not long to go now!!"And a tweeter by the name of CeeJay said :"Why does Remain never realise that circulating luvvie celeb types advocating their cause does NOTHING to convert people to their cause. OMG! Some relative has-been or minor celeb thinks so and so therefore I must too."But the vast majority of responses were positive.Anton W remarked: "Another wise Aberdonian.":Earlier this week, the University of Aberdeen moved to start flying the EU flag for the rest of the month while MPs discuss the future of Brexit.The University of Aberdeen said the move was "not a political statement" adding that it was "a symbolic gesture of solidarity with our European students and staff while the UK Parliament debates the next steps for Brexit".Jamie Pattenden quipped: "Sweet dreams are made of this!"And Anthony Marks said: "Watching the numbers rocket - despite the fact that the site seems to stall from time to time - is one of the things that is currently stopping me from feeling utterly wretched about Brexit."Film star Hugh Grant who supported the petition said: "Ive signed. And it looks like every sane person in the country is signing too."National emergency. Revoke Article  and remain in the EU."TV physicist Brian Cox said: "Ive signed this petition to revoke A and deal with the consequences afterwards - referendum, election, whatever."I have no idea whether these things do any good but after Mays astonishingly irresponsible speech this evening Ill give anything a go."In December, Annie Lennox, Chrissie Hynde, Pink Floydrsquos Nick Mason and Billy Bragg were among numerous artists, bands and music industry leaders who signed an anti-Brexit letter.The open letter, spearheaded by MusicEU, states that ldquoBrexit represents a signicant threat to the UKrsquos Music Industry. Addressed to MPs and the Prime Minister, it called for the British government to seek an alternative to Brexit.Irsquove signed this and, now I know that #@theresa_may# is on my side, Irsquom pretty sure she has too. https:t.co uvYfQsxKRevoke Article  and remain in the EU. - Petitions https:t.co XTbPuLXdigAn issue as big and important as Brexit should not come down to petitions - that said,you are frustrated that the PM is just not listening, you can sign here. https:t.co XpZGrFBfhgldquoWe, the signatories of this letter, represent artists, producers, managers, businesses and s from across the Music Industry in the UK and are writing to express our real concerns over Brexit and the current direction of the UKrsquos proposed departure from the EU, the letter says.The Musicians Union, The Association of Independent Music, Music Managers Forum, the Music Producers Guild and British Academy of Songwriters, Composers  Authors join label executives from Ninja Tune, Domino Recording Company and Warp Records alongside management companies, agents, concert promoters and music festival organizers in signing the letter.

title: herald-diary-ashes-to-ashes
story: IT was sad news when gted Scots author William McIlvanney died. We remembered Willie telling an audience at the Glasgow Film Theatre that he got one of his few negative reviews when he was walking down the road in Glasgow and "a big guy walking down the other side shouted, McIlvanney, who told you you could effin write  And I shouted back, Probably the same person who told you you could effin read, and I hastened on, because he was a large fellow.Hand it to himAUTHOR Bernard MacLaverty has the craggy looks of a man who earns his living from heavy toil rather than from tapping on a keyboard. It probably explains why, at his first book-launch in his native Belfast during troubling sectarian times, he was sitting at a table near the door in order to sign copies of his book, but women entering the store automatically opened their handbags in front of him, assuming he was working security.At first he tried to explain he was an author, but their disbelieving looks made it easier for him simply to rummage through the bags before nodding them in.Boxing cleverAUTHOR Meg Henderson, whose moving novel The Holy City is centred on the Clydebank Blitz, once told us that at a book signing a woman told her that her dead husband, from Clydebank, would have loved to have met her. She then added: "In fact, Ah was getting ready, and Ah thought, Ahll take him up anyway! " and out of her message bag she produced a box containing her husbands ashes.THOSE WERE THE DAYS - : Mr Stirrat drums up pupilsrsquo interest in musicAn age thingWE liked crusty old author Frederick Forsyth explaining that when he finished writing his memoir The Outsider he thought to himself: "Who have I insulted  Who might sue " The then -year-old was relieved to conclude that "there were only two left alive.CreakyOUR old chum Val McDermid, arguably Britains leading thriller author, once explained to fans at the Edinburgh International Book Festival that readers these days expected a bit of character development in a series of books. As she put it: "In the Golden Age it didnt really matter what order you read Miss Marple in ndash the only thing that happens is Miss Marples arthritis gets a bit worse.Ring to itAYRSHIRES Andrew OHagan once told his audience at the Edinburgh Book Festival that his late father was joking with him right up to his death. Recalled Andrew: "He said I had lied on Radio . You told them we had no books in our house when you were growing up. That isnae true. There was one. It was green. It sat on top of the fridge. That was the Kilmarnock Telephone Directory, I said. It doesnt countrsquo."PotteringHARRY Potter author JK Rowling annoyed a few right-wingers in America by describing Donald Trump as a racist. One American contacted her on social media to say he would now burn his Harry Potter books and DVDs. Joanne merely replied: "Well, the fumes from the DVDs might be toxic and Ive still got your money, so by all means borrow my lighter.Dogs leWE liked author Aaron Gilliess observation: "The best thing in the world is dogs with human names. A woman on my train was screaming, Stop it, Norman! You never do this at home!rsquo"Bottoms upOUR story about Glasgow crime writer Alex Grays new novel reminds us of previous author tales in The Diary, including Glasgow-born author Ryan ONeill, now in Australia, who told us: "Ive been in Australia about  years, but as Australians never tire of telling me, I still have my Glaswegian accent."In a shop the assistant asked me, Anything   and I said, No thanks, thats all. After we walked out, my friend who was with me said in a shocked voice, Why did you call him an asshole rsquo"THOSE WERE THE DAYS - : The Alpha robot with flashing lights and Dalek-like voice
