title: countdown-who-are-scotlands-favourite-60-bands
story: THE ASSOCIATESWhat do you want from pop music  Maybe you are after a band who can be your best mate  Or a group who will teach you how to think. Or a band who will be a cartoon version of that better band from the sixties. But whatyou want something more  Something rich and strange  Something extraordinary Billy McKenzie is the greatest gt Scotland has given pop music. This is not up for debate. Really, only Elizabeth Fraser comes close to him. McKenzie sang like a fallen angel. Some people didnrsquot like it. Those people were wrong.The three albums he made with Alan Rankine at the turn of the s rf on Bowiersquos example to produce music that was thrillingly alien. MacKenzies career following the high point of Sulk and its attendant hit singles Party Fears Two and Club Country, was a matter ofonlys and  starts and in  he took his own le. Scottish poprsquos lost boy. But even on his misfiring  album Perhaps he could sing a line like ldquoI had a wild affair, it never lasted and inject a novelrsquos worth of feeling into just a few words.Best for: Anyone who wants to know what the best Scottish pop can aspire to.Avoid : You dont like singing that breaks with Ed Sheeran middling-ness.MARMALADELong before the Eagles and Jackson Browne there was Marmalade, who sounded as though theyrsquod grown up on the San Andreas fault and were weaned on tequila rather than fortied wine. Originally The Gaylords , the band produced lovely swish harmonies, revealed on the likes of Cousin Norman and even Ob-La-Di-ob-lad-da but just as importantly they sang out loud you could be Scottish and not sound like Jimmy Shand.Best For: Classics such as Reflections Of My Le.Avoid : Yoursquore not keen on the Beatles reggae back catalogue.ALTERED IMAGESPost-punk-new-wave-turned-mainstream pop outfit Altered Images was fronted by the very cool Clare Grogan, famous, of course, for the film Gregoryrsquos Girl in which she played heavy-fringed, sweet-voiced Susan, apple of Gregoryrsquos eye . They were far from a flash in the pan, with six UK top  hit singles Best for: Infuriatingly catchy pop.Avoid : Infuriatingly catchy pop makes you vomit.PRIMAL SCREAMIf they had written nothing after Screamadelica, which remains perfect almost  years one, the would still get my vote. To run the country. Did you see Bobby Gillespie on This Week They lived as rock stars are supposed to, which is to say they lived well but unwisely, and yet continued to churn out dance and rock classics all done with swagger, style and utter distain for just about anyone .XTRMNTR, released in , is one of the great British albums of the millennium. With songs called Swastika Eyes and Kill All Hippies, whatrsquos not to like. As a live act, few can touch them.Best for: People who like honestyAvoid : You canrsquot forgive any band for ripping off rfsHUE AND CRYThe brothers Kane did their very best to convince the world they were Scotlandrsquos answer to Daryl Hall and John Oates back in the s with their powerful Stars Crash Down album. Clutches of singles such as Looking For Linda and Remote revealed the duo from Coatbridge could write haunting, hooky melodies butthere was a glitch in their armour it was they seemed to leap all too easily over the genres, which made them harder to sell.Best For: Strong melodies and Pat Kanersquos voice, which was close to being that of a classy crooner.Avoid : You like your bands to enjoy being pop stars.JOSEF KBlazing a trail for Scottish post-punk bands in the early s were Edinburghrsquos super-cool Josef K, named for a character in Franz Kafkarsquos The Trial, fronted by the charismatic Paul Haig and driven by a lo-fi sound that blended nervy, intense guitars with a propulsive rhythm section. At their best in a live setting, they only released one album ndash rsquos The Only Fun In Town, on Postcard Records ndash but somehow that has only burnished their glistening reputation. Along with fellow Edinburgh scenesters The Fire Engines, they remain one of Scotlandrsquos most iconic bands.Best for: Refuting the argument that the only good band to come out of Edinburgh were the Rollers.Avoid : You think Steely Dan should have spent a bit more time on their studio production.SIMPLE MINDSEyeliner, goose stepping and songs which featured a single chord were all emblematic of Simple Minds early work, and in fact little changed over the years.The Minds assumed the arrival of dance, in that they appreciated how far rock fans could travel without a chorus, and certainly never imaged a middle eight would in any way improve a song. The likes of Waterfront, however, proved so intoxicating that Jim Kerr still manages to sell us it today.Best For: Loud, hypnotic melodies.Avoid : Yoursquore trying to avoid the pop star intrusion into polemics.FRUITS OF PASSIONItrsquos a darn disgrace that Fruits of Passion didnrsquot reach the heady heights of pop stardom in, say, the same way that Texas and Deacon Blue did around the same time. Their five singles, released in the mid-s and collected together on their one and only self-titled album, are perfectly crafted pop classics. Vocalist Sharon Dunleavy was an s goddess, all spiky hair and giant earrings, soaring vocals with added heartbreak, and me and my teenage friends LOVED her for it.Best for: Joyful s pop fans.Avoid : Pop doesnrsquot bring you joy.BELLE AND SEBASTIANThe missing link between Glasgow faves The Pastels and every indie outfit to have come out of the cityrsquos art school since about , Belle And Sebastian can lay claim to also being one of Scotlandrsquos most Marmite-y bands: some hate them, many others adore them. But whether you view main man Stuart Murdoch as a twee romantic or the lyrical heir to Edwyn Collins and Morrissey therersquos no doubting the bandrsquos staying power and the impact they have had on a generation of Scottish musicians.Best for: Getting over a break-upAvoid : Yoursquore allergic to duffel coats and s pop-inspired earworms.THE COMMUNARDSFronted by Glasgow-born tto Jimmy Somerville, The Communards only racked up three top  singles but one of them ndash Donrsquot Leave Me This Way, Somervillersquos Hi-NRG take on Thelma Houstonrsquos disco take on the Harold Melvin And The Bluenotes soul classic ndash hit the top spot in , and both Communards albums went platinum. But more than that, as out gay men both Somerville and bandmate Richard Coles made the personal political during some of the bleakest years for the UKrsquos gay community:  ballad For A Friend was one of the first pop songs to deal with AIDs and it wasnrsquot just Donrsquot Leave Me This Wayrsquos soaring hook that made it so anthemic.Best for: Family weddings, about ten minutes before last orders and just ahead of Come On Eileen.Avoid : You prefer your singers to be at the Barry White end of the vocal range.Top : Scotlands all-time favourite albumsWET WET WETClydebankrsquos superstars appeared at the end of the s claiming to be a musical collective but the reality was that hits such as Goodnight Girl and Sweet Little Mystery were written by Graeme Clark. What the band also had was the enigmatic Marti Pellow, with the broadest smile in pop hiding some of the deepest unhappiness. Part of that unhappiness emerged from the fact the band never appeared to be as cool as theyrsquod loved to have been. Pop  Soul  Who knows.Best For: Saturday night party songs.Avoid If: You hate Love Is All Around. Marti certainly did.THE BIG DISHThis band, which formed in Airdrie around , had a knack of creating albums absolutely jam-packed full of brilliant songs. From the critically acclaimed Swimmer to the happy, more poppy Creeping Up on Jesus, you always knew you could stick a Big Dish cassette in the car radio and never have to waste hours trying to fast-forward and rewind it to the good bits.Best for: Fans of polished pop.Avoid : You much prefer ex-frontman Steven Lindsayrsquos solo stuff.THE SUPERNATURALSOne of the best things about Scotlandrsquos music scene in  is that The Supernaturals ndash cheerful Monkees-meets-the Boo Radleys popmasters of the late nineties and early noughties ndash are part of it. The band, most famous for its hit Smile, which has been used in adverts aplenty, are back and thatrsquos great news for the legions of fans who supported them through three brilliant albums, extensive tours and an Ivor Novello award nomination. Top band to see live.Best for: Witty lyrics and catchy tunes.Avoid : You think chirpy s indie pop bands who have broken up should stay broken up.STEALERS WHEELAlas, Stealers Wheel, you were gone too soon. The self-titled debut album included Stuck in the Middle With You as "the single you thought was the best Dylan record since " the  follow-up, Ferguslie Park, is a classic:  songs by Gerry Rafferty and Joe Egan, replete with gorgeous melodies and harmonies: Good Businessman, Star, Over My Head, Nothings Gonna Change My Mind, Steamboat Row. The last album, s Right or Wrong, remains under-rated, even today. Rafferty would of course have a splendid solo career, but his and Egans songs in Stealers Wheel - Ferguslie Park in particular - are worth visiting or re-visiting.Best For: Fans of high-quality songwriting and or intrigued to hear what a British version of Crosby Stills Nash  Young might have sounded like.Avoid If: Youre not a fan of high-quality songwriting and or are not intrigued to hear what a British version of CSNY might have sounded like.DEACON BLUEHave you ever been to a party in which no one, towards the end of the night, has sang Dignity  No. This has never taken place in Scotland since Raintown was released in  and will continue to the end of time as we know it. Ricky Rossrsquos hit rate however has revealed himself to be a master muso and a very clever lyricist. And Lorraine McIntoshrsquos harmonies are not to be dismissed.Best For: Whooping and hollering along to the likes of Real Gone Kid.Avoid : You donrsquot remember all the words to Dignity.LLOYD COLE AND THE COMMOTIONSFormed around a group of Glasgow University friends, one of whom was the titular Mr Cole, The Commotions were pretentious to a tee which is why they can lay claim to being the only Scottish band to name-check Eva Marie Saint, Arthur Lee and Norman Mailer on the same record. But they were also the authors of the catchiest British pop song of the s, rsquos Perfect Skin, and one of the decadersquos best British albums ndash Rattlesnakes, their evergreen  debut. For that reason alone they deserve to be in the pantheon of Scottish greats.Best for: Moody cover versions ndash check out Tori Amosrsquos haunting take on the Rattlesnakes title track.Avoid : Right now yoursquore going ldquoEva Marie Who "THE AVERAGE WHITE BANDThere arenrsquot many Dundee bands who have signed to Atlantic, moved to LA and topped the US album charts with a funk and soul record in the same year as Curtis Mayfield, Al Green and Bobby Womack all had albums out . But The Average White Band did all that and more ndash the more including being sampled by hip-hop acts like Beasties Boys and A Tribe Called Quest, and laying down one of the sharpest instrumental tracks of all time: Pick Up The Pieces, three minutes  seconds of stone cold funk magic.Best for: Keeping on and on until the break of dawn.Avoid : Dundonian funk doesnrsquot rock your boat.Paul Buchanan on Scotlands favourite album, HatsACDCForget Scotland or Australia, they are simply the greatest rock n roll band theres ever been with a back catalogue that will blow up anyones stereo. Brothers Malcolm, Angus, and George Young were born in Glasgow while original front man Bon Scott was born in Forfar. A le-sized statue of Scott has pride of place in Kirriemuir where the annual BonFest take place and  years ago a Scottish Parliament motion was filed ember calling for the achievements of AC DC to be acknowledged. We should salute them.Best for: Anyone who freaks to the sound of a electric guitar played by a dementor.Avoid : You love ballads and loathe innuendo.COCTEAU TWINSIf you had to pick the one artist or band who sounded like they came from a dferent galaxy it would probably be this Grangemouth combo who put the dream in dream pop and produced one of the greatest voices in the form of Elizabeth Fraser. As with all the best music you may not have known what it was when you first heard them. It sounded like music for druggies.Best for: Everyone.Avoid : You think singing in an indecipherable language is utterly pretentious.YOUNG FATHERSExquisitely crafted and experimental art pop hip hop fashioned in Edinburgh that embraces the world and is as multi-cultural sounding as Alloysious Massaquoi, Kayus Bankole and Graham G Hastings are as iniduals.Best for: Those who enjoy music that challenges them.Avoid : You dont enjoy music that challenges you.DJANGO DJANGOFrom the bedroom-produced joys of their eponymous Mercury Prize nominated  debut, to the classic synth-based pop of their third album Marble Skies, this sublimely eclectic four-piece Edinburgh-formed avant-pop combo are a surfabilly thrill ride. Exuberant harmonies and killer synth hooks are the order of the day and they show no signs of letting up.Best for: Getting you from the bar to the dancefloor.Avoid : You dont want to get from the bar to the dancefloor.RUNRIGThey transcended the Scottish Celtic rock scene with tracks such as Hearthammer, Rhythm Of My Heart and An Ubhal As Airdendash the first and only Scottish Gaelic language song to reach the UK Top .The band, formed on Skye in , has seen copious line-ups over the years but for many fans the distinctive voice of lead singer Donnie Munro alongside songwriting brothers Rory and Calum Macdonald are perhaps most synonymous with the sound of Runrig.I would defy anyone not to get a tingle down the spine at hearing the live version of The Bonnie Banks o Loch Lomond as played at Balloch on June , .Best for: Pounding rhythms and rousing lyrics.Avoid : You lack a poeticrsquos soul.IDLEWILDIf you wanted to experience a manic pop thrill play Film For The Future by Roddy Woomble and co from their still irresistible debut album Hope Is Important.Best for: Inducing a headrush of guitar-induced sonic powerlistening to Captain, Hope is Important and some of The Remote Part.Avoid : Driving a car .ORANGE JUICEldquoI wear my fringe like Roger McGuinnrsquos hellip Come on, when did Ricky Ross ever write a line as good as that  In his heyday Edwyn Collins had more fun being a pop star than anyone  born north of the border. From the beginning Orange Juice were fey and wilful and arrogant, slightly incompetentand full of eff-you snottiness, which is exactly what you want in your pop stars. Maybe Edwyn was too cool for school to write anything that aches the way Roddy Framersquos We Could Send Letters aches, but, man, Falling and Laughing comes close, doesnrsquot it Best for: Jangly guitars. They wrote the book on them.Avoid : You dont like jangly guitars.CAMERA OBSCURAldquoYou say your le will be the death of youTell me, do you wash your hair in honeydewAnd long for all of them to fall in love with youBut they never do.Another in a long line of smart, pop-literate Scottish bands elevated above their peers by the fact that Traceyanne Campbell could sing the UKIP manesto and it would sound great .The tragic death of band member Carey Lander seemed to have marked the end of the band, but Campbell tweeted last month that they are back rehearsing.Best for: Lovelorn music fans who find Belle and Sebastian a bit too Walter Softy for their tastes.Avoid : you need music thats injected with an excess of testosterone.BOARDS OF CANADAThe Edinburgh post-electro maestros Dayvan Cowboy was a regular feature on the late lamented early-hours-in-the morning  Minutes show on MTV that was devoted to leftfield music. But it wasnt until the stunning Music has The Right To Children album that the penny dropped and when it did the almost orchestral wonders of Michael Sandison and Marcus Eoins downtempo ambient structures and form made sense.Best for: Chilling.Avoid : Not chilling.MOGWAIStuart Braithwaites crew pretty much define the term post rock and can mess with your headnot in the right mood. Listen to the incredible peaks-and-troughs soft-loud non-album track called My Father, My King ndash a -minute long entry point which was for a long time the best thing they had done. When your ears get attuned to their sonic power, the sheer intensity and dynamic melodies become a real rush.Best for: Giving your unided attention.Avoid : Loud guitars make your scared.BLANCK MASSThe drone electro project from Edinburghs Benjamin John Power, one of the founding members of F*** Buttons is one of the most exciting to emerge in this decade. His art is in his single-minded experimentation which revealed itself in his Odd Scene EP, the title track being a never-to-be repeated mash of electro drone, hardcore punk, black metal and goth that would make Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails weep.Best for: Lovers of in-yer-face electronicsAvoid : You find loud synths scary.THE KLFLook, anyone who could get Tammy Wynette to sing ldquoTheyrsquore justied and theyrsquore ancient. And they drive an ice cream van, gets our vote. In their time Bill Drummondand Jimmy Cauty burned poundmillion on a Scottish beach, took the Doctor Who theme tune to number oneand made some of the greatest Acid House anthems of the age. They bowed out at the Brits in  when they duetted with Extreme Noise Terror, and Drummond fired blanks from an automatic weapon at the audience. The KLF always knew the value of theatre.Best for: Going ldquoWooh wooh along with the band every time What Time is Love  Comes on the radio.Avoid : You have no sense of humour. Or two left feet.THE TRASHCAN SINATRASTheir timing was always lousy. Too late for Postcard, too early for the Postcard revival, constantly out of step with the zeitgeistAll that left is a series of albums so casually bruised and gorgeous that listening to them you canrsquot work how something that sounds so simple can break your heart so easily. If you want proof play Weightlting on repeat. It would make a great national anthem, by the way.Best For: Beta-male boys and girls who know that le is hard but sometimes beautul.Avoid : You are allergic to harmonies.Tomorrow: Part  countdown continuesWhat no Bay City Rollers or Hipsway, Gun or Franz Ferdinand  Tell us who weve missed off the list and why at letters@theherald.Compiled by Teddy Jamieson, Susan Swarbrick, Vicky Allan, Martin Williams, Barry Didcock, Russell Leadbetter, Marianne Taylor, Drew Allan, Andy Clark, Brian Beacom, Scott Wright, Neil Cameron, Ann Fotheringham, Garry Scott, and Mark Smith

title: kevin-mckenna-downs-children-like-my-beautiful-niece-ciara-are-a-gift-not-a-burden
story: Sometimes, depending on the extent of the social and emotional dficulties that already exist in some families, the task of making extra provision for a child with Downrsquos can prove too much. This is where a society such as our own, which aspires to provide care and support to all of its citizens, regardless of their special needs is supposed to rise to the challenge.My -year-old niece, Ciara, who has Downrsquos Syndrome, was born with a cocktail of health challenges associated with this condition, including a hole in her heart. Predictably, and at ious stages of her mumrsquos pregnancy the only advice coming from some medical staff was an abortion. The expert care and attention of other nurses and doctors though saw Ciara through the first few dficult years of her le while the love and dedication of her parents and her older brothers and sisters saw her realise her full, human potential. She has blossomed into a beautul and gted young woman who loves Little Mix and Ed Sheeran and who has represented her school and her country at international swimming events.This is the point where I could quote you statistics about the increasing quality of le enjoyed by Downrsquos Syndrome people or about how, on average, they now have a higher le expectancy than before. This, though, would be to diminish the experiences of those whose Downrsquos has come with an assortment of other issues and where the outcomes havenrsquot been as happy. I can only talk about my familyrsquos experiences with Ciara which, from the beginning, have been almost unormly positive ones.The biggest threat to this, though, came quite recently and from an entirely unexpected direction: the Catholic secondary school in England where, during her first three years there, she had enjoyed a very supportive and rewarding educational experience. She made progress in Maths, Science and English but, most importantly, she was happy in a small circle of friends and was included socially.A change of headteacher saw this change drastically when he refused to consider her for entry into the upper school on the grounds that she couldnrsquot meet the entry criteria for sixth form in Maths and English. Appeals to the board of governors were met with the response that ldquofunding was the main issue. When it was discovered that ldquofunding would be provided by the local authority more obstacles were found to prevent her re-joining her friends at her local school of choice. Further, it was discovered that the so-called ldquoentry criteria was not being imposed on other students.Even after an Education and Health Care Plan review stated that she should be included at this school a number of obstacles have been put in her way which her family believe are clear attempts to humiliate Ciara and to sicken them: she must repeat previous years must leave at lunchtime on certain days and was then refused aafter the half-term break because a teaching assistant couldnrsquot be found. Following a legal letter from the local authority the school has now reluctantly agreed to let herbut she must not mix with her th year peers, even at lunchtimes.Parents of Downrsquos Syndrome children all over the UK will recognise several aspects of this story. They arise from a refusal to recognise them as fully human or as being somehow less than fully-deserving of our public services. When we allow a personrsquos basic human dignity to be so easily stripped away due to disability, ill health and old age none of us will eventually escape the natural consequences of this.During Downrsquos Syndrome Awareness weeks we all become sentimental on social media when photographs are posted of smiling, happy children surrounded by love and we duly pitch in with touching messages of support. Yet a curious dissonance exists here in our attitudes to people with Downrsquos Syndrome. Wersquore all happy to sign up to an agenda which supports their basic human rights to be treated equally and as fully human yet seem quite happy to have Downrsquos Syndrome effectively screened out of existence in our modern, inclusive and enlightened world.The charity Donrsquot Screen Us Out has highlighted government figures indicating that % of babies who are prenatally diagnosed with Downrsquos Syndrome are aborted.Based on the most recent figures for Downrsquos births, this is projected to result in a decline of % reported live births of babies with Downrsquos.According to the charity, ldquothese consequences would have a profound long-term effect on the population of the Downrsquos Syndrome community, and enable a kind of informal eugenics in which certain kinds of disabled people are effectively lsquoscreened outrsquo of the population before they are even born.This is not a debate about abortion, rather itrsquos one about who gets to decide what it means to be fully human and how much we erode the rights of those that society deems to be something less. If we can get to a situation where Downrsquos Syndrome is regarded as such an imposition on our nice, normal way of le that we are screening it out of existence then what are the care and spending implications for those Downrsquos Syndrome people who made it to birth  And once we start quantying the human value of these, our brothers and sisters, sons and daughters, then when do we start coming for the aged, infirm and handicapped on grounds of cost and convenience

title: university-plea-to-scottish-government-over-pensions-black-hole
story: A joint letter from Universities Scotland and the UCU lecturersrsquos union highlights ldquograve concerns following the proposed amendments to public sector pensions by the UK Treasury.The changes impact on the Scottish Teachersrsquo Pension Scheme used by universities north of the Border.The letter states: ldquoYou will know that our organisations have been raising with you and your colleagues our belief in the need for the Scottish Government to make investments additional to the Scottish Budget to support the success of higher education and its contribution to Scotlandrsquos progress.ldquoThe unfunded increase in pension costs faced by Scottish higher education institutions is very dficult to meet from a flat-cash budget settlement.ldquoWe are deeply concerned that this cost will impact detrimentally on students and staff in Scottish universities.The letter says universities have now received notication from the Scottish Public Pensions Agency that the employer contribution to the Scottish scheme will increase even more steeply than expected, rising from . per cent of salary to  per cent from  September this year.It goes on to call for the Scottish Government to use additional money from Westminster that is part of the UK-wide Budget process - known as consequentials - to be given to universities.The letter adds: ldquoCan you confirm that these funding consequentials will be forthcoming and that the Scottish Government is committed to using them to mitigate the impact of increased employer pension contributions for all the sectors affected, including higher education A Scottish Government spokesman said officials were aware of the Treasury changes to public sector pension schemes, including the harmful impact these would have on many universitiesrsquo financial positions.He added: ldquoThe Finance Secretary wrote to the Chancellor early this month to press him to meet the full costs of changes to employer contributions to public sector pensions, including the teachersrsquo pension scheme.ldquoThe Scottish Public Pensions Agency continues to press the Treasury to confirm the extent to which it will provide assistance to address the shortfall in public sector pension schemes arising from these changes.The pension changes add to other cuts including to core budgets.

title: the-laird-who-wants-to-save-planet-and-refuses-to-lord-it-up
story: Roc Sandford regularly travels to and from his London home to spend one- third of the year living off-grid on the remote isle of Gometra.The environmental campaigner, who has not flown or owned a car for over a decade, even ditched his island quad bike ndash as an unnecessary luxuryndash two years ago.Choosing to make the long journey north by public transport, and cycling wherever possible, he stores his bike at Ulva Ferry, on Mull, before catching a ferry to the neighbouring isle ofUlva.The hardy father of four then tackles the final eight miles of rough track to Gometra on foot ndash via a bridge which connects the island to Ulva at low tide.And the aim, he says, is to make it ldquoa pleasure to use ever less fossil fuels.The -year-old, who is calling for the introduction of a carbon tax sothat polluters pay for their pollution, said: ldquoI bicycle most placesI canand otherwise use trains and buses.ldquoI have not flown for over  years and I have no car in Gometra, or London.For more than  years now Mr Sandford who, with help from a neighbouring family, farms a flock of  sheep on Gometra, has lived off-grid whenever he is on the car-free island, which has no ferry service.To say Gometra ndash which Mr Sandford bought to expand his farming acreage, after selling two smaller farms he inherited ndash is lacking in mod cons is an understatement.But the island owner, a paper millionaire who could easily pay for a jetset lestylehe sold his properties, loves the more basic existence that Gometra offers.He said: ldquoGometra is a beautul lump of rock, covered in heather, sat in the sea.ldquoWe have no mains electricity, no utility bills, no washing machine ndash I just have my feet and a bucket.Mr Sandford added: ldquoWe have to make everything ourselves on Gometra, but that is quite fun and stimulating, itrsquos nicer than the on-grid version, there is a satisfaction about it.He believes a greener lestyle is as feasible for town and city dwellers as it is for his own family and the other two households who live on Gometra, where one boat a week brings the mail and supplies to the island.Mr Sandford said: ldquoYou can have a solar , even in a city, then, even in a power cut, you have lights.ldquoPeople can think about the food they eat and how they do their washing, cut down on the amount ofmeat they eat, wear wool clothes, not cotton clothes, then you donrsquot have to heat your house as much.The single parent, who retains a base in London as a court order stipulates that his children must attend school on the mainland, said: ldquoIrsquom trying to import my Scottish off-grid experience to London, where it has much more of an impact because so many more of us live in cities.He added: ldquoI have no car and no telly in either place. In both Scotland and London I have solar .ldquoIn London, I also use renewable-only electricity from the grid. In Scotland I do without hot water.ldquoIn London I have a bath every week or so using gas, and use gas for cooking.ldquoI use wood for heating in London, anditrsquos really cold, or someone is ill, Irsquoll also use some gas for heating in London.ldquoThis is carbon offset lsquogreenrsquo gas ndash but Irsquom sceptical about that.ldquoNobody is perfect, butwe can just all make an effort ... I think, what Irsquom trying to do, is to make it a pleasure to use ever less fossil fuels.He added: ldquoI think there is a lot wrong with our mainstream le, we are programmed to think we want it, but itrsquos actually not very nice.ldquoThe air is polluted and it is noisy and people are unhappy because they are being put in dficult positions by our mainstream society and itrsquos very tempting to go away from that and find a less damaging way of le.ldquoPollution is theft. I think this is the root of the whole problem we are facing ndash that polluters are not paying the cost of their pollution.Mr Sandford lost  ewes-in-lamb in exceptional wintry conditions on Gometra last March, which he blames on climate change.He said: ldquoIf we do not take urgent action, it may well kill everything we love.

title: mystery-of-the-scottish-goalie-who-helped-everton-to-first-league-title
story: But the final resting place of Scots-born David Jardine remains a mystery.Historians attached to the English Premiership giants have already tracked down the unmarked graves of two other players from north of the Border who starred for Everton in the past and have erected memorial headstones.But the exact whereabouts of Jardine, who ed to Scotland when his playing days were over, is proving to be more dficult.A plea has now been issued for information in the hope that the grave ndash believed to be somewhere in Lanarkshire or the Scottish Borders ndash can be found and a permanent tribute put in place.The son of a stonemason from Dumfriesshire, Jardine lived in the Lanarkshire village of Crawford at the start of the th century once his playing career was over.His we, Sarah, died after the family moved to a house near Elvanfoot in .They had two sons ndash John and Robert ndash and it was from Robertrsquos emigration papers when arriving back from South Africa in the s that it is known David Jardine had retired to a cottage at Causewayend between Biggar and Coulter.Jardine senior died on March , , at the cottage just outside Biggar, but that is where the information trail ends.Tony Onslow, from the Everton Heritage Society, said: ldquoThe obvious place for David to be buried is with his we at Elvanfoot Church, but there is no record of him there.ldquoWe have exhausted every option around South Lanarkshire and also where Davidrsquos parents and siblings are buried at Applegarth in Dumfriesshire.ldquoThere is a chance he was cremated but, again, we can find no record.ldquoEverton Heritage Society undertake one or two of these research projects every year with the aim of re-dedicating the grave with a headstone featuring the club crest.David Jardine was born on December , , at Templand in Dumfriesshire. Following school he served his apprenticeship as a tailor, but it was while playing as goalkeeper for Mid-Annandale that he attracted attention.In March , at the age of , he accepted a professional contract from English Football Alliance club, Bootle.It was during a game against Merseyside rivals Everton on April , , that Jardine grabbed the headlines as he helped Bootle pull off a major - shock.The match report in the Football Field periodical stated: ldquoThe young Scot between the sticks punched, kicked and caught the ball with great agility.ldquoHe threw himself down upon the ball in a manner which even the heartbroken Evertonians could not forebear to cheer.Jardine also helped Bootle to lt the Liverpool Senior Cup in his first season.The following November he signed for Everton and made his debut in a - win over Blackburn Rovers as they went on to win their first ever Football League championship.Jardine shared goalkeeping duties during   as Everton saw out their final season playing at Anfield.And he was between the posts in the clubrsquos very first league game at the new Goodison Park against Nottingham Forest on September , .Jardine ndash having played a total of  games for Everton ndash left Merseyside at the end of the season and signed for Lancashire club Nelson.Although he helped his new team win the Lancashire League, he was toto Scotland and marry Sarah Smith in .Jardine also ed to tailoring, although he did briefly help Wrexham win the Welsh FA Cup in .Mr Onslow added: ldquoWe are fairly sure hersquos not buried anywhere in South Lanarkshire as the council has helped us with our research.ldquoWe are hoping that there will be descendants of David Jardine still living in the area who can help us.The Everton Heritage Society has already erected two headstones in Scotland in memory of former players Andrew Hannah and Sandy Young.Civic and religious authorities have records of who is buried where, but researching historic archives can be laborious and often fruitless.Scottish Borders Council has conducted an initial check and officers have agreed to carry out a more in-depth investigation of cemeteries around Broughton and up to the South Lanarkshire boundary in the coming weeks.A spokesman said: ldquoWe have begun checking our records to seeDavid Jardinersquos unmarked grave is situated in the Borders.

title: revealed-scottish-airport-lounge-named-second-worst-in-uk
story: Which  inspectors found the Essex airportrsquos Skyle Lounge had no hot food, no runway view and no sparkling wine, earning the facility just one star out of five.Reviews described the lounge as having ldquostained carpets which were ldquodusted with crumbs, while the food offering was a ldquosad-looking buffet of ldquounripe bananas and ldquopastries cut into halves.Access to the lounge costs nearly pound when booked in advance or pound for those paying on the day.The airportrsquos website claims the lounge is ldquosmart and sophisticated, urging passengers to ldquostart your journey in real style.Edinburghrsquos Aspire lounge received the second worst score with just one-and-a-half stars.Although the facility did include a hot food menu, an inspector described a salad as having ldquoa past-its-best tang while a pasta dish ldquolooked like cat food.Joint third worst were London Lutonrsquos Aspire ndash which offered ldquocongealed eggs and ldquostale bread rolls ndash alongside Belfast International Causeway and London Heathrow Terminal  Aspire.Complimentary sparkling wines and a la carte dishes helped London Heathrow Terminal  No  lounge share first place.It was described by inspectors as the best-equipped facility, boasting a cinema, free showers, private sleep pods and hot food options made to order.Also sharing the top spot were the Manchester Terminal   and London Heathrow Terminal  The House lounges.Which  Travel editor Rory Boland said: ldquoBattling through security queues and the maze that has become duty-free can be such an ordeal ndash itrsquos no wonder that the promise of an oasis of calm in a pay-to-enter lounge is so appealing.ldquoBut with lounges charging up to pound for what might amount to little more than a seat on a stained sofa and a soggy pastry, passengers might be better off saving their cash to treat themselves once they reach their destination.Which  reviewed  pay-as-you-go lounges at nine UK airports between September and December .

title: theresa-may-admits-third-vote-on-her-brexit-deal-may-not-take-place-next-week
story: The Prime Minister wrote to MPs warning thatthere is insufficient support for her Withdrawal Agreement in the coming days that she could seek an extension to Britainrsquos EU membership beyond the European Parliament elections.It came after the DUP ndash whose support will be crucialthe Government is to win ndash indicated they would not back her deal, with the partyrsquos deputy leader Nigel Dodds lamenting the PMrsquos failure to secure any changes to the Northern Ireland backstop while in Brussels.ldquoNothing has changed as far as the Withdrawal Agreement is concerned. We will not accept any deal which poses a long-term risk to the constitutional and economic integrity of the United Kingdom, he said.Mrs May sought to soften her approach in her letter to parliamentarians, offering to hold talks with MPs and thanking those who have backed her plan previously.And she laid out the choices available to the Commons after she agreed a delay to Brexit with EU leaders in Brussels on Thursday night.The PM said the UK could revoke Article  leave without a deal ask for an extension beyond April her deal is rejected or not voted on or leave on May it is finally approved.Mrs May wrote: ldquoIf it appears that there is not sufficient support to bring the deal back next week, or the House rejects it again, we can ask for another extension before  April ndash but that will involve holding European Parliament elections.ldquoIf it appears that there is sufficient support and the Speaker permits it, we can bring the deal back next week andit is approved we can leave on  May.It came as ministers moved to try to head off an attempt by MPs to seize control of Commons business in a bid to secure a ldquosofter Brexit.A cross-party group of pro-EU MPs claimed they had the numbers to force a series of ldquoindicative votes on alternatives to Mrs Mayrsquos Brexit deal.But Business Secretary Greg Clark said the Government was prepared to enable Parliament to express a view on the ious optionsMrs Mayrsquos deal is rejected by the Commons for a third time next week.Defeat for the Government on Monday on the amendment ndash tabled by former ministers Sir Oliver Letwin and Dominic Grieve and Labour MP Hilary Benn ndash would be a further humiliation for Mrs May.If the amendment is passed, it would pave the way for a series of ldquoindicative votes in the House on Wednesday, effectively taking control of the Brexit process out of the hands of the Government.Elsewhere it emerged that Tory former foreign secretary Boris Johnson met Mrs May for talks twice this week, including on Friday.Mr Johnson is said to have asked the PM how she intended to change her approach, and she reportedly set out plans to restructure the Department for Exiting the European Union.Hundreds of thousands of supporters of a second referendum will march through central London on Saturday, where Labourrsquos deputy leader Tom Watson is expected to say he will vote for the PMrsquos dealit is put to the people.Meanwhile Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, who has been reluctant to throw his full weight behind a so-called Peoplersquos Vote, will be campaigning in the North West of England.As Mrs May battles to stay in Number , Prisons Minister Rory Stewart said replacing her would not help the situation.ldquoI would rather she stayed because I donrsquot believe that changing Theresa May for someone  is going to resolve this problem, he told BBC Tworsquos Newsnight.ldquoThe problems are deep in the wounds of the vote, Parliament, the European Union ndash itrsquos not about a single inidual.

title: uri-geller-vows-to-stop-brexit-telepathically
story: In an open letter to the Prime Minister, the Israeli-British TV personality said he felt ldquopsychically and very strongly that most Britons were anti-Brexit and vowed to stop the process ldquotelepathically.An open letter to Theresa MayMy Dear Theresa,We have known each other for over  years since you became our MP. YouhellipPosted by Uri Geller onFriday, March , He wrote: ldquoI feel psychically and very strongly that most British people do not want Brexit.ldquoI love you very much but I will not allow you to lead Britain into Brexit.ldquoAs much as I admire you, I will stop you telepathically from doing this ndash and believe me I am capable of executing it.ldquoBefore I take this drastic course of action, I appeal to you to stop the process immediately while you still have a chance.Geller, who is currently in Israel, used to live in Sonning, which lies in Mrs Mayrsquos Maidenhead constituency.In his letter, he said he had known the now-PM for  years and that she had visited his home.He added: ldquoThree years before you became Prime Minister, I predicted your victory when I showed you Winston Churchillrsquos spoon on my Cadillac, which I asked you to touch.He also claimed he is using the power of his mind to ensure that ldquoJeremy Corbyn never gets the keys to Number  Downing Street.ldquoI will ensure that they bend out of all proportion to ensure that he never takes up residence there, he wrote.Geller rose to prominence in the s with an act based around his apparent psychic powers and telepathy skills, which were even tested by the CIA.He is perhaps best known for his trademark spoon-bending trick.After an extension was agreed by EU leaders on Thursday, the UK is due to leave the union on May Mrs May can get MPs to back her withdrawal deal.

title: unspun-the-political-diary
story: AMAZING what people drop in lts at Holyrood. Like the agenda for last weekrsquos Highland Conservative and Unionist Association AGM in Inverness. The sole motion said delaying Brexit beyond the European elections would ldquobetray the  vote and ldquodamage democracy and our party for a generation. Four days later, Theresa May asked the EU for precisely such a delay. Maybe Chris Grayling was meant to pass on the Highlandersrsquo message.Stocks clearanceWE reported last week that David Stocks, leader of the dysal SNP opposition on North Lanarkshire Council, was to quit his post on Monday. This proved incorrect. We hear Cllr Stocks was so annoyed by Unspun he decided to stand for re-election instead. This proved unwise. In a four-way fight, he was deposed by his deputy, Tom Johnston, who apparently never even thanked his old boss for his service. The fun continues.Logo no-goTALKING of the unwise, Nat nugget James Dornan has been scoffing at fellow Glasgow MSP Annie Wells. Tweeting a picture of Ms Wellsrsquos annual report to voters, Mr Dornan mocked the lack of anything identying her as a Tory. "Looks like she has decided to quit the Tories and go it alone as an Independent, he guffawed. ldquoBrave decision Annie. However, as any fule kno, MSPs are forbidden from putting party plugs on annual reports, so this was inevitable. We trust Mr Dornan follows the rule...Nae MatesA MORE revealing read is the latest Scottish Left Review. The lefty magazine has a special edition featuring the thoughts of Scotlandrsquos top trade unionists. So naturally union fanboy Richard Leonard features heavily, yes  Er, no. The Scottish Labour leader isnt mentioned by a single union boss. Although he does appear once in the mag - providing a testimonial in an ad for the Morning Star.Terrible twosLAST weekrsquos Holyrood committee in Skye about a smacking ban was wild, especially the exchanges between smackosceptic MSP Alex Cole-Hamilton and smackophile Rev Richard Ross. The Rev askedbeing smacked as a child made ACH more violent. ldquoI was smacked once, and I turned round and bit my father in the face, said ACH. ldquoSo, yes, it made me more violent at the time. But wasnrsquot he only two years old  ldquoAbsolutely. He never hit me again.Stormy passageTHE minister and the LibDem MSP also had a ding-dong after the latter said the Bible was used to justy we-beating. Rev Ross demanded ACH quote the exact scripture. ldquoCan you show me  There is an open Bible here. ACH whined to the chair. At which the Rev asked acidly whether ACH or the convener was in charge. The chair ticked off the minister for being ldquoaggressive and disrespectful. But as he only answers to a higher power, we suspect he didnrsquot care.Going for trebleWHEN he was Labour MSP for Glasgow Govan, Gordon Jackson used to joke that, having beaten Nicola Sturgeon twice in the seat,he beat her a third time hersquod get to keep her. In , Ms Sturgeon put an end to that hope and turfed him out. However lsquoJackorsquo may get another chance, of sorts. Alex Salmond has just engaged the QC for his upcoming court case.

title: british-forces-to-remain-in-syria-following-capture-of-last-is-territory
story: Major General Chris Ghika, Deputy Commander of the Global Coalitionrsquos joint task force, said the terror organisation is by no means ldquoleaderless or rudderless, despite its loss of physical territory.But he said he could not predict whether the fall of the physical territory would substantially increase or decrease the terror risk to the UK.The capture of Baghouz is a milestone in the four-year campaign to defeat the grouprsquos so-called ldquocaliphate that once covered a vast territory straddling both Syria and Iraq.It was announced on Saturday by Mustafa Bali, from the Syrian Democratic Forces, who tweeted: ldquoSyrian Democratic Forces declare total elimination of so-called caliphate and % territorial defeat of Isis.ldquoOn this unique day, we commemorate thousands of martyrs whose efforts made the victory possible. #SDFDefeatedISISSyrian Democratic Forces declare total elimination of so-called caliphate and % territorial defeat of ISIS. On this unique day, we commemorate thousands of martyrs whose efforts made the victory possible. #SDFDefeatedISISmdash Mustafa BaliMarch , The US withdrawal is already underway, with its main ally, the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces warning that leaving too soon could have dangerous repercussions and a destabilising effect on the region.Maj Gen Ghika told reporters at a Ministry of Defence briefing ahead of Baghouzrsquos fall: ldquoThere are no plans to scale down the contribution to Operation Shader.He added: ldquoThe US have said they are going to keep a presence in northern Syria so air power will play an important part in that, and we expect the British contribution to keep going on that side.ldquoIn Iraq exactly the same maxim applies, the British troops that are training the Iraqi security forces are going to stay and keep doing what they are doinghellip because Isis continues to present a threat and that threat is met largely by the Iraqi security forces.Maj Gen Ghika said the coalition must remain ldquovery conscious about the continued threat of IS and warned against allowing Syria to become a ldquosafe haven for the ideology.He continued: ldquoThey are not leaderless or rudderless. One of the reasons why even after the end of the physical caliphate Isis will remain a dangerous organisation is because there are members of the organisation willing to take on the struggle.ldquoThey are less experienced, they are less capablehellipthan the people of years agohellip so the organisation is weaker but there are still people willing to take on the leadership hellipand that is one of the things that we target.Maj Gen Ghika estimated there were a few hundred IS fighters in eastern Syria, and between -, in Iraq.The SDF is holding more than , foreign suspected fighters in prisons that it runs in northern Syria.The military commander said it was a ldquosovereign national decision for countries on whether take back citizens who joined IS.He said the British Government must decide whether British forces will have a role in repatriating citizens, including children of fighters.Askedthe threat to the UK would be removed by keeping fighters imprisoned, he said: ldquoI donrsquot think it removes it, but I think it reduces the threat of people of British origin who have fought with IS ing to the UK to conduct terrorist attacks.Maj Gen Ghika was also asked about whether the MoD will attempt to gather evidence from the battlefield once fighting is over which could be used to prosecute British fighters.He said: ldquoI think thatrsquos too early to say whether thatrsquos going to be possible but I thinkwe found any inidual of any nation and we were able to link them to crimes and with evidence we have then we would expect them to be prosecuted under the force of the law.

title: aberdeenshire-jobs-boost-with-announcement-of-joint-scots-eu-funding
story: Investment of pound. million has been announced for Irish-based meat processing company Kepak, based in Portlethen.Nearly  full-time jobs are now estimated to be secure as a result of the funding, as well as the creation of an additional  jobs.The company is aiming to use the money to help signicantly increase the amount of beef, cattle and lamb currently processed at the site.The funding has been made available through theFood Processing, Marketing and Cooperationgrant scheme, which is aimed at providing support for the Scottishfood and drink businesses.On a visit to the site, Rural Affairs Minister Mairi Gougeon said: ldquoThis is great news for the local area, not just to the hundreds of workers and their families who will welcome the job security this provides, but also because the factory plays a vital role in helping farmers get their quality beef and lamb products lsquofrom farm to forkrsquo.ldquoIn spite of the challenges being presented by Brexit, the Scottish Government continues to help our Food and Drink sector to realise the ambition to double in value to pound billion over the next  years.The FPMC scheme has provided vital financial support to over  Scottish food and drink businesses, helping to ensure the long-term viability of our primary producers, and maximise export markets for our fantastic Scottish produce.ldquoWith Brexit looming, this is a timely reminder of how EU funding makes a real dference to the lives of people in rural Scotland ndash providing millions annually to our farmers, fishermen, and food producers.ldquoThe UK Government has yet to guarantee much of that funding in the long term, should Scotland be taken out of the EU against its will.Portlethen site manager Alan Brown said: ldquoKepak Group very much welcomes the financial support provided by the Scottish Government towards the majorupgrading of our Portlethen site.ldquoThe well-established and reputable McIntosh Donald business was acquired seven months ago and we have moved quickly to develop and grow a business with great potential.ldquoThe timely award of this FPMC grant is a great financial and morale boost for the management, staff and suppliers in these uncertain times.

title: scotland-would-be-biggest-loser-from-abolition-of-erasmus-scheme-after-brexit
story: More students north of the Border choose to study and train in the EU through the Erasmus scheme than in nine other areas of the UK.The Erasmus programme, which was set up in , allows students to study or acquire skills in another EU country.The Prime Ministerrsquos Chequers agreement promised to ldquoexplore participation in the scheme, but it was not mentioned in the political declaration on the future relationship with the EU that May negotiated.Around , students from the UK take part every year, of which , study abroad, and Brexit has placed a question mark over whether the scheme will continue.It was revealed last week that students currently on the programme are in the dark over funding and accommodation, and some iniduals fear they could be left without health insurance.Figures released by the Peoplersquos Vote campaign, which backs another referendum, break down the the number of UK Erasmus students by  areas. The statistics, which are based on yearly averages covering  to , show that , students from Scottish universities participated in the scheme during this period.In second place was London, with ,, followed by the South West on , and , for the South East.Universities such as Edinburgh, Exeter, Leeds, Durham, Nottingham, and Bristol would be among the biggest losers.Popular destinations include France, Spain, Germany, and ItalyDavid Rodger, , who is originally from Stonehaven, studied French and German at St Andrews University, and spent a year in Leipzig.Back at St Andrews, he met his girlfriend Andrea, a Spanish student on an Erasmus year at the Fe university.ldquoIrsquove always loved languages and therersquos no better way to learn one than fully immersing yourself in a new city and culture. Erasmus offers kids from Scotland a brilliant opportunity to live and study at top Universities across the continent, he said.Richard Lochhead, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Further Education Minister, said: ldquoBrexit poses a direct threat to our membership of Erasmus, particularly in the event of a no deal.

title: independence-activist-promises-never-to-vote-snp-again-over-sturgeon-picture
story: Jonathon Shafi, who was a senior figure in the Radical Independence campaign, said it was ldquoabsolutely sickening to see Sturgeon photographed with Alastair Campbell, who worked for the former Labour Prime Minister during the run up to the Iraq war.Sturgeon was one of the high profile political figures at an anti-Brexit rally in London yesterday, at which campaigners called for Article  to be revoked and a second referendum to be held.The huge show of support for the UKrsquos place in the EU attracted cross-party support, with politicians such as London Mayor Sadiq Khan, Lib Dem leader Vince Cable and deputy Labour leader Tom Watson joining Sturgeon.Ahead of the rally starting, former Labour MP Douglas Alexander appeared to have a dig at the SNP by saying he was attending for his friend Blair McDougall, who led the pro-UK Better Together campaign: ldquoAnd everyone like him, near and far, who opposes nationalism  isolationism.Campbell, who was Blairrsquos spin doctor in opposition and then took on a similar role in Downing Street, was also on the march and a photograph of himself with Sturgeon was posted on his Instagram accountCampbell wrote: ldquoSorry Douglas. Sorry Ian. But I am genuinely pleased @nicolasturgeon is here to to speak for @peoples_vote.Shafi, who co-founded the RIC, responded: ldquoIrsquom done. Irsquom fucking done.He wrote: ldquoAlistair Campbell is responsible for opening the gates of hell to millions of Iraqis. Sturgeon happy to pose with him. Proud even. Totally done. The SNP will never, ever, get my vote again as long as she is leader.After being challenged by a former SNP MSP, Shafi wrote: ldquoI dont cuddle up to people who led is [sic] to a war that destroyed the lives of millions. Your leader does.He added: ldquoThis is personal too. I made a promise when they bombed Iraq that I would never forget. That I would committ to a le of trying to ensure such a thing would never happen again. That those responsible would be held accountable. Sorry @NicolaSturgeon but a line has been crossed.

title: calling all aberdeenshire residents
story: Are you interested in how Health and Social Care services are delivered in your area  Have you ever visited a GP  Seen a school nurse or health visitor  Visited a Care Home  Or maybe you care for someone or maybe you, yourself are cared for The chances are that everyone in Aberdeenshire has come into contact with the services that the Aberdeenshire Health and Social Care Partnershipis responsible for delivering.The AHSCP is in the process of developing a Strategic Plan for the next five years and we need your help to do it. We need to know what you think about the way we currently deliver health and social care services in your area and how we should shape our services to make sure they are fitfor the future.The Strategic Plan will be built around five key priority areas namely, Effective use of Resources, Prevention and Early Intervention, Reshaping Care, Engagement and Tackling Inequalities and Public Protection.A webpage has been developed with a range of resources including explainer videos to make it as easy as possible to participate http:bit.ly AHSCPengagementRhona Atkinson, chair of the Integration Joint Boardsaid: â€œThe team has developed a series of short videos that explain what each priority is, why it is a priority and some of the services that help us to deliver on that priority. So, it really is as easy as possible to follow and to tell us your experiences of what we offer now and how we could improve things for the future.â€œThere are a number of ways to get involved including an online pack which can be downloaded and used in a group setting, or you can simply choose to complete a very short online survey on the priority area you are most interested in.â€œWe really want to hear from as many people as possible so we are hoping that anyone involved in their community will feel impowered and supported to run their own session and feedback the outcome to us.â€Cllr Anne Stirling, vice-chair of the IJB, said: â€œThe Strategic Plan for the next five years will determine how we develop our services and how we, as a partnership, spend our money. title: call for marine energy to be included in government strategy
story: newsCall for marine energy to be included in government strategyMarch ,  at : am vw, px"  Alistair Carmichael MP.The UK government has been challenged to commit to ensure that marine and tidal energy is part of the governmentâ€™s energy strategy by Alistair Carmichael, MP for Orkney and Shetland.A white paper is a guide on the governmentâ€™s strategy and policy for responding to specic issues, one on energy has been expected for some time.Speaking in the House of Commons on Tuesday, Mr Carmichael said: â€œCan I thank the Minister for meeting with me last month. Of course we need to discuss with the Treasury any support mechanisms, but I do want to continue to engage with the sector on a long term basis.#Speaking after the exchange, Mr Carmichael added: â€œWhite papers outline governmentâ€™s thinking on policy areas, and are a key stage in influencing decisions made by ministers. title: carmichael government must start listening to farmers and crofters
story: Alistair Carmichael, MP for Orkney and Shetland, has today demanded that the UK government listen to farmers and crofters when deciding #no deal# preparations.Speaking in the House of Commons, Mr Carmichael called on government ministers to reconsider the rates of tax which are proposed to be charged on agriculture goods being imported into the UK.Mr Carmichael said: #Has the minister seen the call from the president of the National Farmers Union for Scotland, asking the government to abandon their proposals for an applied tarf in the event of a no deal Brexit #As he pointed out â€˜without the maintenance of tarf protections we would be in danger of opening up the UK to imported food which would be illegal to be produced here. In the s, his predecessors in the conservative government then regarded our fishermen as expendable. It is beginning to look like this government has taken the same attitude towards our farmers.â€Responding on behalf of the government parliamentary under-secretary of state for exiting the European Union, Chris Heaton-Harris MP, replied: â€œI disagree entirely. The tarf schedule is designed to protect every sector of the economy including agriculture. He then went on to talk about standards, and we are not dropping standards of what we expect in agricultural goods.â€Speaking after the exchange, Mr Carmichael added: â€œThe minister can disagree with me all he wants, but he canâ€™t dismiss the views of our farmers and crofters. They know what they are talking about and have genuine concerns about whether food standards will be eroded as a result of cheaper imports. The government must start listening to the experts in this area, and the unions who work on their behalf otherwise we risk undermining an important part of our rural economy.â€œWith only nine days left before we could find ourselves falling into a no deal scenario, the government have got to fix these tarf schedules before they do irreparable damage to our agriculture industry.â€copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: hial atc pay talks ongoing as offer turned down
story: Highlands and Islands Airports Ltdhave said talks with the Prospect union, over a looming air traffic controllers strike, will continue after an offer put on the table this week was turned down.HIAL met with representatives from Prospect in Inverness earlier yesterday to discuss the ongoing pay dispute.A HIAL spokesman said: â€œHIAL again tabled discussion on a possible retention allowance for Air Traffic Control Officers. However, Prospect has indicated that this would not be its membersâ€™ preferred option and it does not believe it would address their underlying pay issues.â€œAs it stands the claim from the trade union remains a minimum of a double-digit increase effective from April , . A report compiled jointly between HIAL and Prospect on air traffic controller pay at non-HIAL airports found no evidence of a signicant pay dferential with other comparable airports.â€œAt this point, it has not been possible to reach an agreement with the trade union on their pay dispute. Therefore, HIAL and Prospect have agreed to refer the matter to ACAS in a bid to resolve the matter.â€However, David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer replied: #Members demands are reasonable and they need to be addressed. They are not seeking parity with Heathrow or Gatwick but other smaller airports.#â€œThey have received a decade of below inflation pay rises while the rest of the industry, in response to a global shortage of controllers, has moved ahead. The company already struggles to recruit controllers and this is having an impact on services at some airports.â€œBy asking for support from ACAS we hope to find a way forward in these talks. However ministersâ€™ instructions to HIAL severely limit the companies negotiating position, so we also need to see these revoked.â€As it stands, controllers at seven of HIALâ€™s eleven sites, including Kirkwall Airport, are due to take strike action on Friday, April .Industrial action short of a strike was also likely to start in April and continue through until August, and include instruction to work to rosters, refusal of non-medical extensions, an overtime ban, and withdrawal of goodwill.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur calls on government to support tourism sector
story: Orkney MSP Liam McArthur has called on the Scottish Government to support Orkney#s tourism sector, urging ministers to resolve the stand-off over RET, support the replacement of the county#s ageing ferry fleet and better infrastructure for Orkney#s heritage sites.During a Membersâ€™ Business debate marking Scottish Tourism Month, Mr McArthur outlined the signicant growth in visitors and income into the county over recent years. He set out that, between -, tourism numbers have increased by an impressive  per cent to almost , people with an estimated value of nearly Â£m.Mr McArthur warned that this success could not be taken for granted and presented its own challenges. As well as urging ministers to resolve the stand-off over RET and provide support for the replacement Orkneyâ€™s ageing internal ferry fleet, the Orkney MSP also repeated his call for Orkneyâ€™s world-class heritage sites to be backed by world-class infrastructure.Speaking after the debate, he said: #Tourism is one of the few sectors that touches almost every part of the country and it is one where Orkney has been punching above its weight over recent years.#With the natural assets we have and a lot of hard work by those involved in all aspects of the tourism sector locally, Orkney has seen visitor numbers and income increase signicantly over recent years. This success has brought awards and recognition, but it also brings with it challenges.#Everyone knows that Orkneyâ€™s reputation for quality requires the tourist experience to be managed carefully. This will involve taking pressure off key sites as well as making more of what Orkney has to offer.#It also needs Scottish Government to step up to the plate, not least when it comes to transport links. The long-overdue introduction of RET would help Orkney remain competitive as a destination, while replacement of the ageing internal ferry fleet is not only vital for the islands they serve but a means of encouraging visitors to explore more widely once they get here.â€œMinisters also have a role to play, through Historic Environment Scotland, in helping ensure that Orkneyâ€™s world-class heritage sites are supported by high-quality infrastructure. Local partners, including Destination Orkney and the Council, must be closely involved but investment through HES is crucial to making this happen.â€œThere is good reason to believe that Orkney can continue playing to its strengths when it comes to tourism and there will be plenty of opportunities over the years ahead showcase our islands.Â  However, we cannot be complacent about what it will take to maintain and enhance Orkneyâ€™s reputation for good qualityâ€.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: oics views sought on electoral arrangements
story: A consultation has begun, asking councils representing Scotland#s three islands areas for their views on electoral arrangements.The exercise is being carried out by the Local Government Boundary Commission for Scotland, with the information gathered provided by Orkney Islands Council, Shetland Islands Council and Na h-Eileanan an Iar, to be used as part of a wider review of electoral arrangements. A public consultation is to follow later this yearThe consultation contains proposals around the use of one of two member wards, where a ward includes an inhabited island â€” an option made available under new islands legislation â€” as well as looking at the boundaries of wards.As part of the review, the public#s views will be asked for this summer.Responding to the launch of the consultation, a spokeswoman for Orkney Islands Council explained that, the commission are not recommending changes to the number of councillors but have proposed some changes to ward boundaries. Representatives from the commission are due to come to Orkney next month to discuss the proposals.Speaking yesterday, Ronnie Hinds, chairman of the commission, said: â€œWe are pleased to begin our consultation on electoral arrangements with the three councils today and I look forward to engaging with them on our proposals.#It is important that electoral arrangements for Scottish councils are effective and that our proposals deliver on requirements for electoral parity and, as far as possible, take account of local ties and special geographical considerations.â€œWe also welcome the flexibility offered by the IslandsAct to use one or two member wards and have used this flexibility as appropriate in our proposals.Â After completion of our consultation with councils we will be seeking public views on our proposals over the summer.â€The  Review of Electoral Arrangements will make proposals for the six council areas specied in the IslandsAct  â€“ Argyll and Bute, Highland, North Ayrshire, Na h-Eileanan an Iar, Orkney Islands and Shetland Islands.The commission is conducting the review in two phases, focusing firstly on Na h-Eileanan an Iar, Orkney Islands and Shetland Islands, with the reviews ofÂ  Argyll and Bute, Highland and North Ayrshire to take place after the public consultation in the islands groups takes place.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney mens shed praised in scottish parliament
story: The success of the Orkney#s Men#s Shed was raised during a Members# Debate in Scottish Parliament, by the county#s MSP Liam McArthur, earlier this week.Praising the work of the charity on Thursday Mr McArthur praised the work of the charity on Thursday, highlighting the benefits in terms of reducing the risk of loneliness and isolation or even poor mental health.The MSP also took the opportunity to repeat his call for ministers to look at the possibility of Menâ€™s Sheds bidding for health and social care funding, as happens in Australia, where the movement began back in the s.Men#s sheds are designed as a meeting and doing places for men who want to meet new folk, make new friends, learn new skills and socialise. Those behind the charity said it is well-known that men find it harder to admit to problems and seek help at an early stage, but the camaraderie of the Menâ€™s Shed is helping to overcome this resistance.Despite the success of Orkney Menâ€™s Shed and the growing popularity of the movement across Scotland, Mr McArthur suggested that they remain a â€œlargely unsung success storyâ€.Â  The MSP described the work the organisation does as â€œle-changingâ€ for its members, providing a sense of purpose and an opportunity to make friends and share company.Speaking after the debate, Mr McArthur said: â€œThe Menâ€™s Shed movement has been a tremendous success over recent years with the number of Sheds and â€˜Sheddersâ€™ across the country continuing to grow. This is illustrated perfectly in Orkney, where the local Menâ€™s Shed is going from strength to strength, with membership up to  and plans for expansion of the shed in Finstown.â€œEveryÂ Menâ€™sÂ ShedsÂ is dferent, of course, but all provide a place to work and relax, pursue hobbies, share skills, have a cuppa and a chatÂ and get practical help with projects. This should not disguise, however, the real impact Menâ€™s Sheds can and do have. Increasingly it is recognised that these facilities make a tangible dference in efforts to tackle loneliness, social isolation and mental ill health.â€œLast month, I urged the government to look at the case for allowingÂ Menâ€™sÂ ShedsÂ to bid in for health and wider social care funding. title: alzheimer s and aluminium linked in edinburgh university study of 7 000 scots
story: Higher levels of aluminium and fluoride in drinking water are related to the onset of dementia, according to a ground-breaking study of thousands of Scots.Research by scientists at the University of Edinburgh to examine environmental factors that might cause dementia found that the people who lived in areas with higher levels of aluminium in the drinking water were more likely to die from the illness.The study involved around , iniduals born in  who undertook an intelligence test in  which was the forerunner of the historical -plus exam. A total of , out of , participants in the study had developed dementia by . A north south ide in Scotland in the quality of drinking water was also revealed, with the North East coming out worst and the Borders and South West coming out on top. Coagulants such as alumare used to trap impurities in raw water by binding them together to form particles before they are filtered out. Fluoride occurs naturally and is not added to the water supply in Scotland. Researchers say there is some evidence that it increases the human absorption of aluminium. Study author, Dr Tom Russ from the Alzheimer Scotland Dementia Research Centre at the University of Edinburgh, stressed that the low levels of aluminium and fluoride found in the water in Scotland were â€œvery goodâ€ in relation to World Health Organisation guidelines. â€œEverybody included in the study was alive in  and they were all born in ,â€ he said. â€œEverybody who subsequently died with dementia was compared with those who died without, and the people who lived in areas of higher levels of aluminium in drinking water were more likely to die than those in areas where the aluminium levels were lower. â€œWe still see this well accepted finding that higher levels of aluminium in particular are associated with an increased risk of dementia. Itâ€™s confirmatory rather than anything .â€The study published in the British Journal Of Psychiatry, obtained water quality data from the Drinking Water Quality Regulator for Scotland for the years -. The DWQR is responsible for regulating public water supplied by Scottish Water, which was established in . Prior to this water quality was the responsibility of separate local authorities. A Scottish Water spokesperson said: â€œScottish Water, like other UK water companies, operates in a highly regulated industry where public health is the prime concern and delivering high quality drinking water to customers across Scotland is a key priority for us.â€œWe carried out over , tests in  at customer taps, our service reservoirs and treatment works to ensure customers receive consistently high quality drinking water and more than . per cent of tests at customer taps passed stringent quality standards.â€Â©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings
